Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of these Codified Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Part One - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE 
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF HURRICANE 
ARTICLE 101. - CODIFIED ORDINANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State law references and cross references- See sectional histories for similar State law; maximum penalty permitted, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(58); authority to impose penalties, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-2(11); codification of ordinances, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-4(b). 

Sec. 101.01. - Designation; citation; headings. 
(a)  All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the City as revised, recodified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component codes, chapters, articles and sections shall be known and designated as the Codified Ordinances of Hurricane, West Virginia, for which designation "Codified Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, chapter, article and section headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances. No provision of the Codified Ordinances shall be held invalid by reason of deficiency in any such heading. 
(b)  All references to codes, chapters, articles and sections are to such components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code." Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by the number, such as "Section 101.01." 
(Code 1991, § 101.01) 
Sec. 101.02. - General definitions. 
    As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless otherwise expressly provided or the context otherwise requires: 
(a)  City means the City of Hurricane, West Virginia. 
(b)  Council means the legislative authority of the City. 
(c)  County means Putnam County, West Virginia. 
(d)  Land or lands and real estate or real property include lands, tenements and hereditaments, and all rights thereto and interests therein except chattel interests. 
(e)  Laws of the State includes the Constitution of the State and the Constitution of the United States, and treaties and laws made in pursuance thereof. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(f)  Offense includes every act or omission for which a fine, forfeiture or punishment is imposed by law. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(g)  Or may be read "and," and and may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
(h)  Owner , when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property. 
(i)  Person or whoever includes individuals, firms, companies, groups, corporations, societies, associations and partnerships. 
(j)  Personal estate or personal property includes goods, chattels, real and personal, money, credits, investments and the evidences thereof. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(k)  Preceding, succeeding or following used in reference to any section or sections of an article means next preceding, next succeeding or next following that in which such reference is made. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(l)  Premises , as applied to property, includes land and building. 
(m)  Property or estate embraces both real and personal estate. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(n)  Public place includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, schoolyard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance or any other place for the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement. 
(o)  Registered mail includes certified mail. 
(p)  Shall is mandatory; may is permissive. 
(q)  State means the State of West Virginia or any department, division, commission, board, educational or other institution of the State. 
(r)  Street includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways, viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the City. 
(s)  Tenant or occupant , as applied to premises, includes any person holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such premises alone or with others. 
(t)  Time. The standard of time within the City shall be Eastern Standard Time, except that during any period when, by Federal or State law or by City ordinance, Eastern Daylight Saving Time is in effect, then, during such period, Eastern Daylight Saving Time shall be the standard of time within the City. 
(u)  Written or in writing includes any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing, engraving, writing or otherwise. But when the signature of any person is required, it must be in his own proper handwriting, or his mark, attested, proved or acknowledged: Provided, that unless a provision of the Codified Ordinances specifically provides otherwise, an electronic signature satisfies this signature requirement if the electronic signature meets the requirements of any state law pertaining thereto. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(v)  W. Va. Code means the West Virginia Code, as amended. 
(Code 1991, § 101.02) 
Sec. 101.03. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(b)  Gender and plural. A word importing the singular number only may be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; a word importing the plural number only may be applied to one person or thing as well as to several; and a word importing the masculine gender only may be applied to females as well as males. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(c)  Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, or if the last be a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday it shall also be excluded. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-1 et seq.) 
(d)  Joint authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more persons confer such authority upon a majority of them, and not upon any less number. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-10) 
(e)  Officer, department. Whenever a reference is made to a particular officer, employee, department, board, commission or other agency without further qualification, it shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Hurricane." 
(f)  Tense. Words used in the past or present tense may include the future, as well as the past and present. 
(g)  Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which contains any express provision excluding such construction, or when the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto. 
(Code 1991, § 101.03) 
Sec. 101.04. - Repeal of repealing act; effect of repeal. 
(a)  When a law which has repealed another is itself repealed, the former law shall not be revived without express words for that purpose. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-9) 
(b)  The repeal of a law, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any offense committed, or penalty or punishment incurred, before the repeal took effect, or the law expired, save only that the proceedings thereafter had shall conform as far as practicable to the laws in force at the time such proceedings take place, unless otherwise specially provided; and that if any penalty or punishment be mitigated by the new law, such new law may, with the consent of the party affected thereby, be applied to any judgment pronounced after it has taken effect. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-8) 
(c)  The repeal by any provision of the Codified Ordinances of an ordinance validating previous acts, contracts or transactions shall not affect the validity of such acts, contracts or transactions, but the same shall remain as valid as if there had been no such repeal, but no further. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-11) 
(Code 1991, § 101.04) 
Sec. 101.05. - Construction of section references. 
(a)  When reference is made to any section or group of sections of the Codified Ordinances, such reference shall extend to and include any amendment of or supplement to the section or group of sections so referred to or any section or sections hereafter enacted in lieu thereof; and unless otherwise provided, whenever a reference to a section or group of sections is made in any amendment or supplement to any section of the Codified Ordinances hereafter enacted, such reference shall be deemed to refer to the section or sections as the same shall then stand or as thereafter amended. 
(b)  Whenever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a section or an inclusive group of sections, such reference shall be construed to mean a violation of any provision of the section or sections included in such reference. 
(c)  References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is superseded by the Codified Ordinances. 
(d)  If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and the last number or letters in the series are deemed to be included. 
(Code 1991, § 101.05) 
Sec. 101.06. - Acts by agent or deputy. 
    When a section requires that an act be done by an officer or person, it shall be sufficient if it be done by his agent or deputy, unless it be such as cannot lawfully be done by deputation. (W. Va. Code, § 2-2-5) 
(Code 1991, § 101.06) 
Sec. 101.07. - Conflicting provisions. 
    If the provisions of different codes, articles or sections of the Codified Ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the meaning or legal effect of the questions of the subject matter taken as a whole. 
(Code 1991, § 101.07) 
Sec. 101.08. - Separability. 
    Each section of the Codified Ordinances and every part of each section is an independent section and part of a section, and the holding of any section or a part thereof or its application to any person or circumstances to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause does not affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof or its application. 
(Code 1991, § 101.08) 
Sec. 101.09. - Code imposes no liability. 
(a)  Nothing in these Codified Ordinances or any other ordinance or resolution of Council shall be construed to impose any liability upon the City or upon any person for any act or omission required or permitted thereby when such act or omission is otherwise lawful, in good faith and without malice or mischievous intent and, in the case of any City officer or employee, is in the line of duty and within the scope of his authority. 
(b)  The City Solicitor shall defend City officers and employees against all claims, demands, actions, suits, prosecutions and other proceedings brought against them for their acts or omissions while acting in the line of duty and within the purview of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 1-9; Code 1991, § 101.09) 
Sec. 101.10. - Sectional history notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the sections. 
Sec. 101.11. - Editor's notes and references. 
    The editor's notes and state law reference notes in the Codified Ordinances are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to assist the user of the Codified Ordinances. 
Sec. 101.12. - Certain ordinances not affected. 
    Nothing in the Codified Ordinances or the ordinance adopting the Codified Ordinances shall be deemed to affect the validity of any of the following ordinances, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect under their own terms and conditions: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the City or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the City; 
(2)  Any ordinance authorizing the execution of agreements with other governments or agencies; 
(3)  Any personnel pay or classification plan or other ordinance or part of an ordinance fixing salaries of officers or employees of the City; 
(4)  Any appropriation ordinance; 
(5)  Any right or franchise granted to any person, firm or corporation; 
(6)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the City; 
(7)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the City; 
(8)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the City, or providing regulations for the same; 
(10)  Any ordinance annexing property to the City or excluding property from the City; 
(11)  Any zoning ordinance of the City; 
(12)  Any taxation ordinance not inconsistent with the Codified Ordinances; 
(13)  Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones or dealing with parking meters, parking meter zones or flow of traffic generally, not inconsistent with the Codified Ordinances; 
(14)  Any ordinance prescribing City rates, fees and charges; 
(15)  Any temporary or special ordinance. 
Sec. 101.13. - Prior offenses, rights, etc., not affected. 
    Nothing in the Codified Ordinances or in the ordinance adopting the Codified Ordinances shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of the Codified Ordinances. 
Sec. 101.14. - Supplementation of Codified Ordinances. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to the Codified Ordinances shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the Council. A supplement to the Codified Ordinances shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the Council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Codified Ordinances. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Codified Ordinances and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Codified Ordinances will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to the Codified Ordinances, all portions of the Codified Ordinances which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Codified Ordinances by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to the Codified Ordinances, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them in the Codified Ordinances. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate headings for sections and other subdivisions of the Codified Ordinances printed in the supplement, and make changes in such headings; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Codified Ordinances and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this Part," "this Article," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Codified Ordinances which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Codified Ordinances); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Codified Ordinances; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Codified Ordinances. 
Sec. 101.15. - Altering Codified Ordinances. 
    It shall be unlawful to change or amend by addition or deletion any part of the Codified Ordinances or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with the Codified Ordinances in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City to be misrepresented. 
Sec. 101.99. - General penalty. 
    Whenever, in the codified ordinances or in any ordinance of the City, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be fined not more than $2,500.00 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1991, § 101.99; Ord. of 6-3-2013(2)) 
ARTICLE 103. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State law references and cross references- Officers generally, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-7; oath of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-8; terms of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-9; vacancies, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-10. 

Sec. 103.01. - Municipal authorities; elective officers; qualifications; vacancies. 
(a)  The municipal authorities of the City shall consist of a Mayor, City Recorder and five members of Council who shall be elected by the qualified voters of the City. The Mayor, Recorder and councilmen shall be residents of the City and shall be qualified voters entitled to vote for members of its governing body. Each official so elected shall continue to be a resident of the City during his entire term of office. 
(b)  If any person elected to Council fails to qualify within 20 days after he is declared elected, or resigns, or ceases to be a resident of the City, then his office shall thereby be vacated and Council shall fill such vacancy by the election of some qualified person for such unexpired term. No person shall be declared elected by Council unless he receives the votes of at least a majority of the members elected thereto and the minutes of such meeting show that fact. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-1; Code 1991, § 103.01) 
Sec. 103.02. - Elective officers; election and term. 
    The Mayor, City Recorder and members of Council shall be elected on the second Tuesday of June and shall hold office for a term of four years, beginning on the first day of July after their election. 
(Ord. of 3-2-1987; Code 1991, § 103.02) 
Sec. 103.03. - Vacancy in elective office; appointed officers. 
(a)  Whenever a vacancy for any cause whatever occurs in the office of Mayor, the Recorder shall perform the duties of the Mayor and be invested with all of his power and authority. 
(b)  Whenever a vacancy for any cause whatever occurs in the office of Recorder, Council shall elect some qualified person to fill such vacancy until the next City election, and until his successor is elected and qualified. 
(c)  Whenever a vacancy occurs for any cause whatever in the office of any appointive officer, his successor shall be appointed by the person making the original appointment, or his successor in office. 
(d)  All elective and appointive officers of the City shall hold their respective offices until their successors are elected, or appointed, and qualified, unless sooner removed. 
(e)  In the event the Police Chief is removed, for reasons other than disciplinary, and he was a member of the department prior to his appointment, he shall return to the position of police officer with a rank commensurate with his years of service, as determined by the Council but not less than the rank held at his time of appointment. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-8; Code 1991, § 103.03; Ord. of 10-4-2010(2)) 
Sec. 103.04. - Officers in addition to elective officers; salaries; clerk. 
(a)  In addition to the municipal authorities mentioned in Section 103.01, the City shall have a City Manager, Treasurer, Municipal Court Judge, Chief of Police, one or more City Solicitors, Building Code Enforcement Official, Humane Officer or Officers and such number of police officers as Council may direct. All the officers named in this and the preceding sections shall be paid proper salaries, which shall be fixed by Council. 
(b)  The Mayor shall appoint the City Treasurer, Municipal Court Judge, Chief of Police, City Solicitors, Building Code Enforcement Official, and Humane Officer or Officers, and, except for Humane Officers and City Solicitors, these appointments shall require confirmation by Council. 
(c)  The City Recorder may be appointed to serve also as City Treasurer. 
(d)  A clerk may be hired, at a salary provided in the annual budget, to act as assistant to City officials and Clerk of Council. The City Recorder may fill this position. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-10; Code 1991, § 103.04) 
Sec. 103.05. - Duties of officers and employees. 
(a)  Council shall prescribe the duties of all of the officers and employees of the City, and all such officers and employees shall perform faithfully and diligently all the duties so described by Council, and the failure to do so by any officer or employee of the City shall be deemed neglect of duty and good cause for dismissal. 
(b)  Council shall review and approve job descriptions, policies and procedures for all employees of the City. Employees shall be advised of changes to City policies and procedures and acknowledge their advisement of same. Failure of an employee to accept the City policies and procedures shall be good cause for dismissal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-13; Code 1991, § 103.05; Amend. No. 2004-003, 2-17-2004) 
Sec. 103.06. - Inspection; right of entry. 
    Whenever any officer or employee of the City is required or authorized by statute, the provisions of these Codified Ordinances or any ordinance or resolution, or rules and regulations or orders issued thereunder, in order to carry out his duties thereunder, to enter any premises or vehicle for the purpose of making an inspection thereof or of anything therein contained, such officer or employee shall have the right to enter any such premises or vehicle in accordance with law at any reasonable time and upon display of proper identification in pursuance of such duties; provided, that this section shall not be construed as purporting to authorize an unreasonable search and seizure prohibited by Section 3-6, Article III of the Constitution of West Virginia. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-18; Code 1991, § 103.06) 
Sec. 103.07. - City books and records available; protection. 
(a)  Except as may be provided otherwise by state law, these Codified Ordinances or other ordinance to safeguard the security of license tax returns, personnel records and other confidential information, all records, books, maps, documents and other papers which are maintained on file in any City office shall be open for inspection and use by residents of the City and others having an interest therein during all regular business hours, but none shall be removed from the office of its custodian except by authority of the Mayor, the City Recorder or Council, or pursuant to a valid subpoena duces tecum issuing from a court or officer having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(b)  No person shall, without proper authority as provided in subsection (a) of this section, remove from the office of its custodian any record, book, map, file, document or other paper which is maintained on file in any City office or court, without giving written receipt therefor to the custodian thereof, nor shall any person fail to return any such item to its proper custodian within the time set by the custodian for its return. 
(c)  No person shall willfully destroy, obliterate, secrete, deface, mark upon, disturb the arrangement of, damage or otherwise tamper with any record, book, map, file, document or other paper which is maintained on file in any City office or court. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-19; Code 1991, § 103.07) 
Sec. 103.08. - Limited authority to administer oaths; false swearing. 
(a)  The Mayor, the presiding officer of Council for the time being, the presiding officer of any Council committee or of any board, commission or other body of the City Government, and each City officer, his deputies and assistants, to whom any sworn report, return, certificate, pledge or statement, whether oral or in writing, is required to be made or submitted by any person pursuant to any provision of these Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or resolution of Council, shall have authority to administer the oath so required; provided, that nothing in this section is construed as purporting to authorize the administration of any oath which, by law, is required to be administered by a judicial officer, notary public or other officer authorized by statute to administer oaths, nor shall this section be construed as purporting to authorize the taking of any acknowledgment of any signature or seal for the purpose of recording in the office of the Clerk of the County Court or elsewhere other than in the office of the City Recorder or some other officer of this City. 
(b)  No person to whom an oath has been administered pursuant to this section shall knowingly make any false report, return, certificate or statement, oral or written, concerning any matter whatsoever in violation of such oath. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-1; Code 1991, § 103.08) 
Sec. 103.09. - Authority of deputies, assistants and subordinates. 
    Authority vested in and duties imposed upon City officers by state law, these Codified Ordinances or other ordinances and resolutions of Council may, when they so authorize, be exercised or performed by their deputies, assistants and other subordinates, to the extent not prohibited by state law, these Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or resolution of Council. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-2; Code 1991, § 103.09) 
ARTICLE 104. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 104.01. - Appointment. 
    The City Manager shall be appointed by Council for an indefinite term as provided by law. Before taking office the City Manager shall furnish a fidelity bond in the amount of $50,000.00, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office, with a corporation licensed to do business in this State as surety. Such bond shall be filed with the Recorder after being approved by Council. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.01) 
Sec. 104.02. - General duties. 
(a)  The City Manager shall have and exercise all powers and duties assigned to the position by statute and such other authority as may be granted by Council. The City Manager shall be charged with the enforcement of the ordinances of the City insofar as their enforcement is within the powers of the City. 
(b)  The City Manager shall update the Council monthly, shall keep the Council informed as to the affairs of the City and shall recommend to Council such actions as may be necessary or expedient for the welfare of the City. 
(c)  The City Manager shall have custody of and be responsible for maintaining all bonds, and records and papers in such fireproof vault as the City shall provide. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.02) 
Sec. 104.03. - Employees. 
    The City Manager shall review the qualifications of prospective employees, other than those authorized by the Mayor or Council for hiring, employee evaluations and/or employee disciplinary claims. The City Manager may delegate to any other official or supervisor the authority to hire or discharge any employee under such official or supervisor. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.03) 
Sec. 104.04. - Officers and departments. 
(a)  All appointive offices of the City shall be filled by appointment by the City Manager, except where otherwise provided by City Code and such City Manager shall report to Council such appointments, for their approval, or any removal from office, before such action is final. 
(b)  Every administrative department of the City shall be under the supervision and approval of the City Manager, who shall have the power to remove from office any officer appointed by such City Manager, with the approval of Council. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.04) 
Sec. 104.05. - Contracts. 
(a)  The City Manager shall examine and approve all proposed contracts to which the City may be a party, and may sign on behalf of the City any contract authorized by Council, excepting where Council directs that some other officer or officers shall do so. 
(b)  The City Manager shall be responsible for execution of all terms of any contract to which the City is a party and shall ensure that such terms are fully performed by all parties thereto. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.05) 
Sec. 104.06. - Purchases. 
    The City Manager shall be the general purchasing agent of the City, and except where specific provision to the contrary is made by law, shall approve all purchases of supplies, materials and equipment authorized by Council, in the manner prescribed by and subject to the limitations imposed by law. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.06) 
Sec. 104.07. - Appropriation and levies. 
(a)  The City Manager shall cause to be prepared each year the annual appropriation budget in time for consideration and enactment by Council during the first quarter of the calendar year; and shall prepare the tax levy ordinance for passage and file a certified copy thereof with the State Tax Commissioner within the time required by law. 
(b)  The City Manager shall keep current accounts of the amounts appropriated and the amounts spent out of each appropriation, showing the unexpended appropriations at all times. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.07) 
Sec. 104.08. - Accounts. 
    The City Manager shall keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the City, including the current and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and anticipated revenue of all Municipal funds and accounts; and shall see to the collection of all money due the City. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.08) 
Sec. 104.09. - Inventories. 
    The City Manager shall keep a current inventory showing all real and personal property of the City and its location, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such property including equipment, buildings, parks and all other City property, which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and control. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.09) 
Sec. 104.10. - Reports and publications. 
    The City Manager shall be responsible for the publication of all notices, ordinances or other documents required by law to be published, and shall prepare or cause to be prepared, all reports which the City or any of the officials thereof are required by law to prepare. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.10) 
Sec. 104.11. - Elections. 
    The City Manager shall assist the Recorder with all notices, ballots and election supplies necessary in connection with the municipal elections. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.11) 
Sec. 104.12. - Records; certificates. 
(a)  The City Manager shall prepare and have custody of all Municipal records required by law to be kept by the City and not by a specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep or maintain records, the City Manager shall make available to such officer assistance for the preparation of such records and shall make available a place for the custody of such records. 
(b)  Where the law requires or provides for certification of any records or documents by any officer of the City, the City Manager shall cause such records or documents to be properly prepared and presented to such officer for his signature. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.12) 
Sec. 104.13. - Collector and comptroller. 
    The City Manager shall be ex officio City Collector and City Comptroller unless such offices, or either them, are duly filled by appointment; and shall perform the duties of each such office in the absence of such appointment to either of them. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.13) 
Sec. 104.14. - Maps; plats. 
    The City Manager shall cause to be kept a complete set of maps and plats showing the location of all City utilities, and other Municipal properties, all streets and other public places and all lots or parcels of land subdivided according to law. These records shall be filed in a safe and secure environment. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.14) 
Sec. 104.15. - Grants and capital projects. 
    The City Manager shall coordinate and manage grant requests as well as capital projects for improvements for all City Departments. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.15) 
Sec. 104.16. - Office. 
    The City Manager shall maintain an office in the Municipal Building and shall spend such time in the performance of the aforementioned duties as may be required by the Council. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2003, § 104.16) 
ARTICLE 105. - ELECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State law references and cross references- Municipal elections, W. Va. Code, § 3-1-2a; municipal voting precincts, W. Va. Code, § 3-1-6; municipal precinct registration records, W. Va. Code, § 3-1-27; absentee voting in municipal elections, W. Va. Code, § 3-3-13; integration of municipal elections with systems of permanent registration, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-13; special municipal elections, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-15a. 

Sec. 105.01. - Candidates for public office; procedures for filing; fees. 
(a)  Placement of candidate on ballot. Any person who is otherwise qualified for public office may be placed on the ballot for election of any Municipal office by either of the following methods: 
(1)  Convention. Any candidate who shall be nominated at a Convention must be nominated between the period beginning February 1 and no later than March 31 of the election year. Pursuant to the election laws of the State of West Virginia, notice of such convention shall give the manner, date, time and location of such Convention by publication of notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation published in the vicinity of the City. Such publication shall be made two consecutive weeks in a qualified newspaper no sooner than 14 days prior to such Convention. 
(2)  Recognized parties. The political parties recognized to hold Conventions are the Citizens Party and the Peoples Party. Participating persons attending the Conventions must be citizens of the City of Hurricane. 
(3)  Quorum and procedures. A quorum of not less than 15 shall be required to hold a qualified Convention. An election of a Chairperson and an Executive Committee of not less than three members shall be held. The Chairperson shall conduct the Convention and open the floor for nominations for candidates for Mayor, Recorder and five Council positions. Any and all nominations made at such Conventions shall be certified, by the Executive Board, to the City Recorder no later than April 1 of the election year, and shall be accompanied by all necessary filing forms and fees. 
(4)  Petition. Any candidate seeking a public office in the City may be placed on the ballot for election to said office, if such candidate shall present, no later than April 1 of the election year, a petition, signed by no less than ten percent of the total number of persons voting in the last regular City general election. Such petition shall contain the names and valid signatures of qualified voters, and shall be presented to the City Recorder, together with the appropriate filing form and fee. 
(5)  Filing fees. The filing fees for public offices are established as follows: $200.00 for the office of Mayor; $100.00 for the office of City Recorder; and $50.00 for the office of City Council. 
(b)  Filing fee for party nominating slate of candidates. In the event that a party nominates an entire slate of candidates for office, such party shall pay a filing fee of $550.00. 
(Code 1991, § 105.01; Ord. of 8-1-1994; Ord. of 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 105.02. - Ballot position; preparation of ballots; publication of ballot; methods of voting. 
(a)  The drawing for ballot positions by candidates shall take place on the 70th day next preceding the general election. 
(b)  The preparation of the election ballot and the method of voting, together with all other aspects of all City elections, shall fully conform, where applicable to the requirement of Chapter Three of the West Virginia Code (W. Va. Code, § 3-1-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1991, § 105.02; Ord. of 8-1-1994; Ord. of 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 105.03. - Date of election; date of assumption of office. 
(a)  In every election year, the election shall be held on the second Tuesday in the month of June of the election year. All polling places shall be open at 6:30 a.m., and shall remain open until 7:30 p.m. 
(b)  Each successful candidate for public office shall assume full responsibility for his office on the first day of the month of July of the election year. 
(Code 1991, § 105.03; Ord. of 8-1-1994) 
Sec. 105.04. - Voter registration; eligibility. 
    The registration of voters of the City of Hurricane shall be integrated with the system of permanent registration of voters established by W. Va. Code, § 3-2-1. No voter otherwise qualified shall be permitted to vote an unchallenged ballot at any election within the City unless he is duly registered under the provisions of West Virginia law. The registration records shall be maintained by and shall remain in the possession of the Clerk of the County Commission, except for use in municipal elections. 
(Code 1991, § 105.04; Ord. of 8-1-1994; Ord. of 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 105.05. - Duties of city recorder. 
    The City Recorder, acting in accord with State law, shall perform such duties relating to all municipal elections held under the municipal authority as the clerks of the county and circuit courts of the county perform under State laws in relation to State, County and district elections in the County; and he shall likewise be the custodian of all ballots, tally sheets, and other related materials pertaining to the election. 
(Code 1991, § 105.05; Ord. of 8-1-1994) 
ARTICLE 107. - ETHICS IN GOVERNMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State law references and cross references- West Virginia Governmental Ethics Act, W. Va. Code, ch. 6B. 

Sec. 107.01. - Governmental Ethics Act adopted. 
    Council hereby finds that the purposes of the West Virginia Governmental Ethics Act (W. Va. Code, ch. 6B) have reasonable, necessary and appropriate application to matters involving all elected and appointed municipal officials and employees, whether full-time or part-time, who derive a salary, payment of wages or other direct remuneration from the City, and does now hereby affirm, ratify and adopt such state defined purposes as being the same purposes of this municipal government ethics article, without specifically republishing such state purposes herein. 
(Code 1991, § 107.01; Ord. of 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 107.02. - Statutory sections adopted. 
    Council further hereby finds that for the purpose of assisting in the administration of the provisions of this Article, various statutory sections of the aforesaid State Act shall be hereby expressly adopted and incorporated as provisions of this Article, except as otherwise expressly provided herein, and which state statutory sections specifically hereby adopted and incorporated herein are as follows: W. Va. Code, §§ 6B-1-1-6B-1-5 and 6B-2-5. 
(Code 1991, § 107.02; Ord. of 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 107.03. - Provisions not applicable. 
    Notwithstanding the affirmation and adoption of the purposes of the State Act and further the specific adoption of the selected, statutory sections which were immediately hereinbefore set forth in Section 107.02, Council specifically finds that certain statutory provisions of the aforesaid State Act are either inapplicable to the administration of this Article or would otherwise be unduly burdensome for the City to require and administer, and specifically, Council finds that the purposes of the State Act and of this Article can be effectively executed at the municipal level without the specific adoption and incorporation of the statutory provisions of W. Va. Code, §§ 6B-2-6 and 6B-2-7, respecting financial disclosure, and West Virginia Code Ch. 6B, Art. 3 (W. Va. Code, § 6B-3-1 et seq.) relating to regulation and registration of lobbyists, and which statutory provisions Council hereby expressly opts not to include as provisions of this Article, and affirmatively elects that such provisions shall not apply to this City and its officers and employees. 
(Code 1991, § 107.03; Ord. of 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 107.04. - Amendments to state statutes. 
    Any amendment to any of the aforesaid statutory provisions of the State which are expressly herein adopted and incorporated as provisions of this Article, shall upon enactment by the State Legislature, pursuant to the state-prescribed effective date thereof, be deemed to be an amendment to this Article unless the City expressly opts not to adopt any such amendment by ordinance duly adopted by Council evidencing the non-adoption of such amendments. 
(Code 1991, § 107.04; Ord. of 11-6-1989) 
ARTICLE 109. - CONTRACTS AND PURCHASES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State law references and cross references- State purchasing, W. Va. Code, § 5A-3-1 et seq.; purchasing, competitive bidding, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-10. 

Sec. 109.01 - Advertisement of bids generally; contracts. 
    Whenever any contract is proposed to be entered into by the City involving the expenditure of more than $25,000.00, the City Manager shall publish an advertisement calling for bids for this work unless the decision is to do this work with City personnel or others employed by the City for such purposes. The time for opening such bids shall not be less than five days from the date of the first publication of the advertisement. The advertisement shall be printed for at least two successive weeks in two newspapers of general circulation in the City, preceding the time of opening the bids, and such publication shall be deemed reasonable and due notice. Council shall reserve the right to reject any and all bids, but the contract, if let, shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder. Council reserves the right to enter into contracts that do not exceed two years that pertain to health, property and liability insurance. 
(Code 1991, § 109.01; Ord. of 7-2-2012(1); Ord. of 4-1-2013; Ord. of 4-1-2013(1)) 
Sec. 109.02. - Contents of advertisements. 
    Notice to bidders shall state: 
(1)  The nature of the work; 
(2)  The place where the plans and specifications and forms of contract may be seen; 
(3)  The amount of cash or bond to be deposited with the City Treasurer as hereinafter required; 
(4)  The time up to which the bids shall be received and the hour and place of opening the bids; and 
(5)  The right of Council to reject any and all bids. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-2; Code 1991, § 109.02) 
Sec. 109.03. - Additional invitations and advertising. 
    Nothing in Section 109.01 shall preclude Council from directing that invitations to bid shall also be given to contractors in other localities believed to be qualified to perform the work sought to be performed, or from causing additional advertisements from being published in other localities; provided, that all such invitations and advertisements conform to the requirements of Section 109.02 and no prospective bidder shall be given any information not given to all other prospective bidders. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-3; Code 1991, § 109.03) 
Sec. 109.04. - Bidding procedure. 
(a)  Submission of bids. Each bid for such work shall be made upon a blank form, to be furnished by the City Manager and shall be placed in a sealed envelope addressed to the City Manager, and endorsed "Proposals for ____________ / ____________ / ____________ ." Each bid shall be signed by the bidder, or by an authorized officer or agent where the bid is by firm or corporation. The bid shall not be opened before the time and hour fixed in the notice. 
(b)  Deposits by bidders. The amount of the cash or bond deposited shall be equal to five percent of the total cost of the work as estimated by the City Manager; provided, that no deposit shall be less than $25.00. The deposit made shall be conditioned so that the successful bidder enters into a written contract to do the work bid for according to the terms of his bid, and furnishes approved security within ten days after the award has been made and the bidder notified thereof. 
(c)  Bidder's deposit forfeited. If any bidder to whom a contract is awarded fails to enter into a contract and to furnish approved security within the time specified, his deposit shall be forfeited to the City and the City Manager may advertise for new bids. 
(d)  Disposition of deposits. Whenever a contract for public work or supplies has been awarded, the City Manager shall be authorized to refund the deposit of each unsuccessful bidder. The deposit of the successful bidder shall be retained until the contract is entered into and approved by the City Manager. 
(e)  Opening of bids. No bids shall be opened and read before the time indicated in the advertisement. 
(f)  Rejection of bids. If in any bid, blanks are not properly filled up so as to make the bid complete and without an ambiguity as to its intent and meaning, or if a bid has any alteration or erasure upon it, or if it is not properly signed, or if the certificate of deposit has not been enclosed with the bid as hereinbefore provided, then the bid shall be rejected. 
(g)  Action upon bids; award of contract. Upon the opening and consideration of all bids by the City Manager, he shall submit them to Council, together with his calculations and recommendations, for appropriate action with respect to awarding the contract; provided, that Council or the City Manager has the authority to reject all bids. 
(Code 1979, §§ 2-5-4-2-5-10; Code 1991, § 109.04) 
ARTICLE 111. - EMERGENCY SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State law references and cross references- Homeland security and emergency management, W. Va. Code, § 15-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 111.01. - Policy and purpose. 
(a)  In view of the existing and increasing possibility of the occurrence of disasters of unprecedented size and destructiveness, resulting from terrorism, enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, or from fire, flood, earthquakes or other natural or manmade causes, and in order to ensure that preparations of the City will be adequate to deal with such disasters, and generally to provide for the common defense and to protect the public peace, health and safety, and to preserve the lives and property of the people of this City, it is hereby found and declared to be necessary: 
(1)  To create a City emergency organization; 
(2)  To provide for the rendering of mutual aid to other cities within the State, and, if necessary, and only by compact with the approval of the Governor of the State, the neighboring cities and counties of another state; 
(3)  To cooperate with the State Government with respect to carrying out emergency services and homeland security functions. 
(b)  It is further declared to be the purpose of this Article, and the policy of this City, that all homeland security and emergency management functions of the City be coordinated to the maximum extent with the State Government, including its various departments and agencies, with other cities and localities, and with private agencies of every type, to the end that the most effective preparation and use may be made of this City's manpower, resources and facilities for dealing with any disaster that may occur. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-1; Code 1991, § 111.01) 
Sec. 111.02. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Emergency services means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to protect, respond and recover, to prevent, detect, deter and mitigate, to minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by flooding, terrorism, enemy attack, sabotage or other natural or other manmade causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, communications, radiological, chemical and other special weapons defense, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. Disaster includes the imminent threat of disaster as well as its occurrence and any power or authority exercisable on account of a disaster may be exercised during the period when there is an imminent threat thereof. 
(Code 1991, § 111.02) 
Sec. 111.03. - Emergency services council. 
    There is hereby created an Emergency Services Council, hereinafter called Council, which shall consist of five residents appointed by City Council, who shall advise the City Emergency Services Director (provided for in the next section) on all matters pertaining to emergency services. The Chairperson of the Council shall be elected by the members. The members thereof shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance of their duties. The City Manager, with the approval of the City Council shall be responsible for and have general direction and control of the emergency services of the City and have such other powers as are granted and conferred by this Article which are not inconsistent with other ordinances of this City. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-3; Code 1991, § 111.03) 
Sec. 111.04. - Director of emergency services. 
    The City Manager is hereby authorized to appoint a Director of Emergency Services, approved by City Council, who shall perform such duties as are imposed upon him by this Article and as are delegated to him when not contrary to other ordinances of this City. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-4; Code 1991, § 111.04) 
Sec. 111.05. - Duties of director. 
    The Director shall coordinate the activities of all organizations for emergency services within this City and shall maintain liaison with and cooperate with the emergency services within the State and within the State Government. When such authority is delegated to him by the City Manager, the Director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the City Organization for Emergency Services subject to the direction and control of the City Manager. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-5; Code 1991, § 111.05) 
Sec. 111.06. - Other duties of director. 
(a)  In performing his duties under this Article, the Director is authorized to cooperate with the State Government, with other cities and counties, and with private agencies in all matters pertaining to the emergency services of the City and/or the State. 
(b)  In performing his duties under this Article, and to effect its policy and purpose, the Director is further authorized and empowered: 
(1)  To make, amend and rescind the necessary orders, rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this Article within the limits of the authority conferred upon him, with due consideration of the plans of the State Government. 
(2)  To prepare a comprehensive plan and program for the emergency services of the City, such plan and program to be integrated into and coordinated with the emergency services plans of the State Government, and of other cities and counties within the State to the fullest extent. 
(3)  In accordance with such plan and program for this City, to procure supplies and equipment, to institute training programs and public information programs, and to take all the preparatory steps including the partial or full mobilization of the Emergency Services Organization in advance of actual disaster, to ensure the furnishing of adequately trained an equipped forces of emergency services personnel in time of need. 
(4)  To make such studies and surveys of the City industries, resources and facilities in this as may be necessary to ascertain the capabilities of the City emergency services, and to plan for the most efficient emergency use thereof. 
(5)  On behalf of this City, to enter into mutual aid arrangements with other cities and counties within this State, and also, with the approval of the Governor of the State, with emergency services organizations of other states, for reciprocal emergency aid and assistance in case of disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(6)  To delegate any administrative authority invested in him under this Article and to provide for the subdelegation of any such authority. 
(7)  To cooperate with the Governor and the West Virginia Division of Homeland Security and Emergency Management and the officials and agencies of other cities and to coordinate the emergency services of the City and State, including the direction or control of: 
a.  Blackouts and practice blackouts, air raid drills, mobilization of emergency services forces and other tests and exercises; 
b.  Warnings and signals for drills or attacks and the mechanical devices to be used in connection therewith; 
c.  The effective screening or extinguishing of all lights and lighting devices and appliances; 
d.  Shutting off water mains, gas mains, electric power connections and the suspension of all other utility services; 
e.  The conduct of civilians and the movement and cessation of movement of pedestrians and vehicular traffic during, prior to and subsequent to drills or attack; 
f.  Public meetings or gatherings; and 
g.  The evacuation and reception of the civilian population. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-6; Code 1991, § 111.06) 
Sec. 111.07. - Mutual aid arrangements. 
(a)  The Director of the Organization for Emergency Services may, in collaboration with other public and private agencies within this State, develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements for reciprocal emergency aid and assistance in case of disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. Such arrangements shall be consistent with the state emergency services plan and program, and in time of emergency, the City Organization shall render assistance in accordance with mutual aid agreements. 
(b)  The Director of the Organization may, subject to the approval of the Governor, enter into mutual aid arrangements with emergency service and civil defense organizations or agencies of other states for reciprocal emergency aid and assistance in case of disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-7; Code 1991, § 111.07) 
Sec. 111.08. - Appropriations and authority to accept services, gifts, grants and loans. 
(a)  Whenever the Federal or State Government, or any agency or officer thereof, shall offer to this City services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant, or loan, for purposes relating to homeland security or emergency services, the City, after consultation and coordination with the Secretary of the West Virginia Department of Military Affairs and Public Safety, and acting with the consent of the Governor and through the City Manager, may accept such offer. Upon such acceptance, the City Manager or City Council may authorize any officer of the City to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the City, and subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. 
(b)  Whenever any person, firm or corporation shall offer the City, services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds by way of gift or loan, for purposes relating to homeland security or emergency services, the City, after consultation and coordination with the Secretary of the West Virginia Department of Military Affairs and Public Safety, and acting through the City Manager or City Council, may accept such offer. Upon such acceptance, the City Manager or City Council may authorize any officer of the City to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds on behalf of the City, and subject to the terms of the offer. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-8; Code 1991, § 111.08) 
Sec. 111.09. - Utilization of existing services and facilities. 
    In carrying out the provisions of this Article, the City Manager is directed to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the City, to the maximum extent practicable, and the officers and personnel of all such departments, offices and agencies are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the Emergency Services Organization of the City upon request. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-9; Code 1991, § 111.09) 
Sec. 111.10. - Political activity prohibited. 
    The Organization for Emergency Services established under the authority of this Article shall not participate in any form of political activity, nor shall it be employed directly or indirectly for political purposes. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-10; Code 1991, § 111.10) 
Sec. 111.11. - Cumulative effect of article. 
    This Article shall not be deemed to repeal any existing ordinances on this subject, but shall be cumulative thereto. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-11; Code 1991, § 111.11) 
Sec. 111.12. - Enforcement. 
    The Organization for Emergency Services established pursuant to this Article and the officers thereof shall execute and enforce such orders, rules and regulations as may be made by the City Manager or Director of Emergency Services under authority of this Article. Such organization shall have available for inspection at their offices all orders, rules and regulations made by the City Manager or Director, under his authority. 
(Code 1979, § 8-1-12; Code 1991, § 111.12) 
ARTICLE 115. - COUNCIL[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State law references and cross references- Open governmental proceedings, W. Va. Code, § 6-9A-1 et seq.; composition of municipal governing body, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-7; oath of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-8; terms of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-9; vacancies, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-10; proceedings of governing bodies, W. Va. Code, § 8-9-1 et seq.; general powers and duties, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-1 et seq.; adoption of rules, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(45); extraterritorial exercise of powers, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-19. 

Sec. 115.01. - Title; how constituted. 
    The City shall have a council, which shall be known and styled as the "Council of the City of Hurricane" and shall consist of five councilmen to be voted for by all the voters of the City, all of whom shall be nominated, voted for and elected in the manner herein provided. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-1; Code 1991, § 115.01) 
Sec. 115.02. - Meetings; regular, special and executive. 
(a)  Council shall meet in regular session of the first Monday of each month at 6:30 p.m. in the Council Chambers in the City Building. When the regular meeting is postponed due to a holiday or other reason, public notice shall be given and the meeting shall be held on the Tuesday after the holiday. 
(b)  A notice shall be posted and maintained by the Recorder, or designated person, at the front door or bulletin board of the City Building, stating the date, time and place fixed and entered of record by Council for the holding of regularly scheduled meetings. In addition, a copy of the agenda for each regularly scheduled meeting shall be posted at the same location by the Recorder, or designated person, not less than 72 hours before such regular meeting is to be held. 
(c)  If a particular regularly scheduled meeting is canceled or postponed, a notice of such cancellation or postponement shall be posted at the same location as soon as feasible after such cancellation or postponement has been determined. 
(d)  Special meetings of Council shall be held when called by the Mayor or four members thereof. Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, the time, place and purpose of all special meetings shall be published in the official recognized newspaper of general circulation in the City. No business, other than that stated in the newspaper announcement, shall be considered at such meeting. 
(e)  In addition, a notice shall be posted by the Recorder, or designated person, at the front door or bulletin board of the City Hall not less that 72 hours before a specially scheduled meeting is to be held, stating the date, time, place and purpose for which such special meeting shall be held. If the special meeting is canceled, a notice of such cancellation shall be posted at the same location as soon as feasible after such cancellation has been determined. 
(f)  An executive session may be held during a regular, special or emergency meeting, but only in compliance with W. Va. Code, § 6-9A-4. No decision shall be made in such executive session. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-2; Code 1991, § 115.02; Ord. of 11-2-1992; Amend. No. 2004-002, 2-17-2004; Ord. of 2-2-2009) 
Sec. 115.03. - Annual tax estimate and levy. 
    Prior to March 1 in each year, Council shall fix a date between March 7 and 28 and at the hour of 7:30 p.m. on the date so fixed Council shall meet in public session at the Council chamber in the City Building and shall then and there proceed with the transaction of the business which is the subject of W. Va. Code, § 11-8-14. Upon completion of that business, the session shall stand adjourned until 7:30 p.m. on the next following third Tuesday in April, at which time it shall reconvene and Council shall proceed in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 11-8-14a. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-3; Code 1991, § 115.03) 
Sec. 115.04. - Biennial organization; oath. 
(a)  At 7:30 p.m. on or before the fourth Monday in June in the year 1979, and every four years thereafter, the Mayor-elect, Recorder-elect and councilmen-elect shall meet in special public session at the Council chamber in the City Building; and shall be called to order by the incumbent Mayor or, in his absence, the incumbent Recorder; and the Mayor-elect, Recorder-elect and councilmen-elect shall then proceed to take the prescribed oath of office, whereupon they shall be deemed to have qualified themselves for the offices to which they, respectively, have recently been elected; provided, that the Mayor-elect and Recorder-elect shall not be deemed to have qualified until they shall have given bond as provided in Section 153.02. 
(b)  The oath, together with the certificate of the officer administering the same, shall be filed, recorded and preserved in the office of the City Recorder, and a certified copy of such oath and certificate shall be filed and recorded in the office of the Clerk of the County Court. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-4; Code 1991, § 115.04) 
Sec. 115.05. - Clerk. 
    The City Recorder, in his ex officio capacity as Clerk of Council, shall render such secretarial and clerical services for Council, its committees and its members as may be imposed upon him by the general laws of the State, these Codified Ordinances and other ordinances, resolutions and orders of Council; and he shall be the custodian of all records and papers of Council. Except where otherwise indicated by the context, references in these Codified Ordinances to the "Clerk" shall mean the Clerk of Council. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-5; Code 1991, § 115.05) 
Sec. 115.06. - Authentication of records. 
    All records of Council shall be authenticated by the signature of the Mayor, and attested by the signature of the City Recorder. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-6; Code 1991, § 115.06) 
Sec. 115.07. - Authorized procedure when meeting lacks quorum. 
    Any number of members of Council, less than a quorum, which may meet at the time and place appointed for any regular or special meeting of Council, may direct the Chief of Police and his deputies to compel the attendance of the absent members, or they may adjourn to a subsequent time and direct the City Recorder to give notice to the absent members, requiring their attendance at such adjourned meeting. The date and time of the adjourned meeting shall be made available, in advance, to the public and news media. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-7; Code 1991, § 115.07) 
Sec. 115.08. - Disorderly conduct prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall behave in a boisterous or disorderly manner at any meeting of Council or any committee thereof, or shall cause any disturbance threat, whether by force, shouting or other action tending to disrupt such meeting, or shall fail or refuse to obey any ruling or order of the officer presiding at such meeting relative to the orderly procedure thereof. 
(b)  Boisterous or disorderly behavior within the purview of subsection (a) of this section includes, but is not limited to, any of the following acts: 
(1)  Contemptuous or insolent behavior towards the presiding officer or any member of Council or committee of Council, or its Clerk or any other officer, while Council or the committee is in session; 
(2)  Any breach of the peace, willful disturbance or indecent conduct in the presence of Council or a committee while so engaged, or so near as to obstruct or interrupt its proceedings; 
(3)  Violence or threats of violence to any member of Council or a committee or any officer, witness or party going to, attending or returning from, any Council or committee proceeding in respect to anything done or to be done in the course of such proceeding; 
(4)  Willful resistance to any lawful order of the presiding officer at any such meeting. 
(c)  The presiding officer of Council or of any committee of Council shall have plenary power to order that Council chambers and adjacent areas be cleared, or any part thereof, or any person or persons ejected from Council chambers or adjacent areas, in the event of disorderly conduct or a disturbance which does or tends to interrupt or disrupt the orderly conduct of business by Council or its committee. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-8; Code 1991, § 115.08) 
Sec. 115.09. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  Council may, by resolution as well as by ordinance, make proper rules and regulations for its own government and for the conduct of its meetings, the transaction of its business and the official conduct of its members, and may include therein reasonable penalties for the violation thereof; but no such rule shall be inconsistent with the state law or these Codified Ordinances. Such rules may include, among other subjects, the following: 
(1)  Appointment, jurisdiction and duties of standing and special committees of Council. 
(2)  Attendance at meetings of Council by members and by others. 
(3)  Investigations and hearings, and compulsory attendance thereat of witnesses and the production of books and papers. 
(4)  Parliamentary procedure. 
(5)  Preservation of order at meetings. 
(6)  Manner and form of petitions, applications and other papers intended for presentation to Council, and procedures relating thereto. 
(b)  All rules adopted pursuant to the provisions of this section on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be spread upon the minutes of Council and duly entered of record in the office of the Clerk of Council. As such rules may from time to time be repealed, amended or added to, the file copies of these Codified Ordinances and the record of repealed and amended portions shall be brought up to date and maintained in a current status in the same manner as provided for ordinances in Section 117.04. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-14; Code 1991, § 115.09) 
Sec. 115.10. - Duties of mayor; recorder. 
(a)  The Mayor shall attend all meetings of Council and preside over that body. 
(b)  The Mayor and the City Recorder shall be members of Council with the right to vote on all questions the same as any other member of Council. The Mayor and City Recorder shall each perform such other duties as Council may require of them. The Recorder shall, in the absence of the Mayor, preside as Chairperson of the meeting of Council, and in the absence of both the Mayor and Recorder at any meeting of Council, some member of Council shall be elected to preside over such meeting. 
(Code 1979, §§ 2-1-6, 2-1-7; Code 1991, § 115.10) 
Sec. 115.11. - Legislative investigations. 
    Whenever by majority vote the Council deems it necessary and proper to exercise its authority pursuant to W. Va. Code §§ 8-12-2(c) and 8-12-5(48) to inquire into and investigate any matter or matters of concern to the City or its inhabitants, it shall, by adoption of formal resolution generally describing the matter or matters to be investigated, commence a legislative investigation. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.20) 
Sec. 115.12. - Docket for legislative investigation. 
    Upon the adoption of a resolution by Council commencing a legislative investigation, the City Recorder shall create a formal docket for all recording, documents, transcripts or things produced in the course of the investigation, and shall assign a single, unique identifying number for the resolution commencing the legislative investigation and for the docket of the investigation. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.20) 
Sec. 115.13. - Investigative orders. 
    For the purpose of its legislative investigation, Council may issue any one or more of the following investigative orders: 
(1)  An order requiring the production of evidence; 
(2)  An order requiring that access to property be granted to investigators designated by Council for the purpose conducting inspections, making copies of relevant data, taking samples, or taking photographs; 
(3)  An order directing that written answers be submitted under oath to written interrogatories or requests for admissions submitted by Council; or 
(4)  An order directing the attendance and testimony of witnesses. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.21) 
Sec. 115.14. - Investigative proceeding to take live testimony. 
(a)  Presiding officer. For any investigative proceeding to take live testimony in the course of a legislative investigation, Council shall designate a qualified court reporter and a presiding officer for the proceeding, who may be the Mayor or, if Council determines that another person with legal or technical expertise relevant to the proceeding is required to manage and facilitate the proceeding, such other person as Council may designate. The presiding officer shall control the course of the proceeding to take live testimony on behalf of Council, and shall rule, in the first instance, on all objections presented. 
(b)  Interrogation of witnesses. For any investigative proceeding to take live testimony in the course of a legislative investigation, Council shall designate a lead interrogator authorized to question the witness on behalf of Council. Unless Council by unanimous vote appoints one of its own members as lead interrogator, the lead interrogator shall be the City Solicitor, or any Assistant City Solicitor appointed by the City Solicitor, or by the Council. 
(c)  Interrogation by members of Council. Notwithstanding Council's appointment of a lead interrogator for any investigative proceeding to take live testimony in the course of a legislative investigation, any member of Council present at the investigative proceeding shall be entitled to question any witness with respect to any matter pertinent to the legislative investigation, subject only to the overall responsibility and authority of the presiding officer to control the order of the proceeding, including its course and duration. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.22) 
Sec. 115.15. - Failure or refusal to comply with investigative order. 
    In case of the failure or refusal of any person to comply with an investigative order served on such person, the Council, in exercise of it authority under W. Va. Code § 8-12-2(c), may invoke the aid of the Putnam County Circuit Court. Upon proper showing, the Circuit Court shall issue an order requiring the witness to comply with the investigative order. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.23) 
Sec. 115.16. - Appeal of ruling of presiding officer on any question of privilege. 
(a)  Right to appeal privilege rulings. On or before the end of the regular business hours of the City two business days after the designated court reporter of any Council legislative investigative proceeding to take live testimony pursuant to Section 115.23 of this Municipal Code files with the City Clerk an initial, complete transcript of the proceedings, whether in electronic form or in hard copy, any party to those proceedings, specifically including the City, may appeal to the full City Council any ruling of the presiding officer made during the proceeding on any question of privilege by filing a notice of appeal with the City Clerk and serving it on all parties (and on the City Solicitor, if the City is not a party), which notice shall specify with particularity the privilege ruling(s) at issues and providing a succinct summary of the legal and factual grounds that will be advanced in support of the appeal. 
(b)  Procedures on appeal. By the end of the regular business hours of the City two (2) business days after filing the notice of appeal pursuant to subsection (a) of this Section 115.24, each appellant shall file with the City Clerk and serve on all parties (and on the City Solicitor if the City is not a party) a brief not to exceed 15 pages in a form that complies with the requirements of Rule 6 of the West Virginia Rules for Trial Courts promulgated by the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals. Each appellee in each appeal shall file with the City Clerk and serve on all parties (and on the City Solicitor if the City is not a party) its responsive brief not to exceed 15 pages in a form that complies with the requirements of Rule 6 of the West Virginia Rules for Trial Courts promulgated by the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals with the City Clerk on or before the end of the regular business hours of the City five business days after the appellant files his brief with the City Clerk. 
(c)  Oral argument discretionary with Council. On the cover page of its brief, each appellant and appellee to an appeal pursuant to this Section 115.24 shall state whether that party is requesting an opportunity to present an oral argument before the full City Council. At the conclusion of the briefing on each appeal, the City Council will determine whether in its judgment oral argument will aid the Council in a just and expeditious resolution of the appeal. If the request for oral argument is granted by the Council, the parties to the appeal will be notified by the City Council of the date and time scheduled for Council to hear their oral arguments. 
(d)  Exhaustion of municipal remedies on privilege issues required. Any party to any legislative investigative proceeding to take live testimony pursuant to Section 115.23 of this Municipal Code seeking to challenge, directly or indirectly, any privilege ruling of the presiding officer made in such proceeding, regardless of by whom the challenge before any court was commenced, must first raise the challenge of such party requesting any relief from that privilege ruling pursuant to the process set forth in this Section 115.24 of this Municipal Code, and thereafter exhaust all of the remedies provided by law with respect to such a challenge to any such privilege ruling. Failure of any such party to first exhaust the municipal remedies available pursuant to this Section 115.24 of this Municipal Code shall bar any request to any court or agency for relief in any form from the privilege ruling of the presiding officer. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.24) 
Sec. 115.17. - Recovery of City's litigation costs and expenses. 
    In any proceedings under Section 115.24 in which the City is the prevailing party or substantially prevailing party, the City is entitled to recover, and the Court shall award to the City, its litigation costs and expenses, including attorneys fees and expenses, expert witness fees and expenses, and, where appropriate, the fees and expenses of no more than one non-testifying technical or scientific expert to assist the City Attorney or Assistant City Attorney(s) in the preparation and prosecution of the action. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.25) 
Sec. 115.18. - Provisions severable. 
    The several sections and subsections of this Article 115 are severable, and if any section or subsection hereof shall be held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, all the remaining sections and subsections of the article shall nevertheless remain valid. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(1), § 115.26) 
ARTICLE 117. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State law references and cross references- Ordinances to make powers effective, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-1; validity of ordinances delegating discretion, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-2; action required to be by ordinance, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-3, 8-5-12; ordinance procedures, W. Va. Code, § 8-11-4; penalty limitation, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-11-1, 8-12-5(58). 

Sec. 117.01. - Ordinances; adoption and procedures. 
    No ordinance shall be passed except in accordance with the requirements of W. Va. Code, § 8-11-4, except where different or additional requirements are specified in other sections of the West Virginia Code, in which event such other different or additional requirements shall be applicable. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-9; Code 1991, § 117.01) 
Sec. 117.02. - Cases requiring enactment of ordinance. 
(a)  In the following enumerated cases, the action of Council shall, except where otherwise provided in the West Virginia Code, be by ordinance: 
(1)  Levying taxes or providing for the collection of fees of any kind; 
(2)  Requiring a license to do business; 
(3)  Relating to offenses and penalties; 
(4)  Authorizing the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness; 
(5)  Providing for a public improvement; 
(6)  Providing for the purchase of private property by the City or for the sale of property belonging to the City; 
(7)  Laying out or vacating a public street, avenue, road, alley or way; 
(8)  Relating to planning or zoning; 
(9)  Granting franchises to public utilities; and 
(10)  Providing for a contractual or other agreement with another jurisdiction. 
(b)  The action of Council shall also be by ordinance in any other case in which an ordinance is required by the provisions of these Codified Ordinances.
