(Code 1979, § 2-2-10; Code 1991, § 117.02) 
Sec. 117.03. - Recording and filing; ordinance record book. 
    Each ordinance when adopted shall be entered in the Ordinance Record Book, and the original copy of the ordinance shall be kept in Council records along with the minutes of the meeting in which the ordinance received its second reading and was enacted. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-11; Code 1991, § 117.03) 
Sec. 117.04. - Repeals, amendments and additions. 
(a)  Each ordinance to repeal, amend or add to any portion of these Codified Ordinances and each ordinance of a general and permanent nature, though constituting new subject matter, shall be drafted so as to specify the specific section numbers, subsections, etc., of these Codified Ordinances which are to be repealed or amended and, with respect to additions and to new subject matter, so as to provide appropriate chapter, articles, section, etc., number, therefor; and each amendment of and addition to these Codified Ordinances shall be set out in full and appropriate chapter and article headings and section catchlines shall be included. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of an ordinance to repeal, amend or add to any portion of these Codified Ordinances or to include new subject matter in these Codified Ordinances the Clerk of Council shall separate the several chapters, articles, sections, etc., of such ordinance and enter them in their proper places in each file copy of these Codified Ordinances and shall delete therefrom any portion so repealed or amended, and in the margin of each insertion in the file copies of these Codified Ordinances he shall note and initial the date of passage, the effective date of the amending or repealing ordinance and, if publication is required, a note as to the time and manner of publication. 
(c)  The requirements of subsection (b) of this section are in addition to the requirement that each ordinance, upon adoption, shall be included in the Ordinance Record Book. 
(d)  "File copies," as used in this section, means that copy or those copies, as the case may be, of these Codified Ordinances, certified by the Mayor upon adoption, and thereafter maintained on file in the office of the City Recorder. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-12; Code 1991, § 117.04) 
Sec. 117.05. - Resolutions; records. 
(a)  Each resolution shall, before its introduction, be reduced to writing and shall be signed by the person who introduces it; and the Clerk of Council shall then number it, and, when adopted, shall spread it in full upon the minutes of Council. The Clerk of Council shall then place the original copy of such resolution in his office in a file to be known as the Record of Resolutions. 
(b)  Resolutions and portions of resolutions which are repealed or amended by subsequent resolutions or ordinances shall be noted and initialed in the margin thereof by the Clerk of Council, so as to show the date and number of the repealing or amendatory ordinance or resolution, but shall not be removed from the Record of Resolutions. 
(Code 1979, § 2-2-13; Code 1991, § 117.05) 
Sec. 117.06. - Applicability of ordinances to acts and omissions beyond city limits. 
(a)  Wherever in these Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance or resolution of Council any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, and no specific place or geographical area is specified with respect to such act, then the doing of such prohibited act or the failure to do such required act shall be unlawful both within the corporate limits of the City and within the unincorporated areas surrounding the City from such distance beyond the corporate limits as may be within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City as provided in the Code of West Virginia. 
(b)  Wherever in these Codified Ordinances or in any other ordinance or resolution of Council any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor within any given distance beyond the corporate limits of the City, pursuant to any pertinent provision of State law, any incorporated area within such distance beyond the corporate limits of the City is excluded. 
(Code 1979, §§ 1-2, 1-8; Code 1991, § 117.06) 
ARTICLE 125. - MAYOR[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State law references and cross references- Position established, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-7; Section 103.01; oath of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-8; terms of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-9; vacancies, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-10; voting rights, W. Va. Code, § 8-9-2; powers and duties generally, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1; acting mayor, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-3; rights and duties at Council meetings, Section 115.10. 

Sec. 125.01. - Title; duties. 
    The Mayor shall be the head of the City Government and the chief executive officer of the City. The Mayor shall see that all of the laws and ordinances of the City are enforced, and he shall have general supervision over all executive departments, offices and agencies of the City Government. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-3; Code 1991, § 125.01) 
Sec. 125.02. - Absence or inability of officers to perform duties. 
    Whenever for any reason the Mayor shall be absent from the City, or unable to attend to the duties of his office temporarily, the City Recorder shall perform them during such absence or inability, and in the absence or inability of the Recorder to attend to the duties of his office temporarily, the Mayor shall designate someone to perform such duties, provided, that such temporary absence or inability shall not exceed 30 days, but if such absence or inability shall exceed 30 days, then such appointment or designation shall be submitted to Council, for confirmation or rejection. In the absence or inability of any other appointive City official to perform the duties of his office, the person or body making the original appointment, or his successor in office, shall designate someone to fill such office temporarily, or if such absence or inability extends over a period of 60 days, he may appoint someone to fill such office permanently. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-9; Code 1991, § 125.02) 
ARTICLE 127. - RECORDER[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State law references and cross references- Position established, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-7; Section 103.01; oath of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-8; terms of office, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-9; vacancies, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-10; voting rights, W. Va. Code, § 8-9-2; powers and duties generally, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-3; chief election official, Section 105.03; rights and duties at Council meetings, Section 115.10; annual financial statement, Section 129.10. 

Sec. 127.01. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The City Recorder shall be the custodian of all records, maps, documents and other papers of the City Government for which no other custodian is designated, and he shall keep them secure against all hazards and make them available to the public as provided in Section 103.07. 
(b)  The office of the City Recorder is recognized as the principal point of contact between the public and the City Government; and all personnel of the City Recorder's office shall provide information and guidance to all orderly persons affected by the provisions of these Codified Ordinances or other ordinances or resolutions of Council, and to those having business to transact in any City department, office or agency. 
(c)  The City Recorder shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as may from time to time be specified by the Mayor or Council. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-4; Code 1991, § 127.01) 
Sec. 127.02. - Fee for copies. 
    The City Recorder is hereby authorized and directed to charge the sum of $0.25 per page for copies of all records and documents supplied to any person upon request made to the Clerk; provided, that no charge shall be made for such copies supplied to the City or any other governmental unit, or any of their agencies, bureaus, departments, divisions or instrumentalities, and members of Council for their official use. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-20; Code 1991, § 127.02) 
Sec. 127.03. - Official seal; custodian. 
    The City Recorder shall be the custodian of the common seal of the City. 
(Code 1979, § 1-10; Code 1991, § 127.03) 
ARTICLE 129. - TREASURER[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State law references and cross references- Supervision of public offices, W. Va. Code, § 6-9-1 et seq.; purchasing, competitive bidding, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-10; collection of moneys, W. Va. Code, § 8-13-15 et seq.; financial statements, W. Va. Code, § 8-13-23; accounting principles, funds, W. Va. Code, § 8-13-17 et seq.; appointment, Section 103.04. 

Sec. 129.01. - Duties. 
    The City Treasurer shall collect and receive all taxes, fees, assessments and other charges and debts due the City and for which no other City officer is designated as the collector or recipient. The City Treasurer shall issue all City licenses and permits for which no other City officer is designated as the issuing officer. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-5; Code 1991, § 129.01) 
Sec. 129.02. - Fiscal year defined; records to conform. 
    All fiscal reports, settlements, accounts and statements of the City and of City officers shall conform to the fiscal year, which begins on July 1 of each calendar year and terminates at the close of business on June 30 of the next succeeding calendar year. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-1; Code 1991, § 129.02) 
Sec. 129.03. - Supervision of finances. 
    The City Treasurer shall direct the Clerk in the proper keeping of all accounts and issuing of warrants, and shall see that the books pertaining to the funds and finances of the City are properly kept, and the Treasurer, whenever required to do so, shall furnish to Council any statement of the financial condition of the City or of any particular fund or the fund apportioned to any particular purpose at any time. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-2; Code 1991, § 129.03) 
Sec. 129.04. - City funds. 
    The City Treasurer shall keep the money of the City in such accounts as may be required or authorized by federal or state law, these Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or resolution of Council; and "accounts," as used herein, shall be interchangeable with "funds" as, for example, the "special fund" and the "general fund." 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-3; Code 1991, § 129.04) 
Sec. 129.05. - Special funds; establishment of escrows. 
    In addition to the funds herein provided, Council shall have power to establish special funds for any specific purposes, such as, for example, the building of a certain sewer, or paving of certain portions of a street, the funds to be raised by the parties interested in the improvements and deposited to the credit of such special fund and to be expended only for the purpose of the fund. The City Treasurer shall also be authorized to accept any money in escrow under any legal contract made by Council or the Mayor, and hold and dispose thereof according to the terms of the escrow agreement or contract. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-4; Code 1991, § 129.05) 
Sec. 129.06. - City depository. 
    All City money or money due the City from any source whatever shall be deposited in the bank or banks designated by Council as City depositories, to the credit of "the City of Hurricane General Fund," designating the fund to which the money should properly go. The City Treasurer shall, either in person or through some official of the bank, issue a receipt for all such deposits showing the date of the deposit, the amount deposited, by whom deposited and the fund to which it was credited. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-5; Code 1991, § 129.06) 
Sec. 129.07. - Expenditures from city funds; purposes. 
(a)  No expenditure from the Paving and Sewer Fund shall be made except for a purpose for which assessments were levied against property owners or for payments of principal, interest and other charges on outstanding bonds of the City in conformity with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-18-14. 
(b)  All other money coming into the Treasury of the City from any source whatever except from a special fund and deposited to the credit of the General Fund, may be used by the City in paying the expenses of the City Government and for such improvements of City property, streets, sewers, parks and public buildings and places as may be justified by the condition of the City's finances and the laws and ordinances governing the levying, collection and expenditure of the City funds. 
(c)  No expenditure shall be made from any special fund or fund held in escrow except for a purpose for which such fund or escrow was established. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-6; Code 1991, § 129.07) 
Sec. 129.08. - Disbursement of general fund; contracts. 
    The General Fund at the time of laying the annual tax levy shall be apportioned by Council for the several purposes for which it was levied or collected, and for the general needs of the City Government, but not including special funds, and Council shall, as nearly as possible, keep the expenses of each department or branch of the City service within the limits of such apportionment, but in the event that a saving can be made in the expenses of any one department, such saving may be applied to any deficit which may arise in the apportionment for any other department, and any excess of revenue over and above the estimated collections from any given source during the fiscal year may likewise be applied to any such deficit, but under no circumstances shall the City expend or contract for the expenditure of more money than the amount estimated each year in the annual estimate published in March of each year, as the probable receipts for the fiscal year, plus any money received into the Treasury by reason of collections for such fiscal year to the credit of the General Fund, in excess of the amount estimated to be received from any such known source of revenue. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-7; Code 1991, § 129.08) 
Sec. 129.09. - Accounts. 
    An account shall be kept by the City Treasurer showing the warrants drawn on the several funds each day, which account shall be kept posted up to within 48 hours of the time when the last warrant was drawn, and the account shall be consolidated at the end of each fiscal year into a report as prescribed by W. Va. Code, § 6-9-1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-8; Code 1991, § 129.09) 
Sec. 129.10. - Annual financial statement. 
(a)  The City Treasurer, within 90 days after the beginning of each fiscal year, shall prepare on a form to be prescribed by the State Tax Commissioner and cause to be published a sworn statement revealing: 
(1)  The receipts and expenditures of the City during the previous fiscal year arranged under descriptive headings, 
(2)  The name of each person who received more than $50.00 from any fund during the previous fiscal year, together with the amount received and the purpose for which paid, and 
(3)  All debts of the City, the purpose for which each debt was contracted, its due date and to what date the interest thereon has been paid. Such statement shall be published as a Class I legal advertisement in compliance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 59-3-1 et seq. and the publication area for such publication shall be the City. 
(b)  The City Recorder shall transmit to any resident of the City, upon request, a copy of any published statement for the fiscal year designated, supplemented by a document listing the names of each person who received less than $50.00 from any fund during such fiscal year and showing the amount paid to each and the purpose for which paid and an itemization of the salaries, receipts, payments to each individual vendor and expenditures to employees of municipal offices, companies and departments otherwise published in the aggregate. 
(c)  The statement required by subsection (a) of this section shall be sworn to by the City Recorder, the Mayor and two councilmen. As soon as practicable following the close of the fiscal year, a copy of any statement herein required shall be filed by the City Recorder with the State Tax Commissioner, the Clerk of the County Commission and the Clerk of the Circuit Court. 
(d)  Where in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, salaries, receipts, payments to each individual vendor and expenditures are published in the aggregate, the City shall, upon written request, provide to any resident of the City an itemized accounting of the salaries, receipts, payments to each individual vendor and expenditures. 
(Code 1991, § 129.10) 
Sec. 129.11. - Indebtedness to city; delinquent payments. 
    The City Treasurer, upon application for and prior to paying out money to any person entitled thereto, may, in the exercise of sound discretion, first ascertain whether such person is delinquent in the payment of any City tax or is otherwise indebted to the City, insofar as such indebtedness, if any, may appear on the City's records. Upon so ascertaining that such person is in fact indebted to the City, the City Treasurer shall then take proper action pursuant to the established administrative and accounting procedures to apply all or such part of the amount to which such person is entitled to receive from the City to the full or partial payment, as the case may be, of his debt to the City; and if the amount such person is entitled to receive from the City exceeds the amount of his indebtedness to the City, the Treasurer shall then pay out to such person the amount of such excess, and, in either case the Treasurer shall give to such person a memorandum of the entire transaction. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-10; Code 1991, § 129.11) 
ARTICLE 131. - SOLICITOR[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State law references and cross references- Hiring special counsel, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1a; claims against City, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-2; to defend City employees, Section 101.09; appointment, Section 103.04. 

Sec. 131.01. - Established; assistant city solicitor; counsel. 
(a)  There shall be a City Solicitor and such number of Assistant City Solicitors as may from time to time be authorized by resolution of Council, each of whom shall be appointed by, and serve at the will and pleasure of, the Mayor, and who shall receive such compensation as may be prescribed by Council. 
(b)  Pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1a, the Mayor is hereby authorized to employ within the limits of funds available for such purpose, in lieu of or in addition to the City Solicitor and any Assistant City Solicitor, an attorney or firm of attorneys as special municipal counsel to represent the City in connection with any legal matter or matters. Any attorney or firm of attorneys so employed shall comply with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1a. 
(c)  During any period of time wherein the City is represented by special municipal counsel in lieu of or in addition to a City Solicitor, pursuant to W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1a, "City Solicitor" and "Assistant City Solicitor" mean such special municipal counsel or the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor, as the case may be, with respect to the subject matter involved. 
(Code 1979, §§ 1-2, 2-3-6; Code 1991, § 131.01) 
ARTICLE 133. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State law references and cross references- Appointment of special police, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-1; powers and duties of police, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-14-1, 8-14-3; hours of duty, work during holidays, W. Va. Code, §§ 8-14-2, 8-14-2a; special school zone police officers, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-5; special parking lot or parking building police officers, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-5a; civil service, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-6 et seq.; disciplinary action, W. Va. Code, § 8-14A-1 et seq.; policemen's pension and relief fund, W. Va. Code, § 8-22-1 et seq. 

Sec. 133.01. - Powers and duties of police officers. 
    The Mayor shall appoint, with the approval of the Council, such number of police officers as are or may be hereafter prescribed. The police officers shall be under command of the Mayor and the Chief of Police, and shall perform any and all duties incident to the office of police officer under the instructions and command of the Mayor and the Chief of Police, and, in addition to the usual and customary duties prescribed by the laws of this State, it shall specially be the duty of each police officer to report to the Chief of Police, or someone designated by the Chief of Police to receive such report, the condition of all streets, sidewalks, alleys, unimproved lots and all other things and matters within the limits of the City that may come under the notice of such police officers which may relate to the health of the residents thereof, the sanitary conditions or the necessity of the removal of any obstructions upon any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks. The Chief and any member of the police force shall have all of the powers, authority, rights and privileges within the corporate limits of the City with regard to the arrest of persons, the collection of claims and the execution and return of any search warrant, warrant of arrest or other process, which can legally be exercised or discharged by a deputy sheriff of a county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-12; Code 1991, § 133.01) 
Sec. 133.02. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Police Department includes the Chief of Police and all police officers and administrative staff employed by the City. 
(b)  Chief of Police means the supervisor in charge, appointed by the Mayor, of all employees and activities of the Police Department. 
(c)  Patrol officers means the employees of the Police Department responsible for going the rounds within the City boundaries in an effort to maintain proper security for all persons. 
(Code 1991, § 133.02; Ord. of 4-3-1989) 
PREAMBLE FOR CITY OF HURRICANE 
POLICE DEPARTMENT 
Sec. 133.03. - Nature of work. 
(a)  Police duties in the City shall require enforcing City ordinances and State laws. Patrol officers shall patrol the City in a patrol vehicle or on foot, usually working alone. 
(b)  Office personnel shall perform specialized clerical duties as assigned. Work involves responsibility for receiving and processing police telephone calls. Position holders shall also monitor and operate equipment located at the work site. 
(c)  All duties shall be performed in conformance with the Departmental rules and regulations as set forth in the Hurricane Police Department Policies and Procedures Manual adopted by Council for the City Police Department. Violation of Department rules and regulations shall constitute disciplinary action, the degree of which will depend on the seriousness of the violations. 
(Code 1991, § 133.03; Ord. of 4-3-1989) 
EMPLOYMENT SELECTION 
AND EVALUATION 
Sec. 133.04. - Selection of an applicant for employment. 
    An applicant for employment shall be selected based upon the City of Hurricane Police Department Policies and Procedures Manual. 
(Code 1991, § 133.04) 
Sec. 133.05. - Hiring board. 
    The Hiring Board shall make the final decision on all hirings for the position of police officer. The top three of the written test shall be submitted to the Hiring Board per each position open. The Hiring Board shall consist of the Mayor, one member of Council and the Chief of Police. The Council member shall be appointed by the Mayor. 
(Code 1991, § 133.05; Ord. of 4-3-1989) 
Sec. 133.06. - Periodic evaluation. 
    A periodic evaluation shall be made as provided in the Hurricane Police Department Policies and Procedures Manual. 
(Code 1991, § 133.06; Ord. of 4-3-1989; Amend. No. 2005-01, § 133.06, 3-7-2005) 
Sec. 133.07. - Disciplinary action. 
(a)  Procedure for investigation. Upon any disciplinary action that results in a dismissal order, the officer shall be entitled to have a hearing in front of a Hearing Board. 
(1)  Definitions. Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, as used in this Article: 
a.  Accused officer means any police officer who is the subject of an investigation or interrogation, which results in a recommendation of punitive action against him. 
b.  Hearing means any meeting in the course of an investigatory proceeding, other than an interrogation at which no testimony is taken under oath, conducted by a Hearing Board for the purpose of taking or inducing testimony or receiving evidence. 
c.  Hearing Board means a board appointed to hold a hearing on a complaint against an accused officer. The Hearing Board shall consist of three members to be appointed pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section. Hearing Board members appointed under subsection (a)(2) of this section may be removed from office as provided by subsection (a)(3) of this section. 
d.  Police officer means any police officer of the municipal Police Department, but shall not include the highest-ranking officer of the Department or any officer who has not completed the probationary period established by the Department, by which he is employed. 
e.  Punitive action means any action which may lead to dismissal, demotion, suspension, reduction in salary, written reprimand or transfer for purposes of punishment. 
f.  Under investigation or under interrogation means any situation in which a police officer becomes the focus of inquiry regarding any matter which may result in punitive action. 
(2)  Hearing Board appointment; term. The Hearing Board shall be a standing Hearing Board. The Department Chief shall appoint the first member; the Fraternal Order of Police shall appoint the second member. The first and second members shall appoint by agreement the third member from the business community. Of the three original appointments, the first member shall serve for six years form the date of his appointment; the second member shall serve for four years from the date of his appointment; and the third member shall serve for two years from the date of his appointment. After the original appointments, all appointments shall be made for periods of four years each by the designated appointing authority. In the event that any member shall cease to be a member due to death, resignation, final removal or other cause, a new member shall be appointed within 30 days of the date the ex-member ceased to be a member. This appointment shall be made by the officer or body, who in the first instance appointed the member who is no longer a member. When the Hearing Board is appointed, the three members shall elect one of their number to act as president of the board, who shall serve as president for one year. In the event that a member has had a part in the investigation or interrogation of an accused officer or is related by consanguinity or affinity to an accused officer, that member shall be recused from participation in the accused officer's hearing. In such an instance, the officer or body who in the first instance appointed the recused member shall appoint another person for the sole purpose of the accused officer's hearing. No member shall hold any other office (other than the office of notary public) under the United States, the State of West Virginia or any municipality, county or other political subdivision thereof; nor shall any member serve on any political committee or take any active part in the management of any political campaign. 
(3)  Removal of member of Hearing Board. Any member of a Hearing Board appointed under subsection (a)(2) of this section may be removed as provided in this subsection. The Mayor of the city may, at any time, remove any hearing board member for good cause, which shall be stated in writing and made a part of the records of the Hearing Board. However, within ten days of removing any member, the Mayor shall file in the Circuit Clerk's Office of Putnam County a petition setting forth in full the reason for the removal and seeking the Circuit Court's confirmation of the Mayor's removal of the member. The Mayor shall file a copy of the petition with the removed member at the same time it is filed with the Circuit Clerk. The petition shall have precedence on the Circuit Court's docket and shall be heard as soon as practicable on the request of the removed member. (W. Va. Code, § 8-14A-1(4)(d)) Any resident of the city shall have the right at any time to seek the removal of any Hearing Board member. To do so, the resident shall file a petition in the Circuit Clerk's office of Putnam County. The resident shall also serve a copy of the petition on the member sought to be removed. Any party adversely affected by the Circuit Court's or Judge's decision shall have the right to petition the Supreme Count of Appeals for a review of the decision as in other civil cases. 
(b)  Investigation and interrogation of a police officer. When any police officer is under investigation and subjected to interrogation by his commanding officer, or any other member of the employing police department, which could lead to punitive action, such interrogation shall be conducted under the following conditions: 
(1)  The interrogation shall be conducted at a reasonable hour, preferably at a time when the police officer is on duty, or during his normal working hours, unless the seriousness of the investigation requires otherwise. If such interrogation does occur during off-duty time of the police officer being interrogated, such officer shall be compensated for such off-duty time in accordance with regular department procedure. If the interrogation of the police officer occurs during his regular duty hours, such officer shall not be released from employment for any work missed due to interrogation. 
(2)  Any police officer under investigation shall be informed of the nature of the investigation prior to any interrogation. Such officer shall also be informed of the name, rank and command of the officer in charge of the interrogation, the interrogating officers, and all other persons to be present during the interrogation. No more than three interrogators at one time shall question the officer under investigation. 
(3)  No police officer under interrogation shall be subjected to offensive language or threatened with punitive action. No promise of reward shall be made as an inducement to answering questions. 
(4)  The complete interrogation of any police officer shall be recorded, either written, taped or transcribed. Upon request of the law enforcement officer under investigation or his counsel, and upon advance payment of the reasonable cost thereof a copy of the record shall be made available to him not less than ten days prior to any hearing. 
(5)  Upon filing a formal written statement of charges or whenever an interrogation focuses on matters which are likely to result in punitive action against any police officer, then the officer shall have the right to be represented by counsel who may be present at all times during such interrogation. 
(6)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the immediate temporary suspension, pending an investigation, from duty of any police officer who reports for duty under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances, or under the influence of an apparent mental or emotional disorder, which would prevent the officer from performing his duties. 
(c)  Hearing. 
(1)  Before taking any punitive action against an accused officer, the police department shall give notice to the accused officer that he is entitled to a hearing on the issues by a Hearing Board. The notice shall state the time and place of the hearing and the issues involved and shall be delivered to the accused officer no later than ten days prior to the hearing. 
(2)  When an accused officer faces any recommended punitive action, the applicable Hearing Board shall conduct a hearing pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c) of this section. 
(3)  The following requirements shall govern the operation conduct of a Hearing Board under subsection (b) of this section: 
a.  The Hearing Board shall keep an official record of each hearing it conducts. The official record shall include the testimony offered and exhibits introduced at the hearing. 
b.  Both the police department and the accused officer shall be given ample opportunity to present evidence and argument with respect to any issue raised at the hearing. 
c.  The Hearing Board may subpoena witnesses and administer oaths or affirmations and examine any individual under oath, and may require and compel the production of records, books, papers, contracts and other documents in connection with any issue raised at the hearing. 
d.  The Hearing Board shall prepare a written order detailing any decision or action it takes as a result of the hearing. The written order shall include written findings of fact setting forth a concise statement of the hearing board's factual findings and conclusions on each issue raised at the hearing. The Hearing Board shall hand-deliver or promptly mail a copy of the written order to the accused officer or his attorney of record. 
e.  A Hearing Board's order is binding on all parties involved unless it is overturned in the appeal process described in subsection (e) of this section. 
(d)  Right to refuse to disclose personal finances; exceptions. No police officer shall be required or requested for purposes of job assignment or other personnel action to disclose any item of his property, income, assets, source of income, debts or personal or domestic expenditures unless such information is obtained through proper legal procedures or is necessary for the employing agency to ascertain the desirability of assigning the police officer to a specialized unit in which there is a strong possibility that bribes or other improper inducements might be offered. 
(e)  Appeal. A Hearing Board's decision rendered may be appealed by the police officer adversely affected by the order or by the department chief if he believes that the department would be adversely affected by the Hearing Board's order. An appeal under this Article shall be made to the Circuit Court of the county in which the police officer resides. 
(Code 1991, § 133.07; Ord. of 4-3-1989; Amend. No. 2005-01, § 133.07, 3-7-2005) 
ARTICLE 137. - BUILDING CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State law references and cross references- Appointment, Section 103.04; issuance of building permits, Section 1705.04. 

Sec. 137.01. - Established. 
    The Building Code Enforcement Official shall be a competent person for the duties of his office. The Building Code Enforcement Official shall not be engaged or interested in the building business in any way or manner. Council shall fix a proper salary for him. The Building Code Enforcement Official shall see that the ordinances of the City and laws of the State concerning building construction are enforced and perform such other duties as the Mayor or Council may direct. 
(Code 1979, § 2-3-7) 
ARTICLE 139. - PLANNING COMMISSION[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State law references and cross references- Authority to establish, W. Va. Code, § 8A-2-1; general provisions, W. Va. Code, § 8A-2-2; comprehensive plan, W. Va. Code, § 8A-3-1 et seq.; zoning recommendations, W. Va. Code, § 8A-7-4. 

Sec. 139.01. - Created; members; qualifications, appointment, vacancies. 
    There is hereby created a Municipal Planning Commission for the City, which shall consist of seven members. One member of the Municipal Planning Commission shall be a member of Council, appointed by Council for a term coextensive with his term as a member of Council. One member of the Municipal Planning Commission shall be a member of the administrative department of the City or a designee, appointed by the City Manager and confirmed by the Council for a term coextensive with his term of office. The other five members of the Municipal Planning Commission shall be residents and taxpayers of the City, who shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council. The membership of the Municipal Planning Commission shall conform to the requirements of the West Virginia statutes relating thereto, and to W. Va. Code, § 8A-2-2, in particular. Members of the Municipal Planning Commission other than the Council member shall be appointed on or before January 1 of each year, to take office on January 1 of the year in which appointed, for staggered terms of three years each and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies other than those due to expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term only. Members of the Municipal Planning Commission shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-5; Code 1991, § 139.01) 
Sec. 139.02. - Official name; powers and duties. 
    The Municipal Planning Commission, the official name of which shall be "Municipal Planning Commission of the City of Hurricane," is hereby vested with the powers and it shall perform the duties prescribed for municipal planning commissions, with respect to zoning as well as to planning, in W. Va. Code, § 8A-2-1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-6; Code 1991, § 139.02) 
Sec. 139.03. - General purpose. 
    The general purpose of the Municipal Planning Commission shall be to make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the City, with due regard to its relation to neighboring territory, with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the City and its environs which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, including, among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of healthful and convenient distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds, and the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-7; Code 1991, § 139.03) 
Sec. 139.04. - Planning; approval of commission required. 
(a)  The duties of the Municipal Planning Commission include the preparing of plans for the development of the whole or any portion of the City and any land outside thereof, which in the opinion of the Municipal Planning Commission bears relation to the planning of the City; provided, that the power of the Municipal Planning Commission shall not extend beyond the territorial limits of the City except so far as is reasonably necessary to protect the community, both within and without the corporate limits, against inadequate streets, highways and sewers, and inadequately planned and zoned territory. Such plans shall show recommendations for new streets, bridges; parks, parkways and other public areas or public improvements and matters properly pertaining to the purposes of the Municipal Planning Commission. 
(b)  Before final action is taken by the City or any department thereof on the location and design of any public building, public memorial, street, alleyway, park, parkway, playground or other public area, such question shall be submitted to the Municipal Planning Commission for investigation and report. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-8; Code 1991, § 139.04) 
Sec. 139.05. - Employing help; budget; cooperation from other officials. 
    The Municipal Planning Commission shall have the power and authority, subject to approval of Council as hereinafter provided, to employ engineers and clerks, or any other help necessary and to meet all such expenses. The Municipal Planning Commission shall submit to the Mayor and Council its budget for each fiscal year, itemizing expenses and amounts, and the purposes. Council shall thereupon consider such budget and make such allowances to the Municipal Planning Commission as it deems proper. All officials and employees of the City shall, so far as practicable, give their services and submit such data or information as may be required to promote and effectuate the purposes of this Article. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-9; Code 1991, § 139.05) 
Sec. 139.06. - President, vice-president and secretary; rules; meetings; records. 
    The Municipal Planning Commission, from its membership, shall elect a president and a vice-president and shall appoint a secretary. The Municipal Planning Commission shall adopt such rules as may be necessary for the transaction of its business, hold regular meetings open to the public and shall keep a record of its official proceedings which shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-10; Code 1991, § 139.06) 
Sec. 139.07. - Contracts for expenditure of money. 
    No contract for the expenditure of money by the Municipal Planning Commission shall be executed by the Municipal Planning Commission or become effective and binding on the City until such contract has been attested by the secretary of the Municipal Planning Commission and approved by the City Manager and Council. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-11; Code 1991, § 139.07) 
Sec. 139.08. - Office. 
    The Municipal Planning Commission shall maintain an office in the City Building and the office of the Clerk of Council is hereby designated as the office of the Municipal Planning Commission and all of the records of the Commission shall be kept in that office. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-12; Code 1991, § 139.08) 
Sec. 139.09. - Plats or replats of land laid out in building lots. 
    All plans, plats or replats of land laid out in building lots, and the streets intended to be dedicated to public use, shall be submitted to the Municipal Planning Commission for its consideration, and no such plat or replat shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of the County Court, as provided by law in other cases, until such plat or replat has endorsed upon it, the fact that it has first been submitted to the Municipal Planning Commission and by the Commission to the City Manager, and by the City Manager to Council and duly approved by Council. 
(Code 1979, § 2-7-13; Code 1991, § 139.09) 
ARTICLE 141. - SANITARY/WATER POLLUTION CONTROL BOARD[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State law references and cross references- Composition of board, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-18; publication of financial statement, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-18a; powers and duties, W. Va. Code, § 16-13-3 et seq.; sewer regulations and rates, Article 935; Sanitary Stormwater Board, Section 935.02. 

Sec. 141.01. - Created; powers and duties; members; term. 
    There is hereby created in and for the City a Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board, which shall be charged with the custody, supervision, control, administration, operation and maintenance of the municipal sanitary/water pollution control system. The Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board shall be composed of the Mayor and four persons appointed by Council. Members of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board, other than the Mayor, shall take office on the second Monday of July of the year of appointment and shall serve for staggered terms of three years and until their respective successors have been duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies other than those due to expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term only. 
(Ord. of 7-1-2013) 
Sec. 141.02. - Officers; salaries; bond of Treasurer. 
(a)  The Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board shall elect a chairperson from its members and shall designate a secretary and treasurer (who may be one and the same person) who need not be members of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board and who shall hold office at the will of the Board. 
(b)  Each member of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board shall receive such salary as may be fixed from time to time by Council and shall be entitled to payment for his reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. 
(c)  The Secretary and Treasurer shall be paid such reasonable compensation for services as from time to time may be fixed by Council, and the Treasurer shall give bond, with qualified corporate surety, in the amount of $5,000.00 or such other amount as Council may require, conditioned for the proper application of all moneys received by him as such and for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(d)  All compensation, and all expense, incurred by the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board, its officers and employees, shall be paid solely from funds authorized to be collected and received by the Board as provided by W. Va. Code, §§ 8-13-1 et seq. and 8-19-1 et seq. 
(Ord. of 7-1-2013) 
Sec. 141.03. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The construction, acquisition, improvement, equipment, custody, operation, maintenance and administration of all works for the collection, treatment, storage and distribution of sanitary/water pollution control within the City and in such other areas as may be within the jurisdiction of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board which shall be acquired, constructed, operated or maintained by the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board, and employment of all engineers, architects, inspectors, superintendents, manager, collectors, attorneys and other employees in the judgment of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board necessary to the execution of its powers and duties, and the collection of all revenues from the works acquired, constructed, operated or maintained by it, shall be under the supervision and control of the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board. 
(b)  In addition to the authority and powers enumerated herein, the Sanitary/Water Pollution Control Board shall be invested with all other powers and authorities provided for such boards by W. Va. Code, § 8-19-1 et seq. 
(Ord. of 7-1-2013) 
ARTICLE 143. - WATER BOARD[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State law references and cross references- Authority to establish, W. Va. Code, § 8-19-19; powers and duties, see W. Va. Code, § 8-16-1 et seq. 

Sec. 143.01. - Created; powers and duties; members; term. 
    There is hereby created in and for the City a Water Board, which shall be charged with the custody, supervision, control, administration, operation and maintenance of the municipal water system. The Water Board shall be composed of the Mayor and four persons appointed by Council. Members of the Water Board, other than the Mayor, shall take office on the second Monday of July of the year of appointment and shall serve for staggered terms of three years and until their respective successors have been duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies other than those due to expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1979, § 22-2-1; Code 1991, § 143.01) 
Sec. 143.02. - Officers; salaries; bond of treasurer. 
(a)  The Water Board shall elect a Chairperson from its members and shall designate a secretary and treasurer (who may be one and the same person) who need not be members of the Water Board and who shall hold office at the will of the Board. 
(b)  Each member of the Water Board shall receive such salary as may be fixed from time to time by Council and shall be entitled to payment for his reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. 
(c)  The secretary and treasurer shall be paid such reasonable compensation for services as from time to time may be fixed by Council, and the treasurer shall give bond, with qualified corporate surety, in the amount of $5,000.00 or such other amount as Council may require, conditioned for the proper application of all moneys received by him as such and for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(d)  All compensation, and all expense, incurred by the Water Board, its officers and employees, shall be paid solely from funds authorized to be collected and received by the Board as provided by W. Va. Code, §§ 8-13-1 et seq. and 8-19-1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 22-2-2; Code 1991, § 143.02) 
Sec. 143.03. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The construction, acquisition, improvement, equipment, custody, operation, maintenance and administration of all works for the collection, treatment, storage and distribution of water within the City and in such other areas as may be within the jurisdiction of the Water Board which shall be acquired, constructed, operated or maintained by the Water Board, and employment of all engineers, architects, inspectors, superintendents, manager, collectors, attorneys and other employees in the judgment of the Water Board necessary to the execution of its powers and duties, and the collection of all revenues from the works acquired, constructed, operated or maintained by it, shall be under the supervision and control of the Water Board. 
(b)  In addition to the authority and powers enumerated herein, the Water Board shall be invested with all other powers and authorities provided for such boards by W. Va. Code, § 8-19-1 et seq. 
(Code 1979, § 22-2-3; Code 1991, § 143.03) 
ARTICLE 145. - HURRICANE DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State law references and cross references- Department of development authorized, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-3a. 

Sec. 145.01. - Purposes. 
    The purpose of the Hurricane Development Authority will be to promote, develop and advance business prosperity and economic welfare for the City of Hurricane, the citizens and business community. The Hurricane Development Authority will encourage and assist through loans, investments or other business transactions the location of new business and industry within Hurricane and rehabilitate and assist existing businesses and industries therein. Also, the Hurricane Development Authority will stimulate and promote expansion of business and industrial development and maximum opportunities and maintain the economic stability of Hurricane, to provide maximum opportunities for employment, encourage thrift and improve the standard of living of the citizens of Hurricane, cooperating with other organizations, federal, state or local, in the promotion and advancement of industrial, commercial, agricultural, and recreational developments, where appropriate. The Hurricane Development Authority may furnish money and credit, land and industrial sites, technical assistance or other such aid as may be deemed requisite to approved and deserving applicants for the promotion, development and conduct of business activity within Hurricane. 
(Code 1991, § 145.01; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.02. - Control of authority; appointment and terms; vacancies; removal of members. 
(a)  The management and control of the Hurricane Development Authority, its property, operations, business and affairs shall be lodged in a Board of nine persons who shall be appointed by the Council and shall be known as members of the Hurricane Development Authority. One member of the Hurricane Development Authority shall also be a member of the governing body appointed to represent it on the board. Other members of the Hurricane Development Authority shall include representatives of business, industry and labor. 
(b)  The members of the Hurricane Development Authority shall be appointed and serve respectfully for staggered terms of three years each. A member of the Hurricane Development Authority may be reappointed for an additional term or terms as the Council may deem proper. If a member resigns, is removed for any other reason than his membership terminates during his term of office, a successor shall be appointed by Council to fill the remainder of the term. Members in office at the expiration of their respective terms shall continue to serve until their successors have been appointed. The appointing agency may at any time remove its appointed member of the Hurricane Development Authority by an order duly entered of record or by other action appropriate for such appointing agency and may appoint a successor member for any member so removed. 
(Code 1991, § 145.02; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.03. - Qualifications of members. 
    All members of the Hurricane Development Authority are not required to be citizens of the City where the Authority will operate and bona fide residents of the City in which Council shall make the appointments. 
(Code 1991, § 145.03; Ord. of 10-3-1994; Ord. of 11-7-2011) 
Sec. 145.04. - Compensation of members; expenses; excusal of member from voting where conflict of interest involved. 
(a)  No member of the Hurricane Development Authority shall receive any compensation, whether in formal salary, per diem allowance or otherwise, in connection with his services as such member. Each member of the Hurricane Development Authority shall however, be entitled to reimbursement by the Authority for any necessary expenditures in connection with the performance of his general duties as such member. 
(b)  Each member present during any meeting of the Hurricane Development Authority when any question is put, shall vote unless he is immediately and particularly interested therein. Before such a question is put, any member having direct personal or pecuniary interest therein shall announce this fact and request to be excused from voting. The presiding officer of the meeting or a majority of the members present may then excuse the members from voting upon the question. The disqualifying interest must be such as affects the members directly, and not as one of a class. 
(Code 1991, § 145.04; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.05. - Authority to be a public corporation. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority and the members thereof shall constitute and be a public corporation under the name provided for in Section 145.02, and as such shall have perpetual succession, may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be pleaded, and have and use a common seal. 
(Code 1991, § 145.05; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.06. - Powers generally. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority is hereby given power and authority as follows: 
(1)  To make and adopt all necessary bylaws, rules and regulations for its organization and operations not inconsistent with law; 
(2)  To elect its own officers, to appoint committees and to employ and fix compensation for personnel necessary for its operation; 
(3)  To enter into contracts with any person, agency, governmental department, firm or corporation, including both public and private corporations, and generally to do any and all things necessary or convenient for the purpose of promoting, developing and advancing the business prosperity and economic welfare of Hurricane, its citizens and industrial complex, including, without limiting any of the foregoing, the construction of any building or structure for lease to the State or Federal Government or any of its agencies or departments, and in connection therewith to prepare and submit bids and negotiate with the Federal Government or such agencies or departments in accordance with plans and specifications and in the manner and on the terms and conditions and subject to any requirements, regulations, rules and laws of the United States of America for the construction of said buildings or structures and the leasing thereof to the Federal Government or such agencies or departments; 
(4)  To amend or supplement any contracts or leases or to enter into new, additional or further contracts or leases upon such terms and conditions, for such consideration and for such term of duration, with or without option of renewal, as may be agreed upon by the Hurricane Development Authority and such person, agency, governmental department, firm or corporation; 
(5)  Unless otherwise provided for in and subject to the provisions of, such contracts or leases, to operate, repair, manage, and maintain such buildings and structures and provide adequate insurance of all types, and in connection with the primary use thereof and incidental thereto to provide such services, such as barbershops, newsstands, drugstores and restaurants, and to effectuate such incidental purposes, grant leases, permits, concessions or other authorizations to any person or persons, upon such terms and conditions, for such consideration and for such term of duration as may be agreed upon by the Hurricane Development Authority and such person, agency, governmental department, firm or corporation; 
(6)  To delegate any authority given to it by law to any of its officers, committees, agents or employees; 
(7)  To apply for, receive and use grants-in-aid, donations and contributions from any source or sources, and to accept and use bequests, devises, gifts and donations from any person, firm or corporation; 
(8)  To acquire real property by gift, purchase, or construction, or in any other lawful manner, and hold title thereto in its own name and to sell, lease or otherwise dispose of all or part of such real property which it may own, either by contract or at public auction, upon the approval by the board of directors of the Hurricane Development Authority; 
(9)  To purchase or otherwise acquire, own, hold, sell, lease and dispose of all or part of any personal property which it may own, either by contract or at public auction; 
(10)  Pursuant to a determination by the Board that there exists a continuing need for programs to alleviate and prevent unemployment within the City in which the Hurricane Development Authority is intended to operate or aid in the rehabilitation of areas in said City which are underdeveloped, decaying or otherwise economically depressed, and that moneys or funds of the Hurricane Development Authority are necessary therefor, to borrow money and execute and deliver the Hurricane Development Authority's negotiable notes, mortgage bonds, other bonds, debentures, and other evidences of indebtedness therefor, on such terms as the Hurricane Development Authority shall determine, and give such security therefor as shall be requisite, including giving a mortgage or deed of trust on its real or personal property and facilities in connection with the issuance of mortgage bonds; 
(11)  To expend its funds in the execution of the powers and authority herein given, for a public purpose and use in the public interest, and for the general welfare of the people of the City. 
(Code 1991, § 145.06; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.07. - Necessity and right of eminent domain. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority is authorized and empowered to exercise the right of eminent domain if the right of eminent domain is made, entered and at least three-fourths of the entire tract has either been purchased, optioned or is under contract to be purchased. Provided, that prior to the issuance of the order a public hearing on the public necessity of the exercise of eminent domain is published in a Class II legal advertisement published in accordance with W. Va. Code, § 59-3-2. A separate hearing must be held and separate order issued for each parcel over which the Authority wishes to exercise the power of eminent domain which shall not exceed one fourth of any land development site proposed by the Hurricane Development Authority. 
(Code 1991, § 145.07; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.08. - Incurring indebtedness; right of creditors. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority may incur any proper indebtedness and issue any obligations and give any security therefor which it may deem necessary or advisable in connection with carrying out its purposes as herein before mentioned. No statutory limitation with respect to the nature, or amount, interest rate or duration of indebtedness which may be incurred by municipalities or other public bodies shall apply to indebtedness of the Hurricane Development Authority. No indebtedness of any nature of the Hurricane Development Authority shall constitute an indebtedness of the governing body of the City, or a charge against any property of the City. 
(Code 1991, § 145.08; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.09. - Agreements in connection with obtaining funds. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority may, in connection with obtaining funds for its purposes, enter into any agreement with any person, firm or corporation, including the Federal Government; or any agency or subdivision thereof, containing such provisions, covenants, terms and conditions as the Hurricane Development Authority may deem advisable. 
(Code 1991, § 145.09; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.10. - Property, bonds and obligations of authority exempt from taxation. 
    The Hurricane Development Authority shall be exempt from the payment of any taxes or fees to the State or any subdivision thereof or to any officer or employee of the State or other subdivision thereof. The property of the Hurricane Development Authority shall be exempt from all local and municipal taxes. Bonds, notes, debentures and other evidence of indebtedness of the Hurricane Development Authority are declared to be issued for a public purpose and to be public instrumentalities, and shall be exempt from taxes. 
(Code 1991, § 145.10; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.11. - Contributions, funds, accounts, reports, audit, records and accounts. 
    Contributions may be made to the Hurricane Development Authority by the City, by any persons, firms or corporations. The bookkeeping records, receipts and expenditures for the Hurricane Development Authority will be handled as part of the General Fund for the City and will be included in the annual financial statement and audit procedures for the City, as set forth in the West Virginia Code. 
(Code 1991, § 145.11; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.12. - Sale or lease of property; reversion of assets upon dissolution. 
    In the event the board of the Hurricane Development Authority shall so determine, the Authority may lease or sell all of its property and equipment, either by contract or at public auction, on such terms and conditions as the Hurricane Development Authority may fix and determine. Upon the dissolution of the Hurricane Development Authority, all of its assets and property shall revert to and become the property of the City. 
(Code 1991, § 145.12; Ord. of 10-3-1994) 
Sec. 145.13. - Charitable contributions-Acceptance and distribution of assets. 
    Hurricane Development Authority is hereby authorized to accept donations from the public for charitable purposes under the direction of the Board of Officers. Furthermore, all donations/assets will be distributed in accordance with the Hurricane Development Authority's policies and procedures. All policies/proceeds for the acceptance of donations shall be in accordance with the Rules and Regulations of the Internal Revenue Service as the same pertains to 501(c)3 designations. 
(Ord. of 8-1-2016(1)) 
ARTICLE 147. - HURRICANE BUILDING COMMISSION[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State law references and cross references- Authority to establish, W. Va. Code, § 8-33-1 et seq. 

Sec. 147.01. - Establishment. 
(a)  There is hereby formed, created and established a municipal building commission, which shall have all of the powers set forth in W. Va. Code, § 8-33-1 et seq., referred to in this Article as "the Act," and which shall be known as the Hurricane Building Commission. 
(b)  The Hurricane Building Commission shall be a public corporation and shall have perpetual existence in accordance with the Act. 
(Code 1991, § 147.01; Ord. of 4-7-1997) 
Sec. 147.02. - Members; term. 
(a)  The Board of said Hurricane Building Commission shall consist of three members, of whom no more than two-thirds shall be from the same political party; no member shall hold any office (other than the office of notary public) or employment under the United States of America, the State of West Virginia, any county, municipality or political subdivision thereof, or any political party; all members shall be residents of the City of Hurricane, West Virginia, and no member shall receive any compensation for services as such, but shall be reimbursed by said Board for reasonable and necessary expenses authorized and actually incurred in the discharge of his duties. 
(b)  As the term of each initial appointee expires, the successor who shall fill the vacancy created by such expiration shall be appointed for a term of five years. Each member of the Board shall have one vote on all matters coming before the Board. Any individual who is a resident of the City shall be eligible to serve as a member of the Board. The City shall inform the Hurricane Building Commission of its appointments or reappointments to the Board by delivering to the Commission a certified copy of the order or resolution making such appointment or re-appointment. 
(c)  If any member of the Board dies, resigns or for any other reason ceases to be a member of the Board prior to expiration of his term, the Council shall appoint another individual to serve the unexpired portion of the term of such individual. Such member shall remain a member of the Board until his successor is appointed. 
(Code 1991, § 147.02; Ord. of 4-7-1997) 
Sec. 147.03. - Project approval by city required. 
    The Hurricane Building Commission shall not undertake any projects or financing therefor without the prior written approval of the City of Hurricane. 
(Code 1991, § 147.03; Ord. of 4-7-1997) 
ARTICLE 153. - EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
State law references and cross references- Compensation of officers and employees, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-12; conflict of interest, W. Va. Code, § 8-5-19; bonds, W. Va. Code, §§ 6-2-11, 8-12-5(46), (47); reimbursement of employment applicant, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(54); employee benefit fund, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-5(56); insurance and indemnification, W. Va. Code, § 8-12-7 et seq.; retirement benefits, W. Va. Code, § 8-22-1 et seq.; military leave, W. Va. Code, §§ 6-11-1 et seq., 15-1F-1; social security, W. Va. Code, § 5-7-5; police working during holidays, W. Va. Code, § 8-14-2a; firemen working during holidays, W. Va. Code, § 8-15-10a. 

Sec. 153.01. - Bonds required of city officers and employees. 
(a)  Every officer of the City, whether or not required by any other ordinance of the City or by any order of Council, and in addition to every City officer, every employee or agent of the City who in the course of his official duties collects, receives, handles or has custody or control of City funds, negotiable instruments or securities of value in excess of $100.00 at any one time shall, before entering upon the duties of his office or position and within two weeks after his election or appointment, give bond, with corporate surety, payable to the City, in such amount not less than $5,000.00 as shall be determined from time to time by Council, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, a true accounting to give of all City funds, negotiable instruments and securities collected, received or handled by him or coming within his custody or control, and payment thereof to the City; provided, that the bond of the City Manager shall be in an amount not less than $50,000.00; the bond of the Mayor shall be in an amount not less than $5,000.00; the bond of the City Treasurer shall be in an amount not less than $10,000.00; the bond of Municipal Court Clerk shall be in an amount not less than $5,000.00; and provided further, that the bonds of deputies and assistants shall be in amounts not less than the bonds of their respective principals; and provided further, that during any period when two or more offices or positions are held by the same person, the bond for such person shall be in an amount not less than the highest amount required for any one of such offices or positions. 
(b)  The premiums on all such bonds shall be paid by the City. 
(c)  All bonds required by this section shall be in the custody of the City Recorder, except that the bond of the City Recorder shall be in the custody of the Mayor. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-14; Code 1991, § 153.01) 
Sec. 153.02. - Bond required of those authorized to carry firearms. 
(a)  Each officer, employee and agent of the City who in the course of his official duties is authorized to carry any firearm shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, give bond to the City, with corporate surety and in such amount as may be fixed by Council but not less than $5,000.00, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties and for the payment of all damages, judgments and decrees resulting from the negligent or unlawful use of such firearm by himself or by any other person with his knowledge and consent. 
(b)  Premiums on all such bonds shall be paid by the City. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-15; Code 1991, § 153.02) 
Sec. 153.03. - Compensation of city officers and employees. 
(a)  Officers and employees of the City shall receive as compensation for their services such salaries, wages and other emoluments as may be provided in the annual budget or other action, order, resolution or ordinance of Council. Fees paid to City officers and employees for documents or services rendered in the performance of official duty shall be paid over by them to the City and shall not be deemed to constitute compensation to them personally. 
(b)  As required by W. Va. Code, § 8-5-12, the following salaries for elected officials shall be as follows: 
(1)  The annual salary of the Mayor of the City shall be $18,000.00 and said official shall also be entitled to reimbursements for travel for City-related activities, not to exceed budgeted amounts. 
(2)  The annual salary of the Recorder shall be $2,400.00. 
(3)  The annual salary of the appointed Treasurer shall be $6,000.00. 
(4)  The annual salary of each Councilperson shall be $2,400.00. 
(Code 1991, § 153.03; Ord. of 3-6-1995; Amend. No. 2004-001, § 153.03, 2-17-2004) 
Sec. 153.04. - Federal social security. 
    Council, having heretofore elected to extend the benefits of Title II of the Federal Social Security Act to all eligible City officers and employees, as provided in W. Va. Code, § 5-7-5, hereby declares that the plan for extending those benefits as heretofore submitted to and approved by the State Auditor in his capacity as the "state agency" shall continue in full force and effect and that the City shall conform to all applicable provisions of W. Va. Code, §§ 5-7-1-5-7-10. 
(Code 1979, § 2-1-21; Code 1991, § 153.04) 
ARTICLE 161. - MUNICIPAL COURT[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Sept. 2, 2014(2), amended Article 161 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Article 161 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1979, § 12-1-1-12-1-25; the Code of 1991, §§ 161.01-161.24. 
State law references and cross references- Establishment, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-2; general right of appeal, W. Va. Code, § 8-34-1; costs for crime victims compensation fund, W. Va. Code, § 14-2A-4; costs for funding law enforcement training academies, W. Va. Code, § 30-29-4; search warrant, W. Va. Code, § 62-1A-1; payment of fine by credit card, W. Va. Code, § 8-10-2a. 

Sec. 161.01. - Power and jurisdiction. 
(a)  Criminal jurisdiction. The Municipal Court of the City shall have criminal jurisdiction over violations of the City laws, municipal ordinances, and these codified municipal codes. A person convicted in the Municipal Court shall have the right of an appeal to the court having jurisdiction over appeals. If the proceeding was tried without a jury, the hearing on the appeal shall be a trial de novo. The Municipal Court shall have the jurisdiction in any criminal cases involving any violation(s) of these codified municipal codes and future municipal codes, orders, ordinances, and resolutions committed within the City; or 
(b)  Civil jurisdiction to enforce municipal code[s]. The Municipal Court of the City shall have plenary civil jurisdiction over any civil action brought in the name of the City by the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor authorized by the City Solicitor or by the City Council) to enforce any of the City laws, ordinances, municipal codes, and these codified municipal codes. In any such civil action brought in the name of the City, the Municipal Court shall have jurisdiction over only those appropriate civil cross-complaints and third-party complaints asserted in that action that did not arise without the corporate limits of the City. A person adversely affected by the judgment of the Municipal Court in a civil action under this subsection (b) shall have the right of an appeal to the court having jurisdiction over appeals. 
(c)  Territorial jurisdiction of Municipal Court. Whenever the Municipal Court determines that the exercise of its jurisdiction pursuant to this Section 161.01 cannot be reasonably and efficiently exercised by confining the exercise thereof within the corporate limits of the municipality, the powers and authority of the Municipal Court under this Section 161.01 shall extend beyond the corporate limits of the City to the extent necessary to the reasonably efficient exercise of such powers and authority within the corporate limits; provided, however, that the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court shall not extend more than one mile beyond the corporate limits of the City. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.02. - Mayor to act as Municipal Judge. 
    The Mayor or an appointee of the Mayor shall exercise all the powers and functions delegated to a municipal judge. Any reference herein to "the Mayor" shall be construed to refer to the "Municipal Judge or Judges," if such appointment has been made. 
(Ord. of 1-7-2013(1); Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.03. - Execution of process. 
(a)  Enforcement of Municipal Court process. Council or the Mayor, in the exercise of the powers and duties prescribed by the laws of the State, shall have the power and authority to enforce the attendance of witnesses, the production of books, papers and documents and to administer oaths in or pertaining to judicial matters before the Municipal Court in the same manner and with the same effect and under the same penalties as magistrates and other officers of the State authorized to administer oaths; and the Municipal Court shall have the power and authority to punish for contempt as hereinafter provided. All process necessary to enforce the powers conferred by the laws of this State and by these codified municipal codes and future municipal ordinances, on Council or the Municipal Court, shall be signed by the Mayor, or by a majority of the members of Council present, if the Mayor refuses to act; and any such process when issued may be executed by any member of the Police force, or by any other person who may be appointed or deputized by Council, or the Mayor. 
(b)  Any warrant or other process by the Mayor may be executed by the officer to whom it is delivered, at any place in the County. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.04. - Witnesses; penalty for failure to appear. 
(a)  The names of those desired as witnesses may in any case be endorsed upon the warrant. In lieu of such endorsement, the Mayor may issue his subpoena for any witness. Any witness, properly summoned, pursuant to endorsement of the warrant, summons or by subpoena, who fails or refuses to attend the trial or to testify, may be proceeded against as for contempt. The Mayor may issue his warrant to compel attendance of such witness. 
(b)  When such witness has been brought before the Municipal Court, he shall be informed of the default of which he is charged, and given an opportunity to show cause, if any he has, why he should not be punished for contempt. If, in the opinion of the Court, such witness has been guilty of contempt, he may be punished in the same manner and to the same extent as for a contempt committed before a Magistrate. 
(c)  The fine for contempt under this Section 161.04 for each separate instance of contempt shall not exceed $500.00 or the imprisonment 15 days, or both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.05. - Mayor's power of arrest. 
    The Mayor may cause the arrest and detention of all riotous and disorderly persons and of those violating the peace and good order of the City by issuing his warrant for such persons. If it is impracticable or inconvenient to issue his warrant before such arrest, he may cause such arrest before issuing the warrant therefor. 
(Ord. of 1-7-2013(1); Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.06. - Officer's power of arrest. 
    An officer may arrest for offenses committed in his presence without a warrant being first issued, and take the offender before the Mayor or Municipal Court. All other arrests are to be made by warrant. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.07. - Preliminary procedure. 
    Before trying a person who has been arrested and charged with violation of a municipal code, a warrant shall be issued by a person of competent authority, returnable before him specifying the offense or violation charged. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.08. - Warrants; by whom issued. 
(a)  The Mayor, Municipal Judge or Magistrate Judge shall each have the authority to administer oaths to complainants and to issue arrest warrants thereon for violations of municipal ordinances and the municipal codes. 
(b)  The City Recorder in the absence of the Mayor or Municipal Judge shall have authority to issue warrants for all offenses committed within the Police jurisdiction of the City. 
(Ord. of 1-7-2013(1); Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.09. - Warrant; issuance upon complaint. 
(a)  A warrant shall issue in any case upon a sworn complaint. The complaint is a written statement of the essential facts constituting the offense charged. 
(b)  If it appears from the complaint that there is probable cause to believe that an offense has been committed and that the defendant has committed it, a warrant for the arrest of the defendant shall issue to any officer authorized by law to arrest persons charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance or of this municipal code. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.095. - Trial by jury in certain criminal cases. 
    Whenever a defendant who has been charged with an offense for which a period of confinement in jail may be imposed is brought before the Municipal Court, the defendant is entitled to a trial by jury. If a Municipal Court Judge determines, upon demand of a defendant, to conduct a trial by jury in a criminal matter, the Municipal Court shall follow the procedures set forth in the rules of criminal procedure for magistrate courts promulgated by the Supreme Court of Appeals, except that the jury in municipal court shall consist of 12 members. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(2)) 
Sec. 161.096. - Trial by jury in certain civil cases. 
(a)  Right to jury trial in civil case. Whenever a party to a civil action before the Municipal Court shall be entitled by the Constitution or statutes of the United States or of the State of West Virginia to a trial by jury, and the Municipal Court Judge determines that a timely and proper demand for a jury trial has been made in compliance with the requirements of subsection (b) of this Section 161.096 by a party entitled to make such a demand, the Municipal Court shall conduct a trial by jury of those claims entitled to be tried by a jury in that civil matter.
