(3)  Any person who maintains, has maintained or imminently threatens to maintain such nuisance; or 
(4)  Any person who, at any time during the creation or existence of a nuisance, owned or had control over any real or personal property or facility at, on, in, from or with which a nuisance has been or imminently threatens to be created, contributed to, or maintained and, who, regardless of actual knowledge of the existence or nature of the nuisance condition, failed to abate the nuisance. 
(5)  Any person who at the time of disposal in the City of any prohibited hazardous substance or hazardous waste owned or operated any facility any part of which is located in the City at which such prohibited hazardous substance or hazardous waste was disposed of or is currently being managed; 
(6)  Any person who by contract, agreement, or otherwise arranged for disposal in the City, or arranged with a transporter for transport for disposal in the City, of a hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substances owned or possessed by such person, by any other party or entity, at any facility owned or operated in the City by another party or entity and containing such hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substances; and 
(7)  Any person (including any past or present generator or past or present transporter) who has contributed to or is contributing to the past or present disposal in the City of any hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance which presents or which may present a nuisance in any place in City or in the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary. 
(b)  Affirmative defenses to liability. There shall be no liability, civil or criminal, under this Section 1135.05 for any Person otherwise liable who can establish by clear and convincing evidence any of the following affirmative defenses applicable to the specified nuisance giving rise to the liability involved: 
(1)  With respect to any nuisance, all of the acts or omissions of the liable party(ies) with regard to the nuisance which cause that person to fall within any of the categories of liability set forth in Section 1135.05(a) were caused solely by: 
a.  An act of God; 
b.  An act of war; 
c.  An act or omission of a third party other than an employee or agent of the liable party or potentially liable party, or other than by one whose act or omission occurs in connection with a contractual relationship, existing directly or indirectly, with the liable party or potentially liable party if the liable party or potentially liable party establishes by clear and convincing evidence that: 
1.  He exercised due care with respect to the acts, events or conditions giving rise to the nuisance, taking into consideration the characteristics of such hazardous substance or pollutant, in light of all relevant facts and circumstance, and 
2.  He took precautions against foreseeable acts or omissions of any such third party and the consequences that could foreseeably result from such acts or omissions; or 
d.  Any combination of the foregoing paragraphs. 
(2)  With respect only to the nuisance declared and defined in Section 1135.04(b)(12), that the vehicle(s) is kept in an enclosed structure, and does not create or contribute to any dangerous or noxious condition at, in or about the structure. 
(3)  With respect only to the nuisance declared and defined in Section 1135.04(13), that the hazardous waste is being stored or disposed of at facility duly licensed pursuant to, and operating in compliance with it license issued pursuant to, RCRA sections 3004 and 3005, 42 U.S.C. §§ 6924 and 6925, (or, where applicable, in compliance with the Toxic Substances Control Act (15 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq.), or in compliance with the provisions of West Virginia law that operate, pursuant to RCRA § 3006, 42 U.S.C. § 6906, "in lieu of" RCRA sections 3004 and 3005, 42 U.S.C. §§ 6924 and 6925, (or, where applicable, in compliance with the Federal Toxic Substances Control Act (15 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq.) or other applicable Federal law, and all applicable State law requirements. 
(4)  With respect only to the nuisance declared and defined in Section 1135.04(b)(14), either or both of the following: 
a.  That the prohibited hazardous substance(s) were, or will be prior to their disposal or management within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, subject to a remedial action in which treatment that permanently and significantly reduces the volume, toxicity or mobility of the prohibited hazardous substance(s), pollutants, and contaminants is a principal element; or 
b.  In the absence of the treatment described in subsection (b)(4)a. of this Section 1135.05, that no other practicable treatment technologies are available for the prohibited hazardous substances. 
(c)  Liability of subsequent owner or operator. A subsequent owner of, or person controlling, any real or personal property or facility described in subsection (a)(4) of this Section 1135.05 shall be liable to the same extent as the person who owned or controlled such facility at the time when such nuisance was created, contributed to, or maintained, so long as such nuisance remains unabated. 
(d)  Scope of liability. When two or more persons liable for a nuisance pursuant to State or Municipal law, which nuisance presents or imminently threatens to present a single indivisible harm to public health, safety, welfare or the environment for which there is no reasonable and reliable basis for apportioning among those persons the harm to the public health, safety, welfare or to the environment presented or imminently threatened by the nuisance, each such person shall be jointly and severally liable for appropriate abatement of the nuisance, reimbursement to the City of all abatement action cost incurred and to be incurred by the City with respect to such nuisance, and for all damages to which the City may be entitled by law arising out of or related directly or indirectly to the nuisance act(s) or condition(s). Any liable party seeking to apportion the harm to public health, safety, welfare or the environment must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the component of the harm which is sought to be apportioned is scientifically and technologically susceptible to reasonable and reliable apportionment, that there is a reasonable and practicable basis for apportioning the harm, and that the separate abatement activity proposed for that harm or portion of the harm is as practicable, safe, efficient, reliable and cost-effective in providing the degree of protection of the public health, welfare and the environment as the abatement activity or activities, if any, proposed by the City. 
(e)  Civil liability for and recovery of future abatement action costs. In any action by the City to recover abatement action costs from a liable party in which the City has prevailed or substantially prevailed, the court shall enter a declaratory judgment on liability for abatement action costs with respect to the nuisance to be incurred by the City that will be binding on any subsequent action or actions to recover further abatement action costs or damages, unless all abatement actions with respect to the nuisance have been completed and all related abatement actions costs have been presented to the Court or their recovery expressly waived by the City. A subsequent action or actions for recovery of further abatement action costs with respect to the nuisance may be maintained at any time during the course of the abatement action, but must be commenced no later than three years after the date of completion of all abatement actions with respect to the nuisance. 
(f)  Settlement of joint and several liability and their effects. 
(1)  Contribution protection. A person who has resolved its liability to the City in an effective settlement approved by the Council after public notice and an opportunity for public comment or in a judicially approved effective settlement shall not be liable for claims for contribution regarding matters addressed in the settlement. Such settlement does not discharge any of the other potentially liable persons unless its terms so provide, but it reduces the potential liability of the others by the amount of the settlement. 
(2)  Rights of settling party. A person who has resolved its liability to the City for some or all of an abatement action or for some or all of the abatement action costs with respect to the nuisance in an administrative effective settlement approved by the City Council after public notice and an opportunity for public comment, or in a judicially approved effective settlement may seek contribution from any person who is not party to a settlement referred to in subsection (f)(1) of this Section 1135.05. 
(3)  Rights of settling party(ies) subordinate to City's rights. In any action seeing contribution for any liability imposed pursuant to this Section 1135.05, the rights of any person who has resolved its liability to the City shall be subordinate to the rights of the City. 
(g)  Liability for common areas of certain buildings. Whenever any owner or agent of any building in the City shall rent, lease or hire out to be occupied any building or part thereof as a home or residence of more than two families living independently of one another, or shall rent, lease or hire a building to different persons for stores and offices in such building, giving to each family or person the common right to halls, yards, water closets, privies or some of them, then such owner or agent shall be liable for the condition of such halls, yards, water closets and privies so that they do not constitute a nuisance or a hazard to the health or safety of the public or of any person, and shall be liable for any nuisance condition therein. Any noxious, offensive, unhealthy, unwholesome condition in such halls, yards, water closets and privies, or other condition in such halls, yards, water closets and privies that endangers the health or safety of any person is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(h)  Limitation of liability of any owner or operator of a licensed waste disposal facility. Notwithstanding any of other provision of Chapter 935 or of this Chapter 1135 of this Municipal Code: 
(1)  Any waste that is required to be reported to the City, and that is properly and timely reported to the City, pursuant to Section 1135.28 of this Municipal Code by any person who owns or operates a "Solid Waste Facility," as that term is defined in West Virginia Code § 22-15-2(34), any part of which is located in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, licensed by any agency or instrumentality of the Federal or State government to manage, including to treat, store, or dispose of, any waste, including, but not limited to, a "Solid Waste," as that term is defined in West Virginia Code § 22-15-2(31) or hazardous waste, shall not be deemed a hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance for purposes of Chapters 935 or 1135 of this Municipal Code; and 
(2)  Any person who owns or operates a "Solid Waste Facility" as that term is defined in West Virginia Code § 22-15-2(34), any part of which is located in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, licensed by any agency or instrumentality of the Federal or State government to manage, including to treat, store, or dispose of, any waste, including, but not limited to, a "Solid Waste," as that term is defined in West Virginia Code § 22-15-2(31) or hazardous waste who has complied with all applicable reporting obligations pursuant to Section 1135.28 of this Municipal Code shall not be subject to any penalty, civil or criminal, under this Chapter 1135 for any treatment, storage or disposal of any waste required to be reported, and that was properly and timely reported, to the City pursuant to Section 1135.28. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4); Ord. of 6-1-2015(1), § 4) 
Sec. 1135.06. - Dangerous condition; abandoned excavations or buildings. 
(a)  Dangerous condition, as used in this section, means any open, unguarded or unprotected excavation, refrigerators with intact doors, swimming pool or building which, when abandoned or left open or otherwise unprotected presents an endangerment to life or limb, or an abandoned, open, uncovered or otherwise unprotected well, cesspool, cistern or catch basin. 
(b)  No property owner, tenant or person having control of property within the City directly or indirectly shall create, allow or maintain any dangerous conditions to exist on premises that he, she or it owns or controls. 
(c)  A dangerous condition as defined in this Section 1135.06 is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.07. - Smoke. 
(a)  Emission from stationary engine, smokestack or chimney. The emission of dense smoke in the City from the smokestack of any stationary engine, steam roller, steam derrick, pile driver, tar kettle or other similar machine or contrivance, or from the smokestack or chimney of any building or premises, except for a period aggregating not to exceed seven minutes in any one hour, during which period the firebox is being cleaned or a new fire is being built therein, is a nuisance. 
(b)  Persons deemed guilty of violation. Any person owning, operating or in charge or control of any stationary engine, steam roller, steam derrick, steam pile driver, tar kettle or similar machine or contrivance or of any building or premises who causes or permits the emission of dense smoke within the City, in contravention of the provisions of this section from the smokestack of any stationary engine, steam roller, steam derrick, steam pile driver, tar kettle or from the smokestack or chimney of any building or premises so owned, controlled or in his charge is causing or contributing to a nuisance and is guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.08. - Inspections, investigations and complaints. 
(a)  When directed by the City Council. When so directed by the City Council, the City Manager, Chief of Police, Chief of the Fire Department and such other City officer or officers as may be designated by the City Council for such purpose, shall make inspections and investigations, or cause inspections and investigations to be made, under their direction and control, of such places, conditions, locations, structures, objects or activities from time to time within the City and within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary as the City Council may designate to determine whether any condition exists or activity is being engaged in which constitutes a nuisance within their respective fields of administrative and enforcement authority under State or Municipal law. 
(b)  Duty of City officers acting on their inherent authority. The City Manager, Chief of Police, Chief of the Fire Department or such other City officer or officers as may be designated by the City Council for such purpose, from time to time shall make inspections and investigations, or cause inspections and investigations to be made, under their direction and control, of such places, conditions, locations, structures, objects or activities within the City and within the area surrounding the City which is within one mile of the City boundary; and any such officer shall make or cause to be made an investigation to determine whether any condition exists or activity is being engaged in which constitutes a Nuisance within their respective fields of administrative or enforcement authority. 
(c)  Duty of City officers acting on responsible complaint. The City Manager, Chief of Police, Chief of the Fire Department, or such other City officer or officers as may be designated by the City Council or the City Manager for such purpose, upon receipt of complaint in writing made by any responsible person; provided, that such complaint alleges in sufficient detail: 
(1)  The facts believed to constitute the nuisance; 
(2)  The place or places where the condition exists or the activity is being engaged in; and 
(3)  If known, the names of the persons maintaining, committing, or contributing to the nuisance, and the name of the owner(s) of the property upon which the condition exists or activity is being engaged in. 
shall make inspections and investigations, or cause inspections and investigations to be made under their direction and control of such places, conditions, locations, structures, objects or activities within the City and within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary that are the subject of the complaint to determine whether any condition(s) exists or activity(ies) is being engaged in which constitutes a nuisance under State, County, or Municipal law. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.09. - Right to conduct investigations and inspections pertaining to known or suspected nuisances. 
(a)  Inspection of real property and premises. In order to assure adequate protection of the public health, safety, welfare and the environment from activities or conditions constituting a nuisance as defined by State law or this Municipal Code, and in order competently to carry out the purposes of this Section 1135.09, the City Manager, or any City officer authorized by the City Manager or the City Council, upon presenting appropriate credentials to the person(s) present at or in charge of the premises where a suspected nuisance condition exists or a suspected nuisance activity is being conducted, is authorized: 
(1)  To enter without advance notice and at reasonable times and with the consent of the owner or any person in charge of such premises or facility any place within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary where a nuisance is known or suspected to exist; and 
(2)  To inspect and investigate, during regular working hours and at other reasonable times, given the nature and timing, if any of the nuisance condition or event, and within reasonable limits and in a reasonable manner, any place within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City limits where a nuisance is known or suspected to exist, and there inspect all pertinent conditions, structures, machines, apparatus, devices, equipment and the materials therein, take samples of any relevant material (allowing splits of any such sample to be taken by the person in charge of the location or premises at their sole cost) which pertain to the suspected nuisance act, condition or event, and to question privately any person(s) who may have knowledge relevant to the nuisance or its appropriate abatement. 
(3)  If any person refuses to consent to, attempts to limit, interfere with, or prevent the City Manager or any authorized representative of the City Manager or of the City Council from conducting an investigation and inspection pursuant to this Section 1135.09, the City Council or the City Manager may direct the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor) to obtain, or with the consent of the City Solicitor, the City Manager may himself obtain an inspection warrant from the Municipal Court, or, at the option of the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor authorized by the City Solicitor or by the City Council), from any other court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  Requirement to produce evidence and appear and give testimony. In making their inspections and investigations under Section 1135.08 of this Municipal Code, if any City officer identified in or pursuant to Section 1135.08 determines that it is necessary and proper to the complete investigation of any known or suspected nuisance to require the appearance and testimony of witnesses, the City officer may request the City Manager to issue, and the City Manager upon such request or, in the case of any investigation being conducted in whole or in part by the City Manager, upon his own instance, shall have authority to issue an investigative order upon ten days notice or upon shorter notice as may be necessary or appropriate under the circumstances, that may require: 
(1)  Any person who has or may have information relevant to the nature of, existence of, cause of, maintenance of, liability of, abatement of, an any actual or threatened nuisance or endangerment of public health, safety, welfare or the healthfulness of the environment within the City, or any information relevant to any person or persons who may be liable for: 
a.  Any actual or imminently threatened nuisance within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary; or 
b.  Any nuisance that is or may be adversely affecting or endangering the public health, safety, welfare, or the healthfulness of the environment within the City. 
(2)  Any person who has or may have information relevant to the assets, ability, liability and responsibility of any guarantor, indemnitor, or insurer of (or providing any benefits to) any person who is or may be a responsible party, which information may be relevant to the ability of the responsible party to perform or pay for the performance of any abatement actions, or to pay, indemnify, or reimburse for the costs of performance of an abatement action by any potentially responsible party(ies) or payment of abatement action costs incurred or to be incurred by the City; 
to appear before any City officer identified in Section 1135.08(a) and a certified court reporter designated by the City and give non-privileged testimony under oath and on a record concerning any of the matters or information described in subsections (b)(1) or (2) of this Section 1135.09, as well as concerning any documents or information that are or may be properly the subject of a request pursuant to subsection (b) of this Section 1135.09. At any such proceeding the City Manager and any of City's officers shall be represented by, and the witness may be questioned by, the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor authorized by the City Solicitor or by the City Council). In any such proceeding, witnesses shall be paid the same fees and mileage that are paid witnesses in the courts of this State. In case of contumacy or failure or refusal of any person to obey such an investigative order to appear and give testimony, the Municipal Court or the Circuit Court has jurisdiction to issue to the person an order requiring the person to appear, to produce evidence if asked and, when so ordered, to give testimony relating to the matter under investigation or in question. Any failure to obey such order of the court may be punished by the court as contempt thereof. Testimony may be compelled either before or after documents and information are produced as provided in this Section 1135.09. 
(c)  Requirement to produce documents, records and things. The City Manager, the City Solicitor any other City officer authorized to act pursuant to this section by the City Council may require, upon 20 days' notice or such shorter notice as may be necessary and appropriate under the circumstances, any person who has or may have information relevant to any nuisance or any endangerment to the public health, safety, welfare or the environment, or any information described in subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this Section 1135.09 within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundaries, regardless of where such information or documents are or may be found, to produce to the designated City officer, the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor authorized by the City Solicitor or by the City Council) or his designee on the date, time and place set forth in the investigative order: 
(1)  Complete, written responses to the City's written demand for information contained in the investigative order, submitted under oath and personally attested to before a notary public; and 
(2)  Production as and when demanded of any thing, and production of copies of any demanded, non-privileged books, records and other documents that contain, relate to, or may reasonably lead to the discovery of, any of the following information: 
a.  The nature, characteristics, origin or extent of any nuisance, or of any hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance that is or may be contributing to a nuisance in the City or within one mile of the City limits; 
b.  The nature, characteristics, origin or extent of any existing or threatened nuisance or release of any hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance or wastes; 
c.  The identification, nature or quantity of materials which may be or may have been related by source, composition, origin, destination or use to the actual or threatened nuisance or endangerments to the public health, safety, welfare, or to the environment in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City limits, or to an existing or threatened release of hazardous waste, prohibited hazardous substance or waste in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary; 
d.  The identification, location, or nature and extent of any assets (including any guarantee, indemnity or insurance agreements, contracts or policies of any kind), or information pertaining to the financial condition of any person who is, may have been, or may be a liable party as defined by Municipal, County or State law; 
e.  Information relating to the ability of any person who is, may have been, or may be a liable party to pay for or perform an abatement action or to reimburse the City for abatement action costs it has incurred or may incur, including information regarding the assets, ability, liability and responsibility of any guarantor, indemnitor, or insurer of (or providing any benefits to) any person who is or may be a responsible party, to perform or pay for the performance of any abatement actions, or to pay, indemnify, or reimburse for the costs of any potentially responsible party's performance of an abatement action or payment of abatement action costs incurred or to be incurred by the City. 
(3)  Any person required by any authorized officer of the City to produce information or to produce and to permit the inspection and copying or photographing or sampling of any books, records, other non-privileged documents, or any other evidence pursuant to subsection (c) of this Section 1135.09 shall, on or before the date and time set forth in the investigative order for production, deliver a written certification, signed under oath administered before a notary public or other official authorized by law to administer such an oath attesting to the following: 
a.  That the written information provided, if any, is truthful and complete; 
b.  That the books, records, other documents, or things produced, if any, together with those withheld from production as privileged or for any other reason and for which the information required by Section 1135.09 of this Municipal Code has been timely produced, if any, constitutes the truthful and complete results of a diligent search, conducted in good faith, for the information and thing(s) demanded; and 
c.  That all books, records, documents and things responsive to the investigative order to produce that are in the possession, care, custody, or control of that person, its agents, representatives, employees, directors, partners, consultants, parent corporations or other entities, subsidiary corporations or other entities, and to the extent they are available to that person, all books, records, documents and things responsive to the investigative order to produce that are in the possession, care, custody, or control of that person's predecessors or successors-in-interest, and any and all persons acting on its behalf or in concert with it, have been produced as required by the investigative order. 
(d)  Materials required supporting assertions of privilege or other legal basis for failure to produce. 
(1)  Privilege log information required : In order to allow the investigating City officer and the City Solicitor adequately to assess the validity of any assertion of any privilege for the purposes of determining whether public resources should be expended to pursue production of any withheld document or other evidence, any person from whom documents or other evidence are demanded pursuant to Section 1135.09 who fails or refuses to produce any such document(s) or thing(s) based in whole or in part upon a claim of privilege or for any other reason must file with the City Clerk and with the Office of the City Solicitor on or before the date set forth in the investigative order for production of the requested documents or things a concise written statement setting forth all factual bases supporting the claim of privilege or other asserted basis for withholding the requested document(s) or thing(s) and the asserted legal authority upon which the failure or refusal to produce is based. The concise written statement required by this Section 1135.09(d) must, at a minimum, include the following as to each document or thing to be withheld: 
a.  The identity of the author thereof, the parties thereto and any other person who helped in its preparation; 
b.  The title or other identifying data; 
c.  The date of the document or, if no date appears thereon, the approximate date; 
d.  A summary of the nature (e.g., letter) and content of the document sufficient to identify it; 
e.  The name and location of each person having or last having possession, care, custody or control of the original and of each copy thereof and the names of all persons to whom the document has been disclosed; 
f.  If such document was, but is no longer in the possession or control of the person from whom the document is requested, what disposition was made of it, including, but not limited to, the name and address of the person who disposed of the document as well as the date, time, place and mode or method of disposal; and 
g.  The precise, current location of the document and the complete name and address of its current custodian. 
(2)  Effects of failure to provide required privilege log information : Any person required by subsection (d)(1) of this Section 1135.09 to provide the concise written statement described therein who fails or refuses timely to file a concise written statement that fully complies with the requirements of that subsection, thereafter, in any proceeding before the City Council, or in any civil or criminal action by the City or by the City Solicitor acting on behalf of the City Council, to enforce any provision of this Municipal Code or any other duly enacted Municipal Code of the City, to abate any nuisance condition, or to recover any abatement action costs, or other fees or penalties pursuant to this Municipal Code, shall be barred from asserting or relying upon any privilege for which a compliant statement of supporting factual basis and legal authority was not timely filed, and shall further be barred from withholding, based upon any assertion of any such privilege, any document or thing for which all of the details required by subsection (d)(1) of this Section 1135.09 were not timely provided. The bar established by subsection (d)(2) of this Section 1135.09 shall apply only to the assertion of any privilege or other asserted basis for withholding requested information, document(s) or thing(s) with respect to which this Section 1135.09 required the filing of a concise written statement, but for which no compliant statement was timely filed. It shall not apply to any failure or refusal to produce such documents based upon the claimed application of the privilege against self-incrimination. 
(e)  Investigations upon reasonable request. Any person who believes that there exists within the City or within one mile beyond the corporate limits of the City a nuisance as defined by State law or this Municipal Code, or who believe that any person may be in imminent danger of physical harm by reason of a known or suspected nuisance may request an inspection by giving notice to the City Manager or his authorized representative of the known or suspected nuisance. Any such notice shall be reduced to writing, shall set forth with reasonable particularity the grounds for the notice and shall be signed by the person requesting the inspection. A copy of the notice shall be provided to the person in charge of the premises or location at which the nuisance is alleged or suspected to exist or his agent no later than the time of the inspection: Provided, that upon the request of the person giving the notice, his name and the names of individual who may have provided him information shall not appear in the copy or on any record published, released or made available pursuant to the public, unless the release of such information is required by a valid court order. If, upon receipt of the notification, the City Manager or City Council determines there are reasonable grounds to believe that such violation or danger exists, the City Manager shall make or cause to be made an inspection in accordance with the provisions of this section as soon as practicable to determine if the violation or danger exists. The City Manager or his authorized representative shall maintain records of the results of any such investigation, which shall be made available to the public upon request. The authority of the City Manager or his authorized representative to inspect any premises for purposes of investigating a notice and report made pursuant to this subsection (c) shall not be limited to the alleged nuisance, but shall extend to any other area of the premises in which the City Manager or his authorized representative has reason to believe that a nuisance may exist. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.10. - Trade secrets; claims of confidentiality. 
(a)  Claim of confidentiality; time limits for asserting claim. Any person required to submit information pursuant to this Article 1135, which information such person believes in good faith to constitute confidential information, may assert a confidentiality claim in accordance with this Section 1135.10. Such claim must be made as soon as practicable, but in no event later than ten days from the date the information was submitted. If a claim of confidentiality is not made within ten days of submission, the City Manager may make the information available to the public without further notice. 
(b)  Submission of information claimed to be confidential. 
(1)  Confidential information - hardcopy submissions. All information that is claimed to be confidential and which is submitted to the City Manager pursuant to the requirements of this Municipal Code in hardcopy form must be submitted on colored paper in order to readily identify such information. The claimant must mark each page containing confidential information "CONFIDENTIAL COPY." The claimant must clearly underscore or highlight by shading the text of all information in the confidential copy that the claimant asserts to be confidential in a manner that will be clearly visible on photocopies of the confidential copy. 
(2)  Redacted submission of information claimed to be confidential for public disclosure. For each hardcopy submission of information, any portion of which is claimed to be confidential, a complete set of the information must be submitted simultaneously on uncolored paper with the information claimed to be confidential redacted, and with the words "REDACTED COPY" marked clearly on each page, so that a set of information is suitable for public disclosure and provides notice to the public that a claim of confidentiality has been made. 
(3)  Confidential information - electronics submissions. For electronic submissions containing information claimed to be confidential, the claimant must submit a cover document and the written justification as required under Section 1135.10(c), regardless of whether that document is submitted in electronic or hardcopy form. Upon the request of the City Manager, the claimant must submit a redacted form of the information. 
(4)  The claimant may assert that multiple pieces of data, which do not individually qualify as confidential information, could be pieced together to form confidential information if made publicly available. The City Manager shall assess such "mosaic effect" claims on a case-by-case basis, and take such action, if any, as is appropriate to effect the protections intended by this Section 1135.10. 
(c)  Cover document. 
(1)  Designee. Each submission of information to the City Manager, any portion of which is claimed to be confidential, must be supported by a cover document that identifies the name and address of the claimant and designates a person as the proper addressee of communications from the City Manager or the City Council regarding information gathering under the Act, the name, address, and telephone number of the designated person; and a request that all City inquiries and communications regarding information claimed as confidential (oral and written) be directed to the designee. The cover document must be submitted within the time frame specified under Section 1135.10(a) when a claim of confidentiality is made. 
(2)  Justification for claimed confidentiality in cover document : In addition to the information required under subdivision (1) of this Section 1135.10(c), the cover document must, at a minimum, include the following: 
a.  A statement that the information is being submitted pursuant to "Section 1135.10 of the Municipal Code of the City of Hurricane, Putnam County, West Virginia"; 
b.  Identification of each segment of information within each page that is submitted as confidential; and the period of time for which the confidential treatment is desired by the claimant (e.g., until a certain date, until the occurrence of a specified event, or permanently); and 
c.  A detailed justification for each segment of information that is claimed confidential. The justification must address the criteria set forth in subsection (e)(1) of this Section 1135.10 and must include the following information: 
1.  If the reason for the claim of confidentiality is that the information would reveal a trade secret, a description of the substantial harmful effects which disclosure of the confidential information would have upon the claimant's competitive position, an explanation of why such harmful effects are substantial, and an explanation of the causal relationship between disclosure and such harmful effects; 
2.  If the confidential information consists of information other than trade secrets, the claimant must provide a description of the information and an explanation as to how it meets the definition of confidential information set forth in subsection 2(e) of this Article 1135; and 
3.  Any other substantiation that is relevant in establishing that the asserted confidential information is confidential. 
(3)  Redacted version. If the cover document contains confidential information, the claimant must provide a redacted version, which will be available for public disclosure. 
(4)  Cover document as basis for review. The cover document justifying the claim of confidentiality will form the basis for the City Manager's review of the confidentiality claim. If the claimant submits additional information to support the confidentiality claim pursuant to subsection (f)(3) of this Section 1135.10, the additional submission will also be considered. 
(d)  Formal submission to City Manager. 
(1)  Confidential copy. The claimant must seal the confidential copy in an envelope displaying the word "CONFIDENTIAL" in bold type or stamp on both sides. This envelope must be enclosed in another envelope for transmittal to the City Manager. The outer envelope must bear no markings indicating the confidential nature of the contents. 
(2)  Method of delivery. The claimant must send the package containing all required information to the City Manager by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by other means providing a reliable and verifiable receipt for delivery. 
(e)  Determination of confidentiality. In the course of making a determination of confidentiality, the City Manager shall consider the following criteria in addition to the required justification under subsection (c)(2) of this Section 1135.10: 
(1)  The claim of confidentiality has not expired by its terms, nor been waived or withdrawn; 
(2)  The claimant has satisfactorily shown that it has taken reasonable measures, and intends to continue taking such measures, to prevent disclosure of the information to others; 
(3)  The information claimed to be confidential is not, and has not been, reasonably obtainable without the claimant's consent by other persons (other than by lawful means available to governmental bodies) by use of legitimate means; for example, the information is not contained in materials which are routinely available to the general public, including without limitation material in administrative or judicial proceedings/decisions, press releases, copies of speeches, pamphlets and educational materials; 
(4)  The extent to which the information has been disclosed to others and whether it was disclosed to other persons either by the claimant (except in a manner which protects the confidentiality of the information)or without the consent of the claimant (other than by subpoena or by discovery based on a showing of special need in a judicial proceeding, arbitration, or other proceeding in which the claimant was required to disclose the information to such other persons, as long as the information has not become available to persons not involved in the proceeding), and the precautions taken to prevent further disclosure; 
(5)  If the United States Environmental Protection Agency, any department, agency or instrumentality of the State of West Virginia or of any other state, or any other department, agency or instrumentality of the United States has previously made a confidentiality determination relevant to the pending confidentiality claim, copies of all such confidentiality determinations; and 
(6)  No law, regulation or order by a court or other tribunal of competent jurisdiction specifically requires disclosure of the information or provides that the information is not confidential information. 
(e)  Notice of determination by the City Manager. 
(1)  If, after review of all the information submitted, the City Manager determines that the information is not confidential, the City Manager will notify the claimant by certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice will state the basis for the determination and that it constitutes the final decision of the City Manager concerning the confidentiality claim. 
(2)  If, after review of all the information submitted, the City Manager determines that the information is confidential, the City Manager will treat such information as confidential in accordance with the provisions set out in subsection (e)(6) of this Section 1135.10. The City Manager will send written notice of the determination to the claimant. This notice will state the basis for the determination and that it constitutes the final decision of the City Manager. The City Manager shall send the notice of its decision to the claimant by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(3)  If a determination has not been made prior to the time that a request for information is received from the public, the City Manager will, after allowing the claimant up to ten days to claim the information as confidential in accordance with this Section 1135.10, proceed expeditiously to make a final determination in accordance with this section. Before making such determination, the City Manager will provide notice to the claimant that a request for the confidential information has been received and provide the claimant a period of five days to submit a written response to that request to the City Manager. 
(4)  All requests to inspect or copy documents submitted under the Article must state with reasonable specificity the documents or type of documents sought to be inspected or copied. Within ten business days of the receipt of a request, the City Manager will: 
a.  Advise the person making the request in writing of the time and place where the person may inspect and copy the documents which, if the request addresses information claimed as confidential, may not be sooner than 20 days following the date of the determination to disclose, unless an earlier disclosure date is agreed to by the claimant; or 
b.  Deny the request, stating in writing the reasons for denial. 
(5)  If the request addresses information claimed as confidential, the City Manager will provide notice of the action taken pursuant to this Section 1135.10 to the claimant by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(6)  Treatment of information pending confidentiality determination. The City Manager will treat asserted confidential information as confidential in accordance with the provisions of this Section 1135.10(h) of this Municipal Code until the City Manager has made a final determination that the asserted information is not confidential. 
(f)  Appeal of confidentiality determination. Any person adversely affected by a determination regarding confidential information under this Section 1135.10 may appeal the determination of the City Manager to the City Council. An appeal to the City Council of the final determination of the City Manager must be filed with City Clerk within 15 days after the date upon which the aggrieved person received notice of the final decision of the City Manager. The filing of a timely notice of appeal will stay any determination to disclose confidential information pending a final decision on the City Council on appeal. Upon the timely filing of a notice of appeal the City Manager shall compile a record of all documents and other information considered and all documents and other information submitted City by the claimant with respect to the decision that is the subject of the appeal. The City Manager shall forthwith transmit the compiled record to the City Council. The scope of review on appeal to the City Council is limited to the question of whether the portion of the records, reports, data or other information sought to be deemed confidential, inspected or copied is entitled to be treated as confidential under this Article. The City Manager and the City Council will take all measures to afford evidentiary protection in appeals as necessary to protect the confidentiality of the information at issue, including the use of in-camera proceedings before the City Council and the sealing of records when appropriate. 
(g)  Treatment of confidential and asserted confidential information. 
(1)  Handling of confidential information by authorized personnel : Only those authorized City employees under the supervision and control of the City Manager and attorneys representing the City and authorized by the City Solicitor or City Council, or authorized employees of the Office of the City Clerk whose activities necessitate access to information for which a confidentiality claim has been made may open and handle any envelope or file which is marked "CONFIDENTIAL." 
(2)  Storage of records. The City Manager shall assure that his office or the Office of the City Clerk stores any records containing confidential or asserted confidential information only in secure rooms, provided that if such records are in a form which is not amenable to such storage, the City Manager shall assure that such records are stored in a manner which similarly restricts access by persons to whom disclosure of the confidential information in question is restricted. With regard to confidential electronic data, the City Manager will take every reasonable precaution to safeguard the integrity of the data. 
(3)  Confidential information clearly identified. Any records made, possessed, or controlled by the City Manager or the City Council and containing confidential or asserted confidential information, will contain indicators clearly identifying the confidential or asserted confidential information. 
(4)  Record of persons accessing confidential information. The City Manager shall assure that his office and the Office of the City Clerk maintain a record of all persons obtaining access to confidential or asserted confidential information, including the date and time of, and the reasons for, the access. 
(5)  Unauthorized use or disclosure prohibited. No person shall access, use or disclose all or any part of confidential information other than authorized by this Municipal Code. 
(h)  Release of confidential information to other governmental entities. Information designated as confidential may be released to governmental entities, their authorized employees and agents as may be necessary to discharge their responsibilities under any legislation that expressly authorizes access to or review of confidential information. Any governmental entity or person requesting information designated as confidential must, prior to receiving such information, complete the "Description of Intent" form attached as Appendix A to this Municipal Code and agree to be bound by the terms of the "NonDisclosure Agreement" attached as Appendix B to this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code. Any governmental entity or person receiving information designated confidential will take appropriate measures to safeguard such information and to protect against its improper disclosure. 
(i)  Use of confidential material by the City Manager. A claim of confidentiality will in no way limit the City Manager, or any authorized assistant to the City Manager, in the exercise of the powers or duties of his office under this Article to see to the effective investigation and abatement of any nuisance within the City and the timely and effective protection of the public health, safety, welfare and the environment from any endangerments, and see to and enforce compliance with any order of the City Council issued pursuant to this Article 1135. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.11. - Actions and reports by City officers. 
(a)  Admonition in the absence of an imminent hazard. If at any time any City officer identified in or pursuant to Section 1135.08 or any Police officer of the City finds a condition to exist or an activity being engaged in which constitutes a nuisance, he shall warn any person who is or may be responsible liable therefor and who is present or readily on call that the nuisance must be abated without delay, and that failure to do so may result in appropriate legal action against him, and that he will be subject to all expenses incurred by the City as well as to a possible criminal penalty. 
(b)  Conditions or activities that may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, welfare or the environment. If it appears to such officer that the nuisance constitutes an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, welfare, safety or the environment, or presents and imminent fire hazard, he shall forthwith take such lawful action within his capabilities as may be necessary to negate the hazard, or else to clear the endangered area of persons, and he shall notify the City Manager promptly by the most expeditious means of communication. 
(c)  Reporting. All City officers identified in or pursuant to Section 1135.08 and all Police officers of the City shall report to the City Manager the facts as to any nuisance found by them upon investigation and the action, if any, taken by them pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, together with recommendations as to the manner of abatement, the time limit for abatement and such other professional recommendations and comment as they may deem pertinent. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.12. - Nuisance abatement response authorities. 
(a)  General nuisance abatement response authorities. Whenever the City Council or any court determines that there is an existing or imminently threatened nuisance in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the city boundary, or that there may be an imminent and substantial endangerment to the public health, safety, to the healthfulness of the environment or to any natural resources held in trust for public arising out of or resulting from, in whole or in part, an existing or imminently threatened nuisance in the City, the City Manager, City Council or the Court shall require the liable parties to undertake, in full compliance with the requirements of this Municipal Code an abatement action that will: 
(1)  Provide timely and effective abatement of the nuisance; 
(2)  Provide timely and appropriate protection of the public health, safety, welfare, and healthfulness of the environment or adequate protection of natural resources held in trust for public from any imminent and substantial endangerment that may be presented by the existing or imminently threatened nuisance; 
(3)  Utilize permanent solutions and alternative treatment technologies or resource recovery technologies to the maximum extent practicable; and 
(4)  Provided it first meets the requirement of subsection (1), (2) and (3) of this Section 1135.12(a), be "cost-effective," as that term is in defined in the NCP. 
(b)  Additional requirements applicable to abatement action for certain environmental nuisances. Whenever the City Council or any court determines that a nuisance as defined and declared in Section 1135.04(b)(13), (14), or (15) exists or is imminently threatened to be created within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, the City Council or the court shall require the liable parties, to undertake abatement action consistent with and in full compliance with the requirements of NCP, as those requirements are modified pursuant to the provisions of Section 1135.12(a), (d) and (e). 
(c)  Abatement enforcement procedures. In addition to any other action taken by Federal, State, or other local government, whenever the City Manager determines that there is an existing or threatened nuisance in [the] City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, or that there may be an endangerment to the public health, safety, healthfulness of the environment or to the adequate protection of natural resources held in trust for public arising out of, in whole or in part, an existing or threatened nuisance, the City Manager shall proceed in any of the following ways: 
(1)  In accord with the provisions of this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code, file with the City Council and serve on such liable parties as the City Manager deems appropriate a complaint in the form of a proposed nuisance abatement order that would, if it became final and binding, require the named responsible party(ies) to undertake partial or comprehensive abatement actions consistent with the requirements of Section 1135.12(a) and (b), as modified, if at all, by the City Manager pursuant to subsections (c) or (d) of this Section 1135.12, so as to provide adequate protection of public health, safety, healthfulness of the Environment, and natural resources held in trust for the public; or 
(2)  Request that the City Solicitor, pursuant to the authority conveyed by this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code, promptly seek such relief with respect to the existing or threatened nuisance as is authorized by this Municipal Code from a court of competent jurisdiction; or 
(3)  At the discretion of the City Manager and with the advice and consent of the City Solicitor, both file and serve a complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order and request that the City Solicitor seek the judicial relief authorized by this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code. 
(d)  When abatement action required under this Article 1135 may be more stringent than the response action required by the NCP. Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this Section 1135.12, the City Manager may seek, and the City Council or court may order, additional or more stringent requirements for an abatement action required by this Article 1135 than those response actions that would or might apply under the NCP whenever the City Manager or the Court determines that there is or may be an endangerment to the public health, welfare, the environment or natural resources arising out of or resulting from, in whole or in part, an existing or threatened nuisance, and further determines that such additional or more stringent requirements are necessary or appropriate to secure adequate protection against, or appropriate abatement of, such nuisance, or are necessary or appropriate to protect or restore approved land uses consistent with the applicable City land use and development plans. 
(e)  Waiver of strict NCP compliance. On his own initiative or upon appropriately supported application for waiver by a liable or potentially liable party, the City Manager may agree to, or the City Council or court upon either consent of the City Manager or upon a timely and appropriately supported application for waiver by a liable or potentially liable party, may order, less stringent requirements for abatement action than those that would or might apply under the NCP, whenever the City Manager, City Council, or court determines that the requested waiver, if granted as requested or as modified by the City Manager, City Council or court, would result in an abatement action that will provide timely, adequate and reliable protection of the public health, safety, healthfulness of the environment and natural resources held in trust for the public, after considering the following factors: 
(1)  Adequate protection of the public health, welfare, the environment or natural resources in light of the existing or threatened endangerments presented and the public and private resources that are, or are likely to be, available to meaningfully and appropriately respond to such endangerments; 
(2)  Restoration of, to the fullest extent practicable, the free use and enjoyment of land within the City of Hurricane, consistent with its general plan, including but not limited to commercial, industrial and residential use and development; 
(3)  Safety of any public water supply; 
(4)  Providing adequate protection of the environment within the City, considered land use planning and development potential; and 
(5)  Preservation and restoration of the safety and healthfulness of the environment so as to preserve and expand the aesthetic interests and the appropriate development of social, recreational, residential and employment opportunities within the City. 
(f)  Right to appeal denial of waiver application. Any liable or potentially liable party whose application for a waiver of strict NCP compliance pursuant to subsection (d) of this Section 1135.12 has been denied in whole or in any significant part by the City Manager, may seek review by the City Council of the decision of the City Manager by filing with the City Clerk a petition for review within ten days of receipt of the decision of the City Manager for which review is sought. Any such petition must set forth in detail the grounds supporting the challenge of the decision of the City Manager and must be served on the City Manager and the City Solicitor. Following its review of the filed petition for review of the decision of the City Manager, the City Council will, by order, schedule such further briefings, hearings, or other proceedings, if any, with respect to the appeal as the City Council deems necessary and proper to the just resolution of the appeal. The City Council will issue a final written decision on any petition for review filed pursuant to this subsection (e). 
(g)  Exhaustion of municipal remedies required. Any liable party or potentially liable party seeking a waiver of any of the requirements for an abatement action set forth in Section 1135.12(a) or (b) of this Municipal Code, or seeking to have any abatement action imposed or to be imposed pursuant to this Municipal Code by the City Manager, the City Council, or by any court, regardless of by whom the action before any court was commenced, incorporate any standard or requirement less stringent than, or not consistent with, the NCP, must first raise the request of such liable party or potentially liable party for such relief by filing with the City Manager a request for waiver pursuant to Section 1135.12(d) of this Municipal Code, and thereafter exhaust all of the remedies provided by Sections 9(e) and 17 of this Municipal Code with respect to such a request for waiver. Failure of any liable party or potentially liable party under this Municipal Code to exhaust the municipal remedies available pursuant to Sections 1135.12(d) and 17 of this Municipal Code shall bar any request to any court or agency for imposition of any abatement action that does not at a minimum comply with the requirements of Section 1135.12(a) and (b) of this Municipal Code. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.13. - Commencement of enforcement action before City Council. 
(a)  Commencement of action before City Council for enforcement of this Article 1135. After conducting such investigation as is necessary and proper to conclude that there are reasonable grounds to believe: 
(1)  That a nuisance exists or is imminently threatened to be created at any place in the City or in the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, and the nuisance should be properly abated; or 
(2)  An appropriate civil penalty pursuant Section 1135.26 of this Municipal Code should be imposed upon one or more of the parties alleged to be liable for the civil penalty pursuant to Section 1135.26 of this Municipal Code; or 
(3)  That the provisions of subsections (1) and (2) of this Section 1135.13(a) are applicable and should be invoked. 
the City Manager may commence an nuisance abatement proceeding before the City Council by filing with the City Clerk a complaint against one or more of the parties liable or potentially liable pursuant to the provisions of this Article 1135 in the form of a complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order, or he may request the City Solicitor to file a complaint before a court of competent jurisdiction for imposition civil penalties pursuant to Section 1135.26, or take both such actions. 
(b)  Required contents of complaint before City Council. The complaint filed by the City Manager before the City Council shall be written and shall be directed against one or more persons alleged to be liable for abatement of the nuisance, as the City Manager may deem appropriate. Any such complaint filed and served by the City Manager pursuant to this section shall include a statement of the factual and legal grounds upon which the proposed order is issued, and shall set forth the proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law that the City Manager asserts support the appropriateness of the abatement actions sought and may include a schedule for completion of specific actions. A complaint filed with the City Council pursuant to subsection (a) of this Section 1135.13 shall on its first page in prominent text contained in a highlighted text box specifically advise the person(s) to whom it is issued of the right to contest the allegations of the complaint and the abatement action sought in the complaint, and request a hearing as provided for in Section 1135.15 of this Municipal Code. Within that same highlighted text box such proposed order shall also conspicuously advise the person to whom it is directed that failure to file and serve an answer to the City Manager's complaint in compliance with the requirements of Section 1135.17 of this Municipal Code within ten days of the date they were served with the City Manager's complaint will result in the complete and final termination of their legal right to contest the provisions or issuance of the proposed order, and, subject only to discretion of the City Council acting sua sponte, the adoption and issuance by the City Council of the proposed order as a binding final order of the City Council. The complaint shall state the findings of fact, conclusions of law and recommended final order that the City Manager seeks to have the City Council enter as a final order in the matter. 
(c)  Service of complaint. Service of the City Manager's complaint shall be accomplished in any manner authorized by law for the service of process in civil or criminal cases, including posting or publication when the person or persons to be served are beyond the jurisdiction of the City or when their names or addresses are unknown. If they are not named in the City Manager's complaint as respondent liable parties for the requested relief, the City Council shall cause an informational copy of the City Manager's complaint to also be served upon the owners of all premises upon which such alleged nuisance activity takes place or upon which such alleged nuisance condition exists, or that will be affected by the proposed abatement action, if any. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.14. - Procedure on application by City Manager for either a temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement action order. 
(a)  Applying for temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement action order. Upon filing with the City Council a verified complaint that complies with the requirements of Section 1135.13 of this Municipal Code and that alleges the existence at any place in the City or in the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundaries of a nuisance which may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, welfare, or to the healthfulness of the environment, or presents an imminent hazard to the health or safety of any person within or near the premises upon which such nuisance exists or where the nuisance activity is occurring, the City Manager may apply to the City Council pursuant to this Section 1135.14 for issuance of either or both a temporary nuisance abatement action order or a preliminary nuisance abatement action order. 
(b)  Required showing for temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement action order. No temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement action order shall issue unless the City Manager establishes on the record before the City Council by preponderance of the evidence and to the satisfaction of the City Council each of the following elements: 
(1)  That the conditions constituting, arising out of, or emanating from the alleged nuisance may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, welfare, or to the healthfulness of the environment, or presents an imminent hazard to the health or safety of any person or persons within or near the premises upon which such nuisance exists or where the nuisance activity is occurring; 
(2)  Unless consolidation as authorized in subsection (c)(2) of this Section 1135.14 has been granted, that the abatement action requested in the City Manager's application is no more extensive than necessary to provide adequate protection of the public health, safety or healthfulness of the environment or of the person or persons within or near the premises involved until such time as the City Council can hear the merits of the City Manager complaint pursuant to this Municipal Code; 
(3)  That there is a likelihood that the City Manager will prevail on the merits of the following required elements of its complaint: 
a.  A nuisance as defined and declared in Section 1135.02(k) of this Municipal Code exists or is imminently threatened to be created in the City or in the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundaries; 
b.  That one or more of the named respondents are a liable person as defined by Section 1135.05 this Municipal Code, with respect to the nuisance(s) at issue; 
c.  The abatement action(s) requested by the City Manager complies with the requirements of Section 1135.12 of this Municipal Code; 
d.  The abatement action requested by the City Manager is reasonably cost-effective in meeting the requirements of Section 1135.12 of this Municipal Code. 
(c)  Temporary nuisance abatement action order; notice; hearing; duration. A temporary nuisance abatement action order may be granted by the City Council without written or oral notice to the alleged liable party(ies) or that party's attorney only if: 
(1)  It clearly appears from specific facts shown by affidavit or by the verified complaint that a condition of nuisance that may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, or to the healthfulness of the environment, or that presents an imminent hazard to the health or safety of any person or persons within or near the premises upon which such nuisance exists or where the nuisance activity is occurring and immediate and irreparable injury, loss, or damage may result to the public health, safety or healthfulness of the environment before the alleged liable party(ies) or that party's attorney can be heard in opposition; and 
(2)  The City Solicitor certifies to the City Council in writing the efforts, if any, which have been made to give the notice and the reasons supporting the claim that notice should not be required. 
Every temporary nuisance abatement action order granted without notice shall be endorsed with the date and hour of issuance; shall be filed forthwith in the City Clerk's office and entered of record; shall define the injury and state why it may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, or to the healthfulness of the environment, or presents an imminent hazard to the health or safety of any person or persons within or near the premises upon which such nuisance exists or where the nuisance activity is occurring, and why the order was granted without notice; and shall expire by its terms within such time after entry, not to exceed 20 days, as the City Council fixes, unless within the time so fixed the order, for good cause shown, is extended for a like period or unless the party against whom the order is directed consents that it may be extended for a longer period. The reasons for the extension shall be entered of record. In case a temporary nuisance abatement action order is granted without notice, the City Manager's motion for a preliminary nuisance abatement action order shall be set down for hearing at the earliest possible time and takes precedence of all matters except older matters of the same character; and when the motion comes on for hearing the City Manager shall proceed with the application for a preliminary nuisance abatement action order and, if the City Manager does not do so, the City Council shall dissolve the temporary nuisance abatement action order. On two days' notice to the party(ies) alleged to be liable, to the City Manager and to the City Solicitor or on such shorter notice as the City Council may prescribe, the party(ies) alleged to be liable may appear and move for the dissolution or modification of the temporary nuisance abatement action order, and in that event the City Council shall proceed to hear and determine such motion as expeditiously as the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and the environment and the ends of justice require. 
(d)  Preliminary nuisance abatement action order. 
(1)  Notice. No preliminary nuisance abatement action order shall be issued without notice to the alleged liable party(ies). 
(2)  Consolidation of hearing with trial on merits. Before or after the commencement of the hearing of the City Manager's application for a preliminary nuisance abatement action order, the City Council may order the hearing of the action on the merits of the City Manager's complaint to be advanced and consolidated with the hearing of the application for a preliminary nuisance abatement action order. Even when this consolidation is not ordered, any evidence received upon an application for a for a preliminary nuisance abatement action order which would be admissible upon the trial on the merits of the City Manager's complaint becomes part of the record on the hearing and need not be repeated upon the hearing. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.15. - Who may request a public hearing on a nuisance abatement action order, effect of timely request. 
(a)  Request for a hearing on City Manager's complaint. Any person alleged to be liable for a nuisance to whom a complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order has been issued, and any owner, occupant or person in charge of any premises upon which a nuisance addressed by an nuisance abatement action order exists who is not named as a liable person in the nuisance abatement action order may, within three days from the receipt of service thereof, apply in writing to the City Manager for a public hearing on the matter. To be effective, any request for a public hearing must be received by the Office of the City Manager no later than the close of regular business hours for the City three business days after receipt of service of the nuisance abatement action order upon the requesting party, and must set forth in writing with reasonable particularity all of the following: 
(1)  If the applicant intends to contest liability for the nuisance at the public hearing, and if the applicant intends to contest liability, all facts upon which the applicant will rely at the public to contest liability under the complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order, or any part thereof; 
(2)  If the proposed nuisance abatement action order imposes joint and several liability upon the applicant that the applicant intends to contest at the public hearing as inappropriate because the harm presented by the nuisance is properly divisible pursuant to the provisions of Section 1135.05(d), all facts upon which the applicant intends to rely to establish that the harm is divisible; and 
(3)  If the applicant intends to assert at the public hearing that an alternative abatement action, removal action or remedial action is more appropriate than action required under the proposed nuisance abatement action order, all facts supporting the adequacy, appropriateness, and costs of any alternative remedial action to be presented at the public hearing. 
(b)  Effect of timely request for hearing on a proposed nuisance abatement action order. Whenever a timely request for a public hearing on a nuisance abatement action order that complies with the requirements of this subsection (a) of Section 1135.15 is received by the City Manager from a person authorized to request such a hearing, the terms of such proposed nuisance abatement action order shall be stayed pending action by Council at or following the public hearing. Unless earlier altered by order of the City Council, such stay will remain in full force and effect unless and until the person who requested the hearing fails to file a timely and compliant answer to the City Manager's complaint as required by Section 1135.17 at which point the proposed nuisance abatement action order will be and become a fully effective, final and binding order. 
(c)  Temporary and preliminary nuisance abatement orders unaffected. The provisions of Section 1135.15(b) do not apply to any temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement order obtained pursuant to Section 1135.14 of this Municipal Code, which temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement order shall not be stayed except upon order of the City Council that by its express terms applies to such temporary or preliminary nuisance abatement order. 
(d)  Effect of failure to timely and properly request a public hearing. If a respondent properly served with a complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order by the City Manager pursuant to this Article 1135 fails to timely file a request for a public hearing that complies with the requirements of Section 1135.15(a) of this Municipal Code, such proposed nuisance abatement action order will immediately be and become a final, binding and enforceable order, subject only to such modification or revocation, if any, that the City Council sua sponte may order pursuant to Section 1135.16 of this Municipal Code, if and only if the respondent is eligible for the discretionary relief authorized by Section 1135.16 of this Municipal Code. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.16. - Effect of untimely request for hearing on proposed nuisance abatement action order; Council options. 
    If any request for a public hearing on a proposed nuisance abatement action order that complies with requirements of subsection (a) of Section 1135.15 is received from a person authorized to request a public hearing under subsection (a) of Section 1135.12 later than three business days after service of the complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order upon the requesting party, and provided also that party has not failed to file a timely and compliant answer as required by Section 1135.17, and further provided that request set forth all facts upon which the applicant relies to support the contention that Council should excuse the delayed filing of the request, Council, in its sole discretion, may take any of the following actions: 
(1)  Summarily deny the request as untimely; 
(2)  For good cause shown, grant the request, with or without a stay of all or any portion of the provisions of the proposed nuisance abatement action order pending Council's decision at or following the public hearing on the proposed nuisance abatement action order; or 
(3)  For good cause shown, grant the request in part, with or without a stay of all or any portion of the provisions of the proposed nuisance abatement action order, pending Council's decision following the public hearing, limiting the scope of the public hearing to specific issues identified by Council. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.17. - Pleadings and procedures before City Council upon filing of City Manager complaint; actions by City Council upon timely request for hearing. 
(a)  Required answer to complaint of City Manager. Any person who has timely filed a request for hearing that complies with the requirements of Section 1134.15 of this Municipal Code, and who seeks to contest all or any part of the liability asserted in the complaint, or seeks to challenge any findings of fact or conclusions of law, or abatement action sought in the complaint must file a timely answer to the complaint that complies with the requirements of this Section 1135.17. An answer must be in writing, filed with the City Clerk, and served on the City Manager and the Office of the City Solicitor on or before the end of regular business hours on the tenth day following service of the City Manager's complaint/proposed order. Any answer must state both the legal and factual bases in support thereof, and must include at a minimum a summary of the issues, facts, and legal authorities to be raised at the hearing. 
(b)  Required contents of answer. The answer required by Section 1135.17(a) shall set forth in short and plain terms the respondent's defenses to each claim asserted in the complaint of the City Manager, and shall admit or deny the averments upon which the City Manager relies. If the respondent is without knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to the truth of an averment, the respondent shall so state and this has the effect of a denial.
