Denials shall fairly meet the substance of the averments denied. When a respondent intends in good faith to deny only a part or a qualification of an averment, the respondent shall specify so much of it as is true and material and shall deny only the remainder. Unless the respondent intends in good faith to controvert all the averments of the City Manager's complaint/proposed nuisance abatement action order, the pleader may make denials as specific denials of designated averments or paragraphs, or may generally deny all the averments except such designated averments or paragraphs as the respondent expressly admits; but, when the pleader does so intend to controvert all its averments, the pleader may do so by general denial, subject to the provisions of Section 1135.17(f) of this Municipal Code. 
(c)  Time requirement for answer deemed jurisdictional. The time requirement for filing the answer required by this Section 1135.17 shall be deemed jurisdictional and may not be waived. Upon timely receipt of an answer which complies with the requirements of this section, the City Clerk shall refer the matter to the City Council for further proceedings as set forth in this Municipal Code. 
(d)  Affirmative matters required in answer of respondent. The answer of each respondent required by Section 1135.17(a) must also set forth in writing with reasonable particularity all of the following, where applicable: 
(1)  If the respondent intends to contest liability, all facts upon which the respondent will rely at the public hearing to contest liability; 
(2)  If the complaint of the City Manager seeks to imposes joint and several liability upon the respondent, and the respondent intends to assert at the public hearing that the imposition of joint and several liability is inappropriate because the harm(s) presented by the nuisance is properly divisible pursuant to the provisions of Section 1135.05(d) of this Municipal Code, all facts upon which the respondent intends to rely to establish that the harm is divisible; and 
(3)  If the respondent intends to assert at the public hearing that an alternative abatement action, removal action or remedial action is more appropriate than the abatement action sought in the City Manager's complaint/proposed order, all facts supporting the adequacy, appropriateness, and costs of any alternative remedial action(s) the respondent intends to be present at the public hearing. 
(e)  Hearing before City Council upon timely request. Upon timely receipt of a request for hearing filed in compliance with the requirement of Section 1135.15 and timely filing of an answer compliant with the requirements of this Section 1135.17, the City Council shall issue an order setting the matter down for hearing within 30 days. The City Manager shall give prompt, written notice thereof to all parties having an interest therein; and further, he shall, at the expense of the applicant, publish an appropriate notice of such hearing in two newspapers of general circulation in the City. Hearings shall be recorded by electronic device or by court reporter. The West Virginia Rules of Evidence do not apply to the proceedings, but each party has the right to present evidence and examine and cross-examine all witnesses. 
(f)  Signing of pleadings, motions and other papers; representations to City Council; sanctions. 
(1)  Signing of pleadings and other papers submitted to City Council. Every pleading, motion and other paper submitted to the City Council in the course of a proceeding conducted pursuant to this Municipal Code shall be signed by at least one attorney of record in the attorney's individual name, or if the respondent or other party is not represented by an attorney shall be signed by that respondent or other party. Each paper shall state the signer's address and phone number, and the West Virginia State Bar identification number, if any. An unsigned paper shall be stricken unless omission of the signature is corrected promptly after being called to the attention of the attorney or party. 
(2)  Representations to or before the City Council. By presenting to the City Council (whether by signing, filing, submitting, or later advocating) a pleading, written motion, or other paper, an attorney or unrepresented party certifies that to the best of the person's knowledge, information, and belief formed after an inquiry reasonable under the circumstances: 
a.  It is not being presented for any improper purpose, such as to harass or to cause unnecessary delay or needless increase in the cost of litigation; 
b.  The claims, defenses, and other legal contentions therein are warranted by existing law or by a non-frivolous argument for the extension, modification, or reversal of existing law or the establishment of new law; 
c.  The allegations and other factual contentions have evidentiary support or, if specifically so identified, are likely to have evidentiary support after a reasonable opportunity for further investigation or discovery; and 
d.  The denials of factual contentions are warranted on the evidence or, if specifically so identified, are reasonably based on a lack of information or belief. 
(3)  Sanctions. If, after notice and a reasonable opportunity to respond, the City Council determines that subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) has been violated, the City Council may, subject to the conditions state below and in addition to or in lieu of the contempt fine it is empowered to impose pursuant to W. Va. Code § 7-1-6, impose an appropriate sanction upon the attorneys, law firms, or parties that have violated subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) or are responsible for the violation. 
a.  Initiated by motion : A motion by any party to any proceeding under this Municipal Code before the City Council for imposition of sanctions pursuant to this Section 1135.17(f) shall be made separately from other motions or requests and shall describe the specific conduct alleged to violate subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f). Such motion shall be filed with the City Clerk and shall be served on the County Solicitor and all parties to the proceeding or their attorney, but shall not be presented to the City Council unless, within ten days after service of the motion (or such other period as the City Council may prescribe), the challenged paper, claim, defense, contention, allegation, or denial is not withdrawn or appropriately corrected. If warranted, the City Council may award to the party prevailing on the motion the reasonable expenses and attorney's fees incurred in presenting or opposing the motion. Absent exceptional circumstances, a law firm shall be held jointly responsible for violations committed by its partners, associates, and employees. 
b.  Initiated on instance of the City Council : On its own initiative, the City Council may enter an order describing the specific conduct that appears to violate subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) and directing an attorney, law firm, or party to show cause why it has not violated subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) with respect thereto. 
(4)  Nature of sanction; limitations. A sanction imposed for violation of subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) shall be limited to what is sufficient to deter repetition of such conduct or comparable conduct by others similarly situated. Subject to the limitations in subparagraphs (a) and (b), the sanction may consist of, or include, directives of a non-monetary nature, and an order to pay a penalty into the appropriate City fund as directed by the City Council, or, if imposed on motion of a party and warranted for effective deterrence, and order directing payment to the movant of some or all of the reasonable attorneys' fees and other expenses incurred as a direct result of the violation. 
(5)  No sanction against represented party. Monetary sanctions may not be awarded against a represented party for a violation of subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f). 
(6)  Order to show cause to precede dismissal or settlement. Monetary sanction may not be awarded on the initiative of the City Council unless the City Council issues its order to show cause before a voluntary dismissal or settlement of the claims made by or against the party which is, or whose attorneys are, to be sanctioned. 
(7)  Required content of order imposing sanction. When imposing sanction pursuant to this subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f), the City Council shall describe the conduct determined to constitute a violation of this subparagraph (2) of this Section 1135.17(f) and explain the basis for the sanction imposed. 
(g)  Burdens of proof and persuasion. At any public hearing held before the City Council upon a complaint by the City Manager pursuant to this Article 1135, the City Manager has the burden of proving his allegation by a preponderance of the evidence and has the duty to go forward with the evidence. The respondent has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence respondent's entitlement to any affirmative defense set forth in Section 1135.05(b) and has the duty to go forward with evidence of respondent's entitlement to any such affirmative defense. 
(h)  Conduct of hearing before City Council. At any public hearing held before the City Council upon a complaint by the City Manager pursuant to this Municipal Code, any party to the action may appear in person or by attorney, either or both, and he may have process for the attendance of witnesses and the production of pertinent books and papers, if there are any; and other parties in interest may also appear and be heard under oath. 
(i)  Findings of facts, determinations, and conclusions of law. At the conclusion of the hearing, the City Council shall make findings of fact, determinations and conclusions of law as to whether: 
(1)  A nuisance as defined and described in this Municipal Code exists at any place in the City and with the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary; 
(2)  Whether each respondent is a liable party as defined by this Municipal Code with respect to a nuisance as defined and described in Section 1135.02(m) of this Municipal Code; and 
(3)  Whether any abatement action is necessary and proper to provide adequate protection of public health, safety and the healthfulness of the environment, and, if so, the appropriate abatement actions compliant with the requirements of Section 1135.12 of this Municipal Code required to be implemented. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.18. - Representation of respondent at public hearing. 
    At any public hearing held pursuant to this Article 1135, the respondent(s) may appear in person or by Attorney, either or both, and may have compulsory process for the attendance of witnesses and the production of pertinent books and papers, if there are any; and other parties in interest may also appear and be heard under oath. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.19. - Final action by City Council on City Manager's complaint; issuance of final nuisance abatement action order. 
(a)  Issuance of final nuisance abatement action order. If, after hearing all relevant and material facts and arguments from all parties on a case commenced before the City Council by a complaint filed by the City Manager, the City Council determines that a nuisance as defined and declared by this Municipal Code exists at any place in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, that one or more respondents are liable with respect to that nuisance, and that an abatement action is appropriate to provide adequate protection of the public health, safety, welfare, and the healthfulness of the environment with respect to such nuisance, the City Council shall take any or all of the following actions with respect to the liable party(ies) as the City Council deem appropriate and proper: 
(1)  Order any person or persons liable for such nuisance forthwith to cease and desist, as may be further delineated in the order, any activity causing, creating, contributing to, or maintaining the nuisance; 
(2)  Order any person or persons liable for such nuisance forthwith to proceed with all required speed appropriately and timely to implement abatement action(s) with respect to the nuisance and any endangerments to public health, safety, welfare or to the healthfulness of the environment that the nuisance may present in compliance with the provisions of the nuisance abatement action order within the time period stated in the nuisance abatement action order under the direction and supervision of a designated officer or agent of the City; 
(3)  Enter against any person or persons liable for such nuisance both such nuisance abatement action orders authorized in subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of this Section 1135.19; 
(4)  In addition to or in lieu of any other relief authorized [by] this Municipal Code, order any person or persons liable for such nuisance to undertake such further action as may be necessary and proper to remedy any adverse consequences to or endangerments of the public health, safety, welfare, or the healthfulness of the environment that may be presented as a result, in whole or in part, of the nuisance. 
(5)  Require one or more of the persons liable for the nuisance timely to reimburse the City for the abatement action costs that it has incurred and that it will incur with respect to the nuisance. 
(b)  Final action by City Council. City Council action issuing or declining to issue a nuisance abatement action order with respect to any alleged nuisance, dismissing a complaint filed by the City Manager, or issuing or declining to issue a nuisance abatement action order with respect to any alleged liable party(ies), or granting or denying a waiver of strict NCP compliance pursuant to Section 1135.12(d) shall be a final order of the City Council. 
(c)  Continuing jurisdiction of City Council. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, the City Council shall have continuing jurisdiction to enforce or modify any nuisance abatement action order and any other relief or recovery ordered by it pursuant to this Municipal Code.) 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.20. - Duty to comply with nuisance abatement action order. 
    No person who is a liable party for a nuisance as defined by Section 1134.05 of this Municipal Code and who has been named as a liable party in a nuisance abatement action order, and who has been served with such nuisance abatement action order as required by this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code shall disobey or fail timely to comply with the terms of such nuisance abatement action order that has become final and binding. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.21. - City's remedies upon failure or refusal to comply with nuisance abatement action order; City's recourse; lien created. 
(a)  City's option to have required abatement actions performed. If any person liable for a nuisance who has been named in and properly served with a nuisance abatement action order that has become final and binding fails or refuses to comply with the terms of such nuisance abatement action order, City Council, after giving reasonable notice to the liable person(s) named in the nuisance action abatement order and to such owner, occupant or person in charge of the premises at which the nuisance exists or which will or may be affected the required abatement action, if such persons are not named as liable person(s) in the nuisance abatement action order, may have such nuisance abated or the provisions of such nuisance abatement action order carried out. 
(b)  City's options to recover abatement action costs. Either separately or in connection with a notice under subsection (a) of this Section 1135.21, Council may give notice of the City's intention to collect its abatement action costs incurred and to be incurred with respect to the nuisance, from the owner, occupant or person in charge, by distress or sale, in the same manner in which taxes levied upon real estate for the benefit of the City are authorized to be collected, and the City's abatement action costs with respect to the nuisance shall remain a lien upon premises or part thereof, the same as taxes levied upon real estate; which lien may be enforced by a suit in equity before any court having jurisdiction, as other liens against real estate are enforced. In case of non-resident owners of real estate, such notice may be served upon any tenant, occupant, assignee or rental agent, or by publication thereof once a week for not less than two consecutive weeks in two newspapers of general circulation in the City. 
(c)  Abatement by or payment to the City not a bar to other remedies. Abatement by the City of any condition which constitutes a nuisance, in whole or in part, and reimbursement to the City of expenses incurred thereby shall not bar prosecution for creation or maintenance of a nuisance, or the City's ability to pursue all of its available civil and criminal remedies. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.22. - Apportionment of cost of abatement. 
    In the event that Council determines that the harm presented by a nuisance may reasonably and equitably be apportioned among several lots of property in proportion to the cost of abating a nuisances on those properties, Council may apportion to each lot in proportion to the amount of the work done and material used in abating the nuisance located on such lot. If Council determines this method of apportionment is impracticable or inequitable in any case, then, to the extent that the nuisance presents a single indivisible harm to public health, safety, welfare or the environment, such abatement action costs shall be addressed in accord with the provisions of Section 1135.05, otherwise those costs shall be apportioned on such other basis as Council determines to be fair and equitable. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.23. - Authority of City solicitor to seek injunction in the name of the City to enforce nuisance abatement action order, recovery of municipal abatement action costs and municipal enforcement costs. 
(a)  Judicial enforcement of nuisance abatement action order. As an alternative to any other recourse available to the City, whenever any person fails or refuses to comply with a nuisance abatement action order that is binding and effective and that was served upon such person in compliance with the requirement of this Article 1135, Council may direct the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor(s) authorized by the City Solicitor or by City Counsel) to apply in the name of the City to any court of competent jurisdiction, or to the judge thereof in vacation, for an injunction forthwith to enforce any binding and effective nuisance abatement action order issued pursuant to this Article 1135 of the Codified Municipal Codes of the City of Hurricane, WV, and to recover judgment for the abatement action costs incurred by the City, and, where appropriate, a declaratory judgment for abatement action costs to be incurred by the City as authorized by this Article 1135. 
(b)  Equitable criteria for injunctive relief authorized by this Section 1135.23. In any civil action brought pursuant to this Section 1135.23 by the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor in the name of the City of Hurricane in which a temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or partial or complete mandatory or prohibitory permanent injunction is sought, it shall not be necessary for the City to allege or prove at any stage of the proceeding that irreparable damage will occur should the temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction (including, enforcing or requiring compliance with any nuisance abatement action order) not be issued; or that the remedy at law is inadequate, and the temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction (including, enforcing or requiring compliance with any nuisance abatement action order) shall issue without such allegations and without such proof. 
(c)  Availability of remedies before the City Council not a bar to judicial relief. An application brought by the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor in the name of the City for injunctive relief pursuant to Sections 1135.21, 1135.23 or 1135.25 of this Municipal Code, or for imposition and collection of a civil penalty pursuant to Section 1135.26 of this Municipal Code may be filed and relief requested therein granted notwithstanding the fact that all remedies that may be available from the City Council pursuant to this Municipal Code have not been exhausted or invoked against the liable or potentially liable person or persons against whom the relief is sought. 
(d)  Recovery of municipal litigation costs. In any proceedings under this section in which the City is the prevailing party or substantially prevailing party, the City is entitled to recover, and the Court shall award to the City, its litigation costs and expenses, including attorneys fees and expenses, expert witness fees and expenses, and the fees and expenses of no more than one non-testifying technical or scientific expert to assist the City Attorney or Assistant City Attorney(s) in the preparation and prosecution of the action. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.24. - Arrest for committing or maintaining nuisance not prohibited. 
    Nothing in this Article shall be construed to prohibit any police officer from arresting any person for committing or maintaining a nuisance when such arrest is made pursuant to law. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.25. - Judicial abatement of nuisance, recovery of damages, authority of the City Solicitor. 
(a)  Authority of City Solicitor. In addition to or in lieu of any other remedy available to the City, the City Solicitor, or any Assistant City Solicitor(s) designated by the City Solicitor or by the City Council, may bring a civil action in the name of the City in any court of competent jurisdiction seeking any or all of the following remedies: 
(1)  Judicial abatement of a nuisance, as the same is defined in State law or in any Municipal Code(s) of the City of Hurricane, existing within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary in compliance with the requirements of Section 1135.12 of this Municipal Code, 
(2)  Recovery of any abatement action costs incurred or to be incurred by the city with respect to such nuisance; 
(3)  Where appropriate, the declaratory judgment on abatement action costs to be incurred by the City with respect to the nuisance as authorized by Section 1135.05(e); and 
(4)  Recovery of such other damages as may be available to the City by law arising out of or resulting from the act giving rise to the nuisance or harm or endangerments resulting in whole or in part from the conditions at or emanating from the nuisance; 
and the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor(s) must bring such action whenever directed by Council. 
(b)  Equitable criteria for injunctive relief authorized by this Section 1135.25. In any civil action brought pursuant to this Section 1135.25 by the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor in the name of the City of Hurricane, in which a temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or partial or complete mandatory or prohibitory permanent injunction or judicial nuisance abatement action order is sought, it shall not be necessary for the City to allege or prove at any stage of the proceeding that irreparable damage will occur should the temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction (including any nuisance abatement action order) not be issued; or that the remedy at law is inadequate, and the temporary restraining order, preliminary injunction, or permanent injunction (including any nuisance abatement action order) shall issue without such allegations and without such proof. 
(c)  Recovery of municipal litigation costs. In any civil action brought pursuant to this Section 1135.25 to abate a Nuisance in which the City is a prevailing party or substantially prevailing party, the City shall be awarded its litigation costs, including attorneys fees and expenses, expert witness fees and expenses, and the fees and expenses of no more than one non-testifying technical or scientific expert to assist the City Solicitor or Assistant City Solicitor(s) in the preparation and prosecution of the action. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.26. - Civil penalties. 
(a)  Imposition of civil penalties. Any person who violates requirement or prohibition of this Article 1135 of this Municipal Code, or who fails or refuses to comply with any temporary, preliminary or permanent nuisance abatement action order issued pursuant to this Article 1135, or who fails or refuses, without good and proper cause, to comply with an information demand issued pursuant to this Municipal Code, is liable to the City for the following civil penalty to be credited to and deposited in the proper City fund as directed by the City Council: 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (2) of this Section 1135.26(a), not more than $5,000.00, but not less than $100.00 per violation per each calendar day of violation; 
(2)  For any intentional, knowing or willful violation, not more than $10,000.00, but not less than $500.00 per violation, per each calendar day of each such violation. 
(b)  Commencement of civil action authorized with respect to civil penalties. Liability for civil penalties under this Section 1135.26 may be imposed in a civil action brought by the City Solicitor or any Assistant City Solicitor in the name of the City of Hurricane before any court of competent jurisdiction. Any such civil action seeking imposition of civil penalties pursuant to this Section 1135.26 by the City Solicitor (or any Assistant City Solicitor authorized by the City Solicitor or by the City Council) may be joined with an action for any other remedy available to the City pursuant to Federal or State law or pursuant to this Municipal Code. 
(c)  Determination of amount of civil penalty. In determining the amount of any civil penalty to be imposed under this Section 1135.26, the Court shall, at a minimum, impose a penalty amount which eliminates, to the maximum extent allowed by the limits set forth in Section 1135.26(a), all economic benefit which has accrued to and which is accruing, or will accrue to the liable party by reason of the nuisance giving rise to his liability or other non-compliance and which compensates the public for the harm and damage done to the public health, safety, welfare and to the healthfulness of the environment, if any, as a result of the liable party's maintenance of the nuisance or other non-compliance. Impossibility of substantial compliance, or the impossibility of quantifying the harm to the environment, does not bar the assessment of a civil penalty under this Section 1135.26. In addition, in determining the proper civil penalty to be imposed, the court shall consider the liable party's degree of recalcitrance, the absence of good faith cooperation with the City officers and the City Manager, and any other governmental entities responding to the nuisance, the liable party's defiance of or indifference to requirements of the law, and any unusual or extraordinary burdens imposed on the public health or welfare or the public fisc as a result of the creation or maintenance of the nuisance or other non-compliance as factors requiring enhancement of the minimum penalty amount. The court may mitigate the total amount of civil penalty calculated under the first sentence of this subsection (c) to reflect any part of the liable party's maintenance of the nuisance or other non-compliance caused by the existence of extenuating circumstances that were wholly beyond the liable party's control or to recognize bona fide efforts by the liable party to timely comply with the requirements of the law and to extend significant and meaningful cooperation to the City officers, the City Manager or the City Council, and to other governmental enforcing agencies with jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.27. - Criminal penalties. 
(a)  Imposition of criminal penalties. Any person committing any of the following specified offenses is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the following criminal sanctions: 
(1)  For the defendant's first violation of Section 1135.03 of this Municipal Code with respect to a nuisance which neither the City Council nor any court of competent jurisdiction has found and determined may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, welfare or to the healthfulness of the environment, defendant shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,500.00, or imprisoned for not more than 30 days; 
(2)  For the defendant's second or subsequent violation of Section 1135.03 of this Municipal Code with respect to a nuisance which neither the City Council nor any court of competent jurisdiction has found and determined may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety or to the healthfulness of the environment, defendant shall be fined not less than $500.00 nor more than $2,500.00, or imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned; 
(3)  For the defendant's violation of Section 1135.03 of this Municipal Code with respect to a nuisance which either the City Council or any court of competent jurisdiction has found and determined may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety, welfare or to the healthfulness of the environment, defendant shall be fined not less than $2,500.00 nor more than $10,000.00, or imprisoned for not more than 30 days; or both fined and imprisoned; 
(4)  For defendant's violation of Section 1135.19 of this Municipal Code with respect to any nuisance abatement action order which does not by its terms find that any nuisance addressed in the order, whether issued by the City Council or by any court, may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety or to the healthfulness of the environment shall be fined not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $5,000.00 for the first offense, and for any second or subsequent offense, shall be fined not less than $2,500.00 nor more than $5,000.00, or imprisoned in the county jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned; 
(5)  For defendant's violation of Section 1135.19 of this Municipal Code with respect to any nuisance abatement action order which by its terms finds that any nuisance addressed in the order, whether issued by the City Council or by any court, may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health, safety or to the healthfulness of the environment shall be fined not less than $5,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00 for the first offense, and for any second or subsequent offense, shall be fined not less than $7,500.00 nor more than $10,000.00, or imprisoned in the county or regional jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(6)  Any person who intentionally misrepresents any material fact in a submission to the City Manager or to the City Council in any record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained, produced or submitted under the provisions of this Municipal Code or of any order issued pursuant to it shall be fined not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00, or imprisoned in a county or regional jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(7)  Any person required to make a report and provide information pursuant to Section 1135.28(a) of this Municipal Code who fails to make the required report or provide the required information as and when required shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $5,000.00, or imprisoned in a county or regional jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(8)  Any person required to make a report and provide information pursuant to Section 1135.28(b) of this Municipal Code who willfully fails to make the required report or provide the required information as and when required shall be fined not less than $500.00 nor more than $5,000.00, or imprisoned in a county or regional jail not more than 30 days, or both fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  Complete defenses to criminal liability. Any defendant who can prove to the satisfaction of the court all of the elements of the following defense shall have no criminal liability for the acts specified in this Section 1135.27: 
(1)  Where a person holding a valid permit issued pursuant to Chapter 22 of the W. Va. Code is carrying out a program of pollution abatement or remedial action in compliance with the conditions and terms of that permit, such person is not subject to criminal liability under this Municipal Code arising out of the abatement of the pollution recognized and authorized by such permit. 
(c)  Courts of competent criminal jurisdiction. Both the Municipal Court and Magistrate Court shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the Putnam County Circuit Court to enforce the provisions of this Section 1135.27. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.28. - Reporting obligations. 
(a)  Required reports by owners and operators of licensed waste management facilities. Any person who owns or operates a site or facility, including, but not limited to, a "solid waste facility" as that term is defined in W. Va. Code § 22-15-2(34), any part of which is located in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary licensed by any agency or instrumentality of the federal, state or local government to manage, including to treat, store, or dispose of, any waste, including but not limited to a "solid waste," as that term is defined in W. Va. Code § 22-15-2(31) or hazardous waste, shall make the following report(s) and provide the following information to the City Manager regarding the following waste at least three working days prior to managing within the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary any of the waste(s) that gives rise to the reporting obligation under this subsection: 
(1)  Wastes generated by a removal action or remedial action. All available information about the source, quantity, physical, chemical or infectious characteristics of any Waste proposed for management or disposal in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary that was generated in whole or in part by any abatement action, removal action, remedial action, nuisance abatement action or by a environmental clean-up at any site, regardless of by whom ordered or performed, and the results of any analysis of such waste. 
(2)  Wastes known or reasonably suspected to be hazardous wastes. All available information about the source, quantity, physical, chemical or infectious characteristics of any waste proposed for management or disposal in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary that any person described in Section 1135.28(a) knows or reasonably suspects to be a "hazardous waste" as that term is defined in W. Va. Code § 22-18-3(26). 
(3)  Wastes requiring any license or permit modification, special permission, waiver, or any waste-specific action by any governmental authority prior to the management of that waste in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundaries. All available information about the source, quantity, physical, chemical or infectious characteristics of the waste proposed for management or disposal within the City of Hurricane or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary which requires any new license or permit, the modification of any license or permit, the granting of any special permission or waiver, or any waste-specific action by any governmental authority prior to the management or disposal of that waste in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary, together with complete copies of any materials, including but not limited to application materials, and reports of any analysis of the waste submitted to any governmental agency with respect to such waste. 
(b)  Required reports regarding location and releases of hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substances. Any person, other than a person subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this Section 1135.28, who owns, operates, or is in charge of any site or facility in the City or within the area surrounding the City and within one mile of the City boundary shall, as soon as he has knowledge of the presence at or on that site or facility of any hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance, or of the release into the environment of any hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance (other than a release in compliance with a valid Federal or State permit) at or from such site or facility, immediately notify the City Manager of the location or release of such hazardous waste or prohibited hazardous substance. 
(c)  Use of reported information. Notification received pursuant to this Section 1135.28 or information obtained by the exploitation of such notification shall not be used against the reporting person in any criminal case, except a prosecution for perjury or for giving a false statement. 
(d)  Consequences of failure to report. Any person obligated by this Section 1135.28 to make a report who fails to make a timely report that complies with the requirements of this Section 1135.28 shall forfeit and not be entitled to assert, or in any other way benefit from, the defenses to liability set forth in Section 1134.05(b). 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.29. - Provisions severable. 
    The several sections and subsections of this Article 1135 are severable, and if any section or subsection hereof shall be held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, all the remaining sections and subsections of the article shall nevertheless remain valid. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Sec. 1135.30. - Effective date. 
    This Article of the City of Hurricane, Putnam County, West Virginia shall become effective September 2, 2014. 
(Ord. of 9-2-2014(4)) 
Part Thirteen - PLANNING AND ZONING CODE 
ARTICLE 1305. - PURPOSE AND INTERPRETATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State law references and cross references- Zoning authority generally, W. Va. Code, § 8A-7-1. 

Sec. 1305.01. - General provisions. 
    This Zoning Ordinance establishes comprehensive zoning regulations for the City of Hurricane, State of West Virginia, and provides for the administration, enforcement and amendment thereof, in accordance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, ch. 8A. 
(Code 1991, § 1305.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1305.02. - Reserved. 
Sec. 1305.03. - Statement of legislative intent. 
    It is the intention of the City: 
(a)  To guide its future growth and development to achieve the most beneficial and convenient relationship among the residential, nonresidential and public areas within the City; considering the suitability of each area for such uses, as indicated by existing conditions, trends in population and modes of living, and future requirements considering such conditions, trends and requirements both within the City and in relationship to areas outside thereof; 
(b)  To provide adequate light, air and privacy; to secure safety from fire and other danger, and to prevent overcrowding of the land and undue congestion of the population; 
(c)  To protect the character and the social and economic stability of all parts of the City; to encourage the orderly and beneficial development of all parts of the City; and to protect and conserve the value of land and buildings appropriate to the various districts established by this comprehensive Zoning Ordinance; 
(d)  To bring about the gradual conformity of the uses of land and buildings throughout the City through the comprehensive Zoning Ordinance set forth herein, and to minimize conflicts among the uses of land and buildings; 
(e)  To promote the most beneficial relationship between the use of land and buildings, and the street system which serves these uses, having particular regard to the potential amount and intensity of such land and building uses in relationship to the traffic capacity of the street system, so as to avoid congestion in the streets, and to promote safe and convenient vehicular and pedestrian traffic movements appropriate to the various uses of land and buildings throughout the City; 
(f)  To provide a guide for public action in the orderly and efficient provision of public facilities and services, and for private enterprise in building development, investment and other economic activity relating to uses of land and buildings throughout the City. 
(Code 1991, § 1305.03; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1305.04. - Territorial application of zoning ordinance. 
    This Zoning Ordinance applies within the corporate limits of the City of Hurricane, West Virginia. 
(Code 1991, § 1305.04; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1305.05. - Reserved. 
Sec. 1305.06. - Conflicting ordinances; effective date. 
    In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of health, safety and general welfare of the City. The Ordinance is not intended to interfere with or abrogate or annul other rules, regulations or ordinances of the City or to supersede any deed restrictions, provided that where this Ordinance imposes a greater restriction upon the use of buildings or premises, or upon the height of a building, or requires larger open spaces than are imposed by other such rules, regulations, ordinances or deed restrictions, the provisions of this Ordinance shall prevail. This Ordinance shall become effective on October 4, 1977. For areas annexed to the City after this date, this Ordinance shall become effective on the date of annexation. 
(Code 1991, § 1305.06; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
ARTICLE 1309. - DEFINITIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State law references and cross references- Statutory definitions, W. Va. Code, § 8A-1-2; general definitions, Section 101.02. 

Sec. 1309.01. - General definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Zoning Ordinance, certain terms or words used herein shall be defined or interpreted as follows: 
(a)  Shall and will are always mandatory and are not discretionary. "May" is permissive. 
(b)  Building or structure includes any part thereof. 
(c)  Used for includes "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for" or "occupied for." 
(d)  Person includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association or any other similar entity. 
(e)  Lot includes "parcel" or "plot." 
(Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1309.02. - Definition of terms. 
    Terms used in this Zoning Ordinance shall have the definition provided in any standard dictionary, except the following terms: 
(1)  Abandonment means the relinquishment of property or a cessation of the use of the property by the owner or lessee without any intention of transferring rights to the property to another owner or resuming the nonconforming use of the property for a period of one year. 
(2)  Accessory building means a building subordinate to the main building and used for purposes customarily incidental to those of the main building. 
(3)  Area, net floor, means (as applied to off-street parking) the area used or intended for services to the public as customers, patrons, clients or tenants, including areas occupied for fixtures and equipment used for display or sale of merchandise. Floor areas may be excluded which are used exclusively for storage, housing of mechanical equipment integral with the building, for maintenance facilities or for those areas so restricted that customers, patients, clients, salespersons and the general public are normally denied access. 
(4)  Automobile repair, major, means general repair, rebuilding or reconditioning of engines, motor vehicles or trailers; collision service, including body, frame or fender straightening or repair; overall painting or paint shop; vehicle steam cleaning. 
(5)  Automobile repair, minor, means minor repairs, incidental body and fender work, painting and upholstering, replacement of parts and motor service to passenger automobiles and trucks not exceeding 11/2 tons capacity, but not including any operation specified under "Automobile repair, major." 
(6)  Automobile sales lot means a lot arranged, designed or used for the storage and display for sale of any motor vehicle, and where no repair work is done except minor incidental repair of automobiles displayed and sold on the premises. 
(7)  Boardinghouse means a residence in which, for compensation, lodging or meals, or both, are furnished to not more than nine guests. A boardinghouse shall not be deemed a home occupation. 
(8)  Building or structure means any structure having a roof supported by columns or by walls designed for the shelter or housing of any person or animal. Also includes freestanding signs. 
(9)  Building Code Enforcement Official means the City Building Code Enforcement Official or his authorized representative. 
(10)  Building line means the line of that face of the building nearest the front line of the lot. This face includes porches but does not include steps. 
(11)  Camper. See "Trailer." 
(12)  Child care center means a day nursery, child boarding home, day camp, summer camp, foster family home or other place for the reception, board or care with or without compensation, of a child or children under 16 years of age. For the purpose of this Ordinance, a facility providing day child care between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. to not more than three children shall not be considered a child care center. Further, "child care center" shall not include any family-type facility which provides child care to not more than five children placed by order of any court of competent jurisdiction, or by any public welfare department or other governmental agency having responsibility of placing children for care, or placed by a child-placing agency. 
(13)  Commercial means engaging in a business, commerce, enterprise, activity or other undertaking for a profit. 
(14)  Conforming use means any use complying with the regulations of this Ordinance. 
(15)  Depth of lot means the main horizontal distance between the front lot line and rear lot line of a zoning lot. 
(16)  Dwelling means a building designed for dwelling purposes. "Dwelling" or any combination thereof shall not be deemed to include hotel, roominghouse or boardinghouse, motel, clubhouse, hospital or other accommodations used for more or less transient occupancy. 
(17)  Dwelling group means two or more detached dwellings located on the same lot and conforming to the special conditions and requirements hereinafter set forth. 
(17.5)  Enclosed structure means a structure surrounded by walls or one continuous wall and having a roof enclosing the entire structure and includes a permanent appendage thereto. 
(18)  Erected includes built, constructed, reconstructed, moved upon or any physical operations on the land required for the building. Excavation, fill, drainage and the like shall be considered part of the erection. 
(19)  Exception means the permission or approval granted by the Board of Zoning Appeals in situations where the provision therefor is by the terms of this Ordinance. 
(20)  Family means any number of individuals living and cooking together as a single housekeeping unit, as distinguished from a group occupying a boardinghouse. 
(21)  Front yard means the open space extending across the whole width of the lot, between the front line of the building and the street right-of-way line. 
(22)  Height. The height of a building shall be measured from the mean level of the ground surrounding the building to a point midway between the highest and lowest points of the roof, provided that chimneys, spires, towers, tanks and similar projections shall not be included in calculating the height. 
(23)  Home occupation means: 
a.  An accessory use which: 
1.  Is clearly incidental to or secondary to the residential use of a dwelling unit; 
2.  Is customarily and traditionally carried on within a dwelling unit by one or more occupants of such dwelling unit; 
3.  Occupies not more than 25 percent of the total floor area; and 
4.  Is limited to members of the family except for one secretarial employee. 
b.  In connection with the operation of a home occupation, it shall not be permitted: 
1.  To sell upon the premises articles produced elsewhere than on the premises. 
2.  To have exterior displays, or a display of goods visible from the outside. 
3.  To store materials or products outside of a principal or accessory building or other structure. 
4.  To display signs, except one sign not exceeding a total area of two square feet, affixed to the building, not projecting more than one foot beyond the building, that will indicate from the exterior that the building is being utilized in part for purposes other than that of a dwelling. Illuminations shall be either a white nonflashing enclosed light design or indirect lighting from a shielded source. 
5.  To make external structural alterations which are not customary in residential buildings. 
6.  To generate traffic by such home occupation in greater volume than would normally be expected in the residential neighborhood; any need for parking generated by the conduct of such home occupation shall be provided off the street and other than in a required front yard. 
7.  To produce offensive noise, vibration, smoke, dust or other particulate matter, odorous matter, heat, humidity, glare or other objectionable effects. 
c.  Home occupations include: 
1.  Fine arts studios. 
2.  Professional offices. 
3.  Teaching of not more than four pupils simultaneously, or, in the case of musical instruction, of not more than a single pupil at a time. 
4.  Seamstresses, cabinetmakers. 
5.  Real estate or insurance agents. 
6.  Barber shops and beauty parlors. 
d.  However, home occupations shall not include: 
1.  Commercial stables, kennels, nurseries or farms. 
2.  Mortuary establishments. 
3.  Boardinghouses or roominghouses or tourist homes. 
4.  Commercial repair or storage of automobiles or watercraft. 
5.  Dance studios. 
(24)  Kennel means any zoning lot on which three or more dogs six months old or older are kept. 
(25)  Lot means the parcel of land on which any main building and any accessory buildings are placed, together with the required open spaces. 
(26)  Lot area means the area of a zoning lot. 
(27)  Lot depth means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
(28)  Lot width means the mean horizontal distance across the lot between the side lot lines measured at right angles to the depth. 
(29)  Main building means a structure in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which it is situated. 
(30)  Mobile home means a structure or vehicle with the following characteristics: 
a.  It is used, designed for use or capable of being used as living quarters, an office or any commercial activity; and 
b.  It is designed for transportation, after fabrication, on streets or highways on its own wheels and rests on its own chassis; and 
c.  It arrives at the site where it is to be occupied complete except for minor or incidental unpacking and assembly operations, locations on jacks or other temporary or permanent foundations, connections to utilities and the like. Any mobile home which has the characteristics of subsections (30)a. to c. hereof may be located in a mobile home or trailer court. A "trailer" is not a mobile home. See also "trailer." 
(31)  Mobile home lot means a parcel of land within a mobile home park designated for the placement of a single mobile home and for the exclusive use of its occupants and guests. 
(32)  Mobile home park or trailer court means any lot, parcel or tract of land together with open spaces required by this Ordinance, used, designed, maintained or held out to accommodate one or more mobile homes or trailers, including all buildings, structures, tents, vehicles, accessories or appurtenances used or intended as equipment of such mobile home or trailer court, whether or not a charge is made for use of the court and/or its facilities. A mobile home or trailer court does not include an automobile, mobile home or trailer sales lot on which unoccupied mobile homes or trailers are parked for inspection and sale. 
(33)  Mobile home park development means a contiguous parcel of land subdivided into individual lots, each lot individually owned and intended or utilized as the site for placement of a mobile home and its facilities. 
(34)  Motel means a building made up of two or more living or sleeping quarters used independently of each other and used principally for overnight accommodations. 
(35)  Multifamily dwelling means a building designed for and occupied exclusively as a residence for two or more families living independently of one another. 
(36)  Nonconforming use means a building, structure or premises lawfully occupied at the time of the enactment of this Ordinance by a use that does not conform with the provisions of this Ordinance for the district in which it is located; also such use resulting from changes in zoning districts or in textual provisions made hereafter. 
(37)  Nursing, convalescent home or home for the aged means any dwelling with sleeping rooms where persons are housed or lodged and furnished with meals and nursing care for hire, or a home operated by a nonprofit group and operated as an institution. 
(38)  Open space means an unoccupied space open to the sky on the same lot with a dwelling. 
(39)  Parking area means an off-street area containing one or more parking spaces of minimum size ten feet by 20 feet for driveways nine feet by 18 feet for parking lots with passageways or aisles assuring adequate access. Minimum size of one-way aisles shall range from 11 feet to 12.5 feet; two way aisles from 20 feet to 22 feet. 
(40)  Private recreation facilities means a facility such as a swimming pool, tennis court, community center, beach, boat dock or basketball court which is an accessory use located on residential zoning lots, the use of which is restricted to the occupants of the principal use and guests for whom no admission or membership fees are charged. 
(41)  Property owner means the owner or owners as recorded in the County Clerk's Office. 
(42)  Public means any land or building owned, used, or maintained by the federal, state, county or local governments or their agencies. 
(43)  Public utility means an activity, or a building housing such an activity, which operates to serve the community as a whole or a portion of the community, and which is publicly run or subject to special government controls. 
(44)  Rear yard means the open space extending from the rear of the main building and along the rear lot line (not necessarily a street line) and extending across the whole width of the lot. 
(45)  Roominghouse means a building or premises other than a hotel where lodging is offered by prearrangement for a definite period of compensation of three or more persons not open to transient guests, in contradiction to hotels, motels or tourist homes open to transients. A roominghouse shall not be deemed a home occupation. 
(46)  Side yard means the open space extending between the building and the adjacent side line of the lot extending from the front yard to the rear yard. 
(47)  Sign, billboard or pennant means any writing (including letter, word or numeral); pictorial representation (including illustration or decoration); emblem (including device, symbol or trademark); flag (including banner or pennant); or any other figure of similar character, which is a structure or any part or is attached to, painted on or in any other manner represented on a building or other structure. An illuminated sign located in a window is a sign. The area of the sign includes the support material from the bottom of the sign to and beyond the top of the sign. 
(48)  Single-family dwelling means a building designed for and occupied exclusively as a residence for only one family. 
(49)  Street line means a line defining the edge of a street right-of-way and separating the street from abutting property or lots. If, on the master plan of streets and highways duly adopted by the City, a street is scheduled for future widening, the proposed right-of-way line shown on the master plan shall be the street line. 
(50)  Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent location on the ground or attached to something having a permanent location on the ground. 
(51)  Subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, plots, sites or other division of land, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of legal or equitable title, interest or ownership or of building development, including all changes in street or lot lines; provided, however, that this definition of a subdivision shall not include bona fide divisions of land for agricultural purposes in parcels of more than ten acres not including any new street or easement of access. 
(52)  Tourist home means a dwelling, occupied as such, in which sleeping accommodations in less than six rooms with not more than four persons per room are provided or offered for transient guests for compensation, under the management of the occupants of that dwelling for dwelling purposes. A tourist home shall not be deemed a home occupation. 
(53)  Trailer, camping, means a portable or mobile living unit used for temporary human occupancy away from the place of residence of the occupants, and not constituting a principal place of residence of the occupants. 
(54)  Trailer, hauling, means a vehicle to be pulled behind an automobile or truck which is designed for hauling animals, produce, goods or commodities, including boats. 
(55)  Trailer park means a lot or premises occupied or designed for occupancy by two or more mobile homes. 
(56)  Variance means authorization by the Board of Zoning Appeals to an owner in the use of land or a structure when a literal enforcement of this Ordinance would result in unnecessary hardship. All variances shall be forwarded to Council and entered in their official minutes as a matter of public record. 
(57)  Yard means that portion of a zoning lot extending open and unobstructed from the lowest level to the sky along a lot line, and from the lot line for a depth or width set forth in the applicable district yard regulations. 
(58)  Zoning Board of Appeals means the Board of Zoning Appeals of the City of Hurricane, West Virginia. 
(59)  Zoning Ordinance or this Ordinance means the City Zoning Ordinance passed October 3, 1977, as amended. 
(Code 1991, § 1309.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977; Ord. of 7-7-2008) 
ARTICLE 1313. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State law references and cross references- Enforcement, W. Va. Code, § 8A-10-1; injunction, W. Va. Code, § 8A-10-3; penalty, W. Va. Code, § 8A-10-2; building permits, Article 1705. 

Sec. 1313.01. - Responsibility for administration and enforcement. 
    The Planning Commission and the Building Code Enforcement Official, with the aid of the Police Department, shall enforce this Zoning Ordinance, in accordance with the administrative provisions of the Building Code and this Ordinance. In the absence of a Building Code Enforcement Official, all applications for building permits for new structures shall be reviewed and approved by the Municipal Planning Commission or a member or members designated by the Commission before permits may be issued. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1313.02. - Application for building permit. 
    Every application for a building permit shall be accompanied by plans in duplicate, based on survey and drawn to scale in ink or blueprint, showing the actual shape and dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the exact location, size and height of the building or structure to be erected or altered, the existing and intended use of each building or part, the proposed number of families or housekeeping units, and such other information with regard to the lot and neighboring lots as may be necessary for the enforcement of this Zoning Ordinance. One copy of such plans shall be returned to the applicant when approved by the Building Code Enforcement Official together with such permit as may be granted. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.02; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1313.03. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    Before using any building or premises or part thereof hereafter created, erected, changed, converted or enlarged in use or structure, a certificate of occupancy shall be obtained from the Building Code Enforcement Official. Such certificate shall show that such building or premises, or part thereof, and the proposed use thereof conform with the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.03; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1313.04. - Procedure for violations. 
(a)  In case any building or structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure or land is used in violation of the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance, the City Solicitor, in addition to other remedies, shall institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use, to restrain, correct or abate such violations, to prevent the occupancy of such buildings, structure or land, or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about such premises. 
(b)  The Building Code Enforcement Official shall report all violations of this Ordinance coming to his attention to the City Solicitor immediately. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.04; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1313.05. - Injunction. 
    The Planning Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals or any designated enforcement official may seek a mandatory injunction in the Circuit Court directing a person or unit of government to remove a structure erected in violation of the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance or of any ordinance or rule and regulation adopted pursuant hereto. If the Commission, the Board or the designated enforcement official is successful in any such suit, the respondent shall bear the costs of the action. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.05; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1313.99. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or whoever resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance, where no other penalty is provided, shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day's continuance of a violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1991, § 1313.99; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
ARTICLE 1317. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State law references and cross references- Open governmental proceedings, W. Va. Code, § 6-9A-1 et seq.; establishment; composition, W. Va. Code, § 8A-8-1 et seq.; appeals, W. Va. Code, § 8A-8-10 et seq.; injunction, W. Va. Code, § 8A-10-3. 

Sec. 1317.01. - Appointment. 
(a)  A Board of Zoning Appeals shall be appointed by Council in accordance with W. Va. Code, § 8A-8-1 et seq. 
(b)  The Board of Zoning Appeals shall consist of five members who shall be residents of the City. Such members shall have been residents of the City for at least three years preceding the time of their appointment. No member of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be a member of the City Planning Commission nor shall any member hold other elective or appointive offices in the government of the City or the County. Members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms. The terms shall expire on January 1. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.02. - Officers; quorum. 
    At the first regular meeting of each year, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall elect a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson from its membership. The Vice-Chairperson shall have authority to act as Chairperson during the absence or disability of the Chairperson. A majority of members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall constitute a quorum. No action of the Board of Zoning Appeals is official unless authorized by a majority of the members present at a regular or properly called special meeting. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.02; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.03. - Reserved. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.03; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.04. - Powers and duties. 
    The Board of Zoning Appeals has the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Hear, review and determine appeals from an order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official or board charged with the enforcement of the Zoning Ordinance or rule and regulation adopted pursuant thereto; 
(2)  Authorize exceptions to the district rules and regulations only in the classes of cases or in particular situations, as specified in the Zoning Ordinance; 
(3)  Hear and decide conditional uses of the zoning ordinance upon which the board is required to act under the zoning ordinance; 
(4)  Authorize, upon appeal in specific cases, a variance to the Zoning Ordinance; 
(5)  Reverse, affirm or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and have all the powers and authority of the official or board from which the appeal was taken; 
(6)  Adopt rules and regulations concerning: 
a.  The filing of appeals, including the process and forms for the appeal; 
b.  Applications for variances and conditional uses; 
c.  The giving of notice; and 
d.  The conduct of hearings necessary to carry out the board's duties under the terms of this article; 
(7)  Keep minutes of its proceedings; 
(8)  Keep an accurate and complete audio record of all the Board's proceedings and official actions and keep the audio record in a safe manner, which audio record is accessible within 24 hours of demand, for three years; 
(9)  Record the vote on all actions taken; 
(10)  Take responsibility for the custody and preservation of all papers and documents of the Board. All minutes and records shall be filed in the office of the Board and shall be public records; 
(11)  With consent from the governing body, hire employees necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the Board. Provided, that the governing body sets the salaries; and 
(12)  Supervise the fiscal affairs and responsibilities of the Board. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.04; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.05. - Jurisdiction and powers. 
    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall have jurisdiction in matters and shall have the specific and general powers provided in this Zoning Ordinance in accordance with W. Va. Code, ch. 8A. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.05; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.06. - Map interpretation. 
    Where the street or lot layout actually on the ground, or as recorded, differs from the street and lot lines as shown on the official Zoning Ordinance Map, the Board of Zoning Appeals, after notice to the owners of the property and after public hearing, shall interpret the Map in such a way as to carry out the intent and purpose of this Ordinance for the particular section or district in question. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.06; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.07. - Appeal from decision of administrative official or board. 
(a)  An appeal from any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official or board charged with the enforcement of the Zoning Ordinance, or rule and regulation adopted pursuant to the Zoning Ordinance, shall be filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(b)  The appeal shall: 
(1)  Specify the grounds of the appeal; 
(2)  Be filed within 30 days of the original order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official or board charged with the enforcement of a zoning ordinance; and 
(3)  Be on a form prescribed by the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(c)  Upon request of the Board of Zoning Appeals, the administrative official or board shall transmit all documents, plans and papers constituting the record of the action from which the appeal was taken. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.07; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.08. - Hearing of appeal. 
(a)  Within ten days of receipt of the appeal by the Board of Zoning Appeals, the board shall set a time for the hearing of the appeal and give notice. The hearing on the appeal must be held within 45 days of receipt of the appeal by the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(b)  At least 15 days prior to the date set for the hearing on the appeal, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall publish a notice of the date, time and place of the hearing on the appeal as a Class I legal advertisement in compliance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 59-3-1 et seq., and written notice shall be given to the interested parties. The publication area shall be the area covered in the appeal. 
(c)  The Board of Zoning Appeals may require the party taking the appeal to pay for the cost of public notice and written notice to interested parties. 
(d)  At the hearing, any party may appear in person, by agent or by an attorney licensed to practice in this state. 
(e)  Every decision by the Board of Zoning Appeals must be in writing and state findings of fact and conclusions of law on which the Board based its decision. If the board fails to provide findings of fact and conclusions of law adequate for decision by the circuit court, and as a result of the failure, the circuit court returns an appealed matter to the Board and dismisses jurisdiction over an applicant's appeal without deciding the matter, whether the court returns the matter with or without restrictions, the board shall pay any additional costs for court filing fees, service of process and reasonable attorneys' fees required to permit the person appealing the Board's decision to return the matter to the circuit court for completion of the appeal. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.08; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.09. - Staying of work on premises when appeal taken; exception. 
    When an appeal has been filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals, all proceedings and work on the premises in question shall be stayed, unless the official or board from where the appeal was taken certifies in writing to the Board of Zoning Appeals, that a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property. If the written certification is filed, proceedings or work on the premises shall not be stayed. Nothing in this section prevents obtaining a restraining order. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.09; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1317.10. - Appeal from decision of Board of Zoning Appeals. 
(a)  Every decision or order of the Board of Zoning Appeals is subject to review by certiorari. 
(b)  Within 30 days after a decision or order by the Board of Zoning Appeals, any aggrieved person may present to the circuit court of the county in which the affected premises are located, a duly verified petition for a writ of certiorari setting forth: 
(1)  That the decision or order by the Board of Zoning Appeals is illegal in whole or in part; and 
(2)  Specify the grounds of the alleged illegality. 
(Code 1991, § 1317.10; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
ARTICLE 1321. - AMENDMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State law references and cross references- Amendment procedure, W. Va. Code, § 8A-7-8 et seq. 

Sec. 1321.01. - Power of council. 
(a)  Council may, from time to time, amend, supplement, modify or change, by ordinance, the boundaries of districts established on the official Zoning Ordinance Map or the regulations set forth in this Zoning Ordinance. Any proposed amendment or supplement or change shall first be submitted to the Municipal Planning Commission for its recommendation and report. 
(b)  Before amending the Zoning Ordinance, the Council with the advice of the planning commission, must find that the amendment is consistent with the adopted comprehensive plan. If the amendment is inconsistent, then the Council with the advice of the planning commission, must find that there have been major changes of an economic, physical or social nature within the area involved which were not anticipated when the comprehensive plan was adopted and those changes have substantially altered the basic characteristics of the area. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1321.02. - Hearing of planning commission. 
    Before submitting its recommendations and report to Council, the Municipal Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed amendment, supplement or change. It shall give at least 15 days' notice of the time and place of such hearing by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the City and by mailing notices to all property owners who, in the opinion of the Commission, may be affected by such amendment, supplement or change, and in accordance with such rules of procedure as it may establish. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.02; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1321.03. - Public hearing of residents; petition. 
(a)  No amendment, supplement or change in any of the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance or in the boundaries of any of the districts established thereunder shall become effective until after a public hearing in relation thereto, at which parties in interest and residents shall have an opportunity to be heard. At least 15 days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation, in the City. 
(b)  In case of a protest against a proposed change in the boundaries of a district signed by the owners of 20 percent or more of either of the area of the lots included in such proposed change, or of those immediately adjacent in the rear thereof extending 100 feet therefrom or of those directly opposite thereto extending 100 feet from the street frontage of such opposite lots, or the lots adjacent thereto, such amendments shall not become effective except by the favorable vote of three-fourths of all the members of Council. 
(c)  Any persons desiring a change in zoning of property shall accompany the petition for such change in zoning, or the ordinance introduced for the purpose of changing such zoning, with a statement giving the names and addresses of the owners of all properties lying within the block where the proposed change is to be made and within 200 feet of any part of the property proposed to be changed. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.03; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1321.04. - Fees. 
    Before any action is taken as provided in this Article, the party proposing or recommending a change in the Zoning Ordinance or district boundaries or any action necessitating a public hearing shall deposit with the Municipal Planning Commission the sum of $100.00 to cover the approximate cost of this procedure and under no condition shall such sum or any part thereof be refunded after deposited. No deposit of money shall be required when any action is recommended by the Planning Commission on its own motion. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.04; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1321.05. - Petition for change of zoning regulations. 
(a)  After the enactment of the Zoning Ordinance, the Planning Commission or the owners of 50 percent or more of the real property in the area to which the petition relates may petition to amend the Zoning Ordinance. The petition must be signed and be presented to the planning commission or the clerk of the Council. 
(b)  Within 60 days after a petition to amend the Zoning Ordinance is received by the Planning Commission or the Council, then the Planning Commission or the Council must hold a public hearing after giving public notice. The public notice of the date, time and place of the public hearing must be published in a local newspaper of general circulation in the area affected by the proposed zoning ordinance, as a Class I legal advertisement, in accordance with the provisions of W. Va. Code, § 59-3-1 et seq., at least 15 days prior to the public hearing. 
(c)  If the petition to amend the Zoning Ordinance is from the owners of 50 percent or more of the real property in the area, then before amending the Zoning Ordinance, the Council with the advice of the Planning Commission, must find that the amendment is consistent with the adopted comprehensive plan. If the amendment is inconsistent, then the Council with the advice of the planning commission, must find that there have been major changes of an economic, physical or social nature within the area involved which were not anticipated when the comprehensive plan was adopted and those changes have substantially altered the basic characteristics of the area. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.05; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1321.06. - Failure to give notice as provided by article. 
    The failure to notify, as provided by this article, shall not invalidate an ordinance, provided such failure was not intended and the omission of the name of any owner or occupant of property who may, in the opinion of the Municipal Planning Commission, be affected by such amendment, supplement or change, unless such omission is intentional, shall not invalidate any ordinance passed hereunder, it being the intention of this article to provide so far as may be for notice to the persons substantially interested in the proposed change that an ordinance is pending before Council, proposing to make a change in zoning. 
(Code 1991, § 1321.06; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
ARTICLE 1333. - DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED; MAP[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State law references and cross references- Zoning districts generally, W. Va. Code, § 8A-7-3. 

Sec. 1333.01. - Establishment of districts. 
    In order to apply the provisions of this Zoning Ordinance, the City is hereby divided into the following classes of districts for the purpose of zoning, shown in order of most restrictive to least restrictive: 
R-1 Single-Family Residential. 
R-2 General Residential. 
R-3 Mobile Home Residential. 
B-1 Business and Residential. 
B-2 Central Business District. 
B-3 Business and Highway Use. 
G General Use. 
(Code 1991, § 1333.01; Ord. of 10-3-1977) 
Sec. 1333.02 - Zoning of annexed areas to provide for pre-determination of the zoning class prior to annexation. 
    Unzoned areas to be annexed into the City shall be classified by the City prior to the annexation according to the use of the area. If the area to be annexed is other than R-1 single-family residential, the application shall be submitted to the Municipal Planning Commission for review, and a public hearing will be held, and the Municipal Planning Commission's recommendation shall be forwarded to City Council for final approval of the zoning classification. If any party desiring to be annexed does not agree or concur with the decision as to the zoning classification of the area to be annexed, the annexation applicant may withdraw his petition and the matter shall proceed no further. 
(Code 1991, § 1333.02; Ord. of 10-3-1977; Ord. of 1-24-2009)
